War News Summary B2

North Korea Announces
Policy Shift on Nuclear Talks
North Korea, in a major policy shift, said it would negotiate its nuclear program without sticking "to any particular dialogue format." The new policy signals an end to a six-month insistence on two-way talks with the United States. A4

Stalled U.S. Effort on Cuba
Cuba's jailing of dozens of dissidents and the execution of three ferry hijackers have stalled what had been an increasingly popular drive in Congress to ease trade and travel restrictions on the island. A18

Language Tensions Easing
The 40 year long uneasy relationship between English and French speakers in Quebec is easing as voters are seeking -- and finding -- a bicultural, bilingual accommodation over such issues as health care, taxes and the economy. A12

Japan Power Shortage Threat
Industry officials in Japan say the Tokyo Electric Power Company will have to press 16 nuclear power plants back into operation in order to avoid severe power shortages and even blackouts this summer. A23

SCIENCE/HEALTH

Health Workers on Front Line
SARS, a new and mysterious respiratory illness, has changed the lives of the healthcare workers on the front line, forcing them to think about ways to avoid catching the highly infectious disease, which has already hit at least 267 doctors, nurses and medical students. A16

NATIONAL A24-28

U.S. to Review Research At Hospitals for Veterans
The Bush administration has ordered a nationwide review of medical research at 115 veterans' hospitals and has halted some studies after investigators found serious violations of federal rules, including some that may have contributed to the deaths of patients. A24

Wilderness Protection Limited
The Interior Department wants to limit Bureau of Land Management lands eligible for wilderness protection to 23 million acres, a figure environmental groups say leaves millions of acres vulnerable to development. A24

Flaws at NASA Studied
Investigators of the Columbia shuttle accident are finding that serious problems with a particular component or components, repeatedly weathered by various shuttle missions, might have proved fatal in the end because management misread them as maintenance headaches. A27

Retiree Restoring Town
A retired businessman is buying up and restoring property in Tuscumbia, Ala., the rundown town where he grew up, as many small towns around the country are struggling financially. A26

EDUCATION

Beyond Privatization
The experiment that brought Edison and six other outside managers to run 45 of Philadelphia's schools caused widespread excitement last fall. But the educational and political landscape has shifted, and attention has turned to the new school chief, Paul G. Vallas. A24

NEW YORK/REGION A29-34

Experts Say Dispute at M.T.A. Stems From Structural Flaws
A dispute between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's inspector general and its top security official once again raises serious questions about the independence of the inspector general's office, the agency's corruption watchdog. Several experts and former inspectors general say there are inherent flaws with an office intended to serve as an independent monitor, but whose leadership and budget are controlled by the political apparatus it is supposed to police. A29

New York and L.A. Similarities
Social scientists have compared New York and Los Angeles. Partisans may be sorry to learn that the two regions strike some of them as increasingly alike. A29

OBITUARIES A35-36

Dr. Donald W. Fiske
A psychologist who challenged the idea that personalities could be defined with traits that were consistent through time, he was 86. A35

Chess A35
Weather A37
Cong. Vote A34

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: AMERICAN CASUALTIES; 
Plans for Families, Degrees and Careers Come to Abrupt End in Iraq

BYLINE:  By MONICA DAVEY 

 BODY:
Left behind, somewhere in the desert, were all of their plans.
 One Army captain was signed up to enter Harvard Business School once he got home. It would be another step, he hoped, on his way to teaching at the United States Military Academy at West Point. Another man, with 20 years of Marine Corps service behind him, planned to start a second career as a police officer as soon as his retirement papers came through. 
 And one young soldier, Devon D. Jones, hoped to teach English in a high school like the one from which he had just graduated. Private Jones knew he would need a college degree for that, which was why he had found himself in Iraq to begin with. 
" 'I don't have any other way to pay,' " his former girlfriend, Tiffany Taylor, remembered him telling her when he enlisted last year.
"That is the thing about him dying there," Ms. Taylor said of Private Jones, one of more than 100 Americans killed so far in the war. "So much lay ahead. He was really trying to do something in his life. He had everything ahead of him."
"That wasn't supposed to be it," she said. "It just wasn't."
The third week of war brought a turning point as American troops entered the heart of Baghdad and ousted the government of Saddam Hussein. And while many Americans were relieved that the war seemed to be moving more quickly than it might have, the week also brought the worst news to more than 40 families, families who learned that their own had perished in Iraq.
They died when helicopters crashed, and when a vehicle fell into a ravine. They died, eight more families learned last week, after an Army unit was ambushed in Nasiriya on March 23. They died in firefights as they entered Baghdad. 
But before that, before Iraq, all had plans. Some envisioned long military careers, as a way to carry on a family legacy, to earn a solid wage, or to follow a sense of duty. Others signed up to get somewhere else -- into college or a new job, out of a tough neighborhood or bad times. But, in their letters and phone calls home, when they mentioned SAT preparatory books and their babies' due dates, computer schools and long, hot showers, they had all been looking ahead, beyond Iraq, to futures they seemed certain they would have time to shape. 
Private Jones, 19, had told anyone who would listen that he wanted to become a teacher. While at Lincoln High School in San Diego, he volunteered to read to students at a nearby elementary school. He adored children, Ms. Taylor said, perhaps in part because his own childhood had been such a struggle.
Private Jones's mother went to prison and his family broke up early. He was sent to live in group homes for children, then found a woman who was willing to be a foster mother for him and his two younger brothers -- all of them together.
"He was avery grateful young man," Evelyn Houston, his foster mother, said. "He felt so thankful for a country that had foster care, when in many other countries they just abandon you."
When he enlisted in the Army a few weeks after high school graduation last summer, friends and teachers were surprised. But he said he wanted to help support his two younger brothers with the paychecks, and he wanted money the Army would offer him to go to college later.
He told Ms. Taylor that his work, inside a tank, turned out to be hard. The Army recruiters had not warned him about what it would really be like, she said he told her, and that he would not recommend the Army to others. 
Private Jones died along with two fellow soldiers -- Pfc. Wilfred D. Bellard, 20, of Lake Charles, La., and Specialist Daniel Francis J. Cunningham, 33, of Lewiston, Me. -- when their vehicle fell into a ravine on April 4. Private Jones's former English teacher said she had to remove his photos from her classroom wall. Otherwise, she could not stop crying.
The last time his foster mother spoke to him, Private Jones was in the desert, in a rush to use the phone before the next guy needed it, and asking for her prayers. He sounded upbeat, Ms. Houston said, but also a little scared. "He said, 'I signed on for it, and I ain't going to cry about it now.' "

'He Became Proud of Himself'
Six men perished together when their UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter, hovering above a battle, crashed in central Iraq on April 2. They had come from opposite ends of the country -- towns like Bennington, Vt., and Granburg, Tex. -- and, until that day, seemed headed toward separate futures.
Specialist Mathew G. Boule, 22, loved his flock of "birds" (that was the only term he would tolerate for the precious Black Hawks) but he also wanted to come home one day, to Dracut, Mass., his mother, Sue Boule, said. He dreamed of working as a police officer on a search and rescue team.
The service had changed her son, his mother said. He had given up baggy pants and wisecracks, she said. He wore his shirts ironed. And he seemed three inches taller than she remembered, even though he had not grown. "He wasn't slouching anymore," Mrs. Boule said. 
"We were proud of him for anything he did beforehand, but he became proud of himself, that's what it was," she said. "It seemed like he had a mission in life."
Chief Warrant Officer Scott Jamar, 32, of Granbury, Tex., had always wanted to be a military pilot, and had been in the service for more than 10 years -- long enough to know the military was going to be his life's work, his family said. 
The same held true for Chief Warrant Officer Eric A. Smith, 41, of Rochester, N.Y., who reminded his mother that if he had to die, he would rather do it flying a helicopter, and Chief Warrant Officer Erik A. Halvorsen, of Bennington, Vt., who had once given up the military briefly, only to return to it.
Officer Halvorsen, 40, had tried out commercial pilot work for an airline, but he found that he did not like it, his mother, Dorothy, said. There was too much sitting on the ground, not enough flying, she said. And he missed the camaraderie of the Army. So, in 1999, he re-enlisted.
"He found this structure something that was good for him," Ms. Halvorsen said. "He really did enjoy it. He wouldn't have gone back if he didn't. He lived in an apartment complex with a group of pilots his age, or younger, or people who had been involved with the military. That was what he enjoyed, to be with people who were a lot like him. They were all kind of loners, but they hung together."
But Capt. James F. Adamouski, 29, who was also on the Black Hawk, set an independent, ambitious course for himself. He and his wife were preparing to move from Savannah, Ga., to Cambridge, Mass., in August, so he could get his master's from Harvard. He learned that he had been accepted there in January, just before he was deployed to Kuwait. After business school, his family said, he planned to teach economics at West Point, from which he was a 1995 graduate.
"Jimmy was an individual who always looked deeply into what he was going to do and how he was going to do it," his father, Frank Adamouski, said. In the fourth grade, he picked West Point. At 12, when he missed the bus to his northern Virginia school one day, he called a cab for himself.
Captain Adamouski played soccer at Robert E. Lee High School in Springfield, Va., and again at West Point. He won first team all-conference honors in college, then played for a professional German team while he was stationed in Germany. 
He had served three tours in Bosnia, and one in Albania. This one looked like it would be his last.
When the crisis in Iraq emerged, Captain Adamouski was prepared, but he was also concerned, his father said. "I wouldn't say he had doubts. He had some apprehensions, as relative to things unknown. When you do this type of work, this is the job. You don't have an umpire or a referee to say 'play by the rules, and it's going to be a fair game.' It's not a soccer game; it's a war."
Circumstance had led Sgt. Michael F. Pedersen, of Flint, Mich., another member of the helicopter team, into the military. When he died, he had served seven years, and had already signed up for more. If he had lived, this seemed to be where he would have stayed, his mother said. 
And to think, way back, that he might not have joined. Sergeant Pedersen was just a teenager, still finishing Northern High School and working at a Long John Silver's in Flint, when military service dawned on him. His daughter had just been born. One day he came home and announced: "Mom, I've made a decision. Long John Silver's will never pay me enough to take care of my family."
"That's why he joined the Army," Lila Lipscomb, his mother, said. "From the beginning, when he signed up, his intention was to make it a career. He intended to retire from the Army."
When he was home this past Christmas, Sergeant Pedersen acknowledged that he had fears about what the future in Iraq might hold. He had no doubt that he needed and wanted to go, his mother said. 
Still, Mrs. Lipscomb said, "Just before he left he fell into my arms crying. He said, 'Mama, I'm so scared to go. I wish I didn't have to go.' My son was very concerned. But he knew what he had to do. He was part of a team. He loved being part of the team on that helicopter."
Mrs. Lipscomb said she was thankful when her son had first enlisted. "The Army gave him confidence," she said. "It allowed him to learn what it was to succeed. It made him the strong man he was when he died."
Days before that, his daughter, Destiny, turned 7.

'Opportunity to Better Himself'
Some of the Americans killed, especially some of the youngest ones, had seen their stints in the armed services as a chance to figure out just what their futures could hold. Some were still sorting out their plans, searching for what to do after this. They saw the Army, the Marines or the Air Force as a way to buy some structure, some adventure, a steady paycheck -- and some time to think.
Cpl. Mark Evnin's decision to join the Marines in 2000 after he finished high school was a recognition that he was not ready, just yet, for more school, his mother, Mindy Evnin, said. 
"He was always trying to figure it out," Ms. Evnin said of her son, who was 21 and lived in South Burlington, Vt. "Different days he wanted different things. But he knew for sure that to make anything meaningful out of his life he would need a college education."
Lately, he had talked about the Central Intelligence Agency or maybe the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He often asked his mother to pass along information about colleges so he could consider different options. Perhaps he would study international relations or foreign languages. 
Corporal Evnin was shot in the abdomen in a firefight in Iraq. Ms. Evnin will never know exactly what profession, what city, what family life he might have chosen. "But I'm sure he would have gone to college," she said. "And the thing about it is this: When he would have gone, he would have been ready."
In San Antonio, when Pfc. Anthony Scott Miller finished high school, he liked to draw and to listen to rock music, but he was uncertain about what to do next, his brother, Patrick Miller, said. When he signed up for military service last March, he was searching for direction, Mr. Miller said.
"It was an educational opportunity," Mr. Miller said. "He saw an opportunity to better himself." Private Miller was 19 when he died in Iraq.
In Temperance, Mich., Pfc. Juan Guadalupe Garza Jr. 20, had always struggled in school. Academics were especially hard for him, his aunt, Jodi Bucher, said. After high school, he was drawn to the Marines: he always had loved war movies and he had relatives who had served.
It was a remarkable change, Ms. Bucher said. In just nine months since he went to boot camp, he seemed happier and more successful than he ever had before.
In Iraq, his aunt said, a sniper shot him in the chest.
"It took him five years to get his life together, and he finally had," she said. "And then this. Things were just getting good for him. You can't help but think that he was too young to have this happen."
In Natchez, Miss., Cpl. Henry L. Brown's mother pressed him to enlist. "I thought it would be good, he being a mama's boy," his mother, Rhonda James-Brown, said. "I thought it would be one way to mold him."
Once Corporal Brown got into the Army, his mother said, military life absorbed him. He loved it. He met his wife in the service. He said he wanted to become a sergeant some day. "I said, don't stop at sergeant," his mother said she told him. "Go to the highest rank you can get."
Corporal Brown, 22, had started talking about a career in the Army, Ms. James-Brown said, and he even seemed to be thinking beyond that.
She remembered him telling her, "Mama, when I retire, I'm going to come home and sit on my porch."

'No Idea What War Would Be'
Others had seen the service as a ticket to education, pure and simple. They needed tuition money, and the military had all sorts of aid packages promoted on Web sites and in television commercials.
Cpl. Bernard G. Gooden, smaller, at 5-foot-4, than some marines, had no intention of staying in the service forever. He believed the Marine Corps taught values like toughness and discipline, but he also wanted to become a corporate lawyer, a family friend, Patricia Johnson, said. 
So in June 2001, he enlisted. 
"He had a lot of dreams," Ms. Johnson said. "But he didn't have the money. He went in the Marines hoping to do his time and get on out. He had no idea what war would be."
Corporal Gooden grew up in Jamaica, then moved to Canada as a teenager, shesaid. He ran out of money for his education there, and moved to the United States, settling with family in Mount Vernon, N.Y. When he died in a firefight on April 4, he was 22. He had hoped to go to New York University or Fordham, Ms. Johnson said.
Pfc. Chad E. Bales, meanwhile, wanted both: an education and a career in the military. His plan was four years in the Marines, four years of college, then back to the Marines as an officer. When he died he was 20, and in the first year of his plan. 
His stepfather, John Wayne Metcalf, of Coahoma, Tex., initially had some concerns about Private Bales's choice to enlist. Then he saw Private Bales graduate from boot camp.
"It was so amazing," Mr. Metcalf said. "It made him so proud. I had no reservations after that."
The last time his family heard from him, Private Bales was calling from the desert in mid-March. The wind was whipping up. Static crackled on the line. "The last thing he told his mom was, 'If you think we have sandstorms back at home in Texas, you should see this,' " Mr. Metcalf said. Then the line went dead, leaving Private Bales's mother weepy. "That whole night all she could talk about was how she hadn't gotten to say goodbye or anything."

A 'Sense of Adventure'
The service members left personal plans unfinished, too, their own and those of other people. Some had not started families yet, but had told their parents that they wanted to. Others left children behind. One woman, who was separated from her husband when he left for Iraq, said she would forever wonder if the marriage might have healed some day.
Private Bellard's wife, Letricia, is eight months pregnant with their second child.
Before he left Louisiana for the war, Private Bellard tried to talk to his wife about issues like benefits. He wanted her to know where everything was. He sent her a tennis bracelet set with opals, and the bank card.
Ms. Bellard, 20, said her husband also asked her to make sure, in case something happened, that the children never forgot him. The new baby's name, she said, will be Wilfred Jr.
Second Lt. Jeff Kaylor married his college sweetheart -- a fellow member of the Virginia Tech Reserve Officer Training Corps' Ranger Company -- last July, and was shipped out a few weeks later. They did not have time for a honeymoon.
Lieutenant Kaylor was on a regular rotation when he left for Kuwait, long before the conflict in Iraq felt imminent. "He had no idea there would be a war," his mother, Roxanne Kaylor, said.
"Jeff had always expressed that he'd like to have some sense of adventure," Mrs. Kaylor said from the family's home in Clifton, Va. 
Lieutenant Kaylor, 24, had gone to Virginia Tech on an R.O.T.C. scholarship, graduating in 2001. He followed in the path of his father, who retired from the Army in 1992. 
Lieutenant Kaylor's wife, Jenna Cosbey, was on tour in the Persian Gulf when her husband's death was reported.
Sgt. Duane R. Rios had met his wife, Erica, in high school. He joined the Marines in 1999, as a way to get work experience and good benefits and as a chance for him and his new family to leave the Midwest.
Sergeant Rios, who loved motorcycles and rap music, wanted to be a highway patrol officer eventually, but that was still at least three years away. Meanwhile, he told his wife, he was glad to fight in Iraq. It was the right thing to do, he said. But the sunsets, Ms. Rios said, will be harder.
They had made it out of the Midwest, after all, and settled on the California coast. "We have an apartment with a beautiful panoramic view," she said. "I would fall asleep in his arms and watch the sun go down."

'He Loved It'
For the most certain among these service members -- the people who knew they wanted military careers -- their deaths meant an end to the march they had long anticipated through the ranks. 
Before they left, some of them expressed concern about what dangers might be ahead on the battlefield, while others took care of financial matters -- just in case. But they also told their families that they expected to come home. And when they did, they said, they planned to keep working their way along, the same as before, in the military.
Staff Sgt. Wilbert Davis, 40, had joined the Army a little later than some people. As a young man, he had worked for a Tampa utility company, his family said. But then, at his sister's suggestion, he tried out the military, his niece, Likeithia Davis, said.
"And he loved it," Ms. Davis said. "In the military you have great benefits as far as for your family and your retirement plan. The military is just good all the way around, as far as family. He always said that -- that he loved it."
Sergeant Davis seemed destined to stay until he finished his 20 years and retired, she said. In fact, he seemed to be making plans for other people's futures too: he often recommended the Army to young people in his old Tampa neighborhood, Belmont Heights, as one way out.
"He just wanted to show them that there is something outside," Ms. Davis said. "He went and said, 'You know, there's a future. It's O.K.' "
Sergeant Davis, she said, was never one to "bite his tongue as far as giving advice." 
Sergeant Davis died when his Humvee ran off the road and flipped into a canal in Iraq. A journalist, Michael Kelly, was with him, and also died.
Sergeant Davis served in the first Gulf War and in Afghanistan, Ms. Davis said. "Then when this one turned around, he was just like: this is my job, this is what I have to do. This is what my commander in chief has put on my plate."
Lance Cpl. Andrew Julian Aviles was far earlier in his military career, and, at 18, far younger. But he already viewed military service as his duty.
"Andy from an early age knew what he wanted out of life," his uncle, John Aviles, said. "His attitude was: after I graduate, I fulfill my military obligation, then come back and go into business, go into officer candidate school making the military a career. We talked about it. I was very proud of the fact he wanted to do this."
Military service ran through Corporal Aviles's family tree, Mr. Aviles said. "He took it as a moral obligation because of our ideals about the military. We're from the old school, we felt military service is something everybody in the family should do. He felt very strong about it, he liked the R.O.T.C., he liked what he saw."
Just out of high school, Corporal Aviles was to serve a nine-month assignment, as part of his plan to become a Marine Corps officer. A scholarship was waiting for him at Florida State University when he got back.
"Andy has always been a focused young man, involved from an early age," Mr. Aviles said.
School officials in Tampa, where he graduated from high school in 2002, said Corporal Aviles had been practically everything: student government president, a cheerleader, wrestler, naval junior R.O.T.C. program cadet, National Honor Society member, and ranked third in his class of 335.
He died on April 7 when an enemy artillery round struck the amphibious assault vehicle he was riding in. He would have turned 19 this month.

'Starting Something New'
First Sgt. Edward C. Smith, 38, of Vista, Calif., had lived out one of his plans already. As his 20-year Marine Corps service date drew close, he began planning for what he might do next, once he retired from the military. Like so many of his colleagues, he was drawn to law enforcement work.
So, a few years ago, he signed up for the Palomar College Police Academy in San Marcos, Calif. If he was older than most recruits, it did not show. He finished first in his class. 
Still on active duty in the Marines, Sergeant Smith went on to join the Anaheim Police Department as a part-time reserve officer, riding as a second officer on patrol rounds, becoming part of the special weapons and tactics team, and serving in the detail that stood guard when the Anaheim Angels played in the World Series. The city department named him reserve rookie of the year in 2000. A year later, the surrounding county, Orange, gave him the same award.
By this year, he was prepared to take a full-time slot with the police department. All he had to do was retire from active service in the Marines. 
"He was looking forward to that very much," Sandy Smith, Sergeant Smith's wife, said. "I think he had done the 20 years with the military, and that was enough. He was starting something new."
Months ago, before the war in Iraq, he submitted his retirement papers, Ms. Smith said. He had hit the 20-year service mark this past January, but then came word that the Marine Corps was not allowing retirements like his -- not in times like these, she said.
Sergeant Smith would have to wait one more year, until January 2004. 
Despite that, he did not object to being deployed to the war, his family said. He felt it was his duty, they said. "He was just going to go over there to take care of business," said Tony Toliver, his brother-in-law.
Then he would come back and get his full-time police badge. When they heard of Sergeant Smith's death, Anaheim police officers covered their own badges with black bands.

*Date of deaths uncertain. These eight were ambushed on March 23. Their deaths were announced April 5.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE OPPOSITION; 
Both Iraqi Exiles and Residents Invited to Talks on Government

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12 

 BODY:
About 100 Iraqis, drawn from those who have lived under the fallen government or in exile, have been invited by American officials to gather Tuesday in Nasiriya for talks aimed at building a new government while avoiding the appearance of anointing leaders, administration officials said today.
 Two-thirds of those invited to the session, the first since the war began, were "Iraqis who have been living in newly liberated areas of the country," a senior administration official said. He described the rest as "Iraqis living in freedom," including expatriates and people coming from semiautonomous Kurdish areas in the north. 
 The Bush administration was taking steps to avoid recent criticism that it was playing favorites with well-known opposition leaders, in particular Ahmad Chalabi of the Iraqi National Congress, based in London, who has close ties to a number of senior Pentagon officials.
Mr. Chalabi and several other outspoken opposition figures were asked to send representatives, but were not themselves invited, so that the others in attendance -- especially those who have spent their lives under the previous government -- would not feel overshadowed, the official said.
"The main point is to start a process where Iraqis can begin to discuss among themselves the shape of the government of a free Iraq," the official said. "The goal is to identify principles that Iraqis can agree on -- and in that context I would say that democracy takes many different forms.
"We are aware that foreigners cannot prescribe the form it should take in Iraq."
The administration is also trying to show that the Defense Department, the State Department and others in the government are broadly in agreement over how to proceed, despite recent frictions over the postwar management of Iraq, where the administration intends to create an interim authority to pave the way for an independent government.
Invitations to the daylong meeting were issued by Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the wartime commander, although he is unlikely to attend himself. Lt. Gen. Jay Garner, the retired Army officer chosen by the Bush administration to manage the initial Iraqi civil administration, will run the meeting.
Others who will represent the administration are Zalmay Khalilzad, the president's special envoy to the Iraqi opposition; Ryan C. Crocker, deputy assistant secretary of state for Middle Eastern affairs; and Larry Di Rita, special assistant to Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, officials said.
Britain, Australia and Poland, the three other nations that have contributed combat troops to the war, will send representatives, and Spain, which recently dispatched a field hospital, will send an observer.
The Nasiriya session, the senior administration official said, "is just the start of a process." The goal is to "transfer as much authority as possible as quickly as possible to the Iraqis," the official added.
Topics of the opening session are likely to include the role of law and legal institutions in a new Iraq, protections for civil liberties, choices for economic institutions and concepts for a constitution, the official said. "Democracy isn't built -- it grows," the official said. "And it doesn't grow in a day or week or a month."
The official declined to predict whether the future leadership of Iraq would emerge from the 100 people invited to this meeting, or whether the government would be drawn from those who might emerge at the next set of sessions.
"That is a complete unknown," the official said. "We thought it was very important to get the process started, even though the war is not over yet."

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: ISTANBUL; 
Turks and Kurds Maintain a Mutual Suspicion

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, April 12 

 BODY:
Almost as soon as Kurdish forces streamed into the northern Iraqi city of Kirkuk this week, American diplomats were on the phone to Turkish government officials to assure them that allied forces would take control of the situation.
 That pledge had an immediate practical goal: to keep Turkish troops from entering the region, thus preventing the possibility of clashes between Turkish soldiers and Iraqi Kurds. 
 But it also recognized the bitter history between Turks and Kurds, a volatile relationship that preceded the war in Iraq, hovers around its edges and could threaten the stability of the region in the future.
Many Turks maintain a profound suspicion that Kurds in Iraq and Kurds in Turkey have long wanted their own state, one that could ultimately claim territory from Turkey. In that view, Kurdish control of Kirkuk and the nearby Iraqi city of Mosul, both rich with oil, could be a first, pivotal step in the process. 
"That's the worst-case scenario for Turkey," said Mensur Akgun, director of foreign policy at the Turkish Social and Economic Studies Foundation. "Although I don't think that it would ever materialize, Turkish leaders still worry about it."
Many Kurds in Iraq and Turkey, for their part, worry that Turkish leaders will spare no effort to repress them. They cite the long period of emergency rule under which the Turkish government placed the densely Kurdish southeastern region of the country, from the mid-1980's until recently. It was prompted by a separatist rebellion among some Kurds there that included guerrilla warfare and an aggressive crackdown by the Turkish military. The fighting left tens of thousands of people dead.
During that time, the Turkish government placed restrictions on Kurdish language and education, and human rights advocates say Turkish soldiers routinely tortured Kurds.
But the roots of the reciprocal animosity run deeper than that.
After World War I, when the victors drew the boundaries of the Middle East, they left the Kurds without a state of their own, dispersing them in Iraq, Iran, Syria and Turkey. In all those countries, Kurds were an ethnic minority. In Turkey, their expressions of ethnic identity -- including, for some, a devout adherence to Islam -- rivaled the insistence by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the first ruler of the Turkish republic, on a coherent, secular national identity.
Over the decades, there have been sporadic Kurdish uprisings in southeastern Turkey, coupled with swift reprisals by the Turkish government. But it was not until the late 1970's and early 1980's that Kurdish resentments in Turkey and neighboring countries took on a nationalist and separatist cast. That crystallized with the founding, in 1984, of the Kurdistan Workers Party, a militant group that waged its campaign of terror in southeastern Turkey.
By the late 1990's, Turkey had essentially crushed that rebellion, but human rights advocates and many Turkish political experts say the Turkish persecution of Kurds in the southeast continued.
They say it still does, despite the recent passage of laws here that eased restrictions on Kurdish language, education and broadcasting. Last month, a Turkish court shut down one of the leading pro-Kurdish political parties.
Other experts say the Turkish government, eager to draw closer to the European Union by improving the country's rights record, has made strides toward improving its treatment of the Kurdish minority.
Turkish government officials say they do not see most Kurds in Turkey as latent separatists and note that a majority of the country's roughly 12 million Kurds do not live in the southeast, where the worst tensions exist.
But they say that when Iraqi Kurds entered Kirkuk and Mosul this week, it fueled Turkish anxieties about a potentially rich, autonomous Kurdish state that Kurds in southeastern Turkey would want to join or emulate. "This fed a certain mentality, a kind of obsession," said one senior Turkish government official.
Political experts said there was yet another psychological dynamic at work: Turkey's preoccupation with the security of its borders and the safety of its territory.
"This is the legacy of the Ottoman Empire," Mr. Akgun said. "We lost an empire, and that's why we are so concerned with the fate of the country."

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
Opening the Books Should Open N.H.L.'s Eyes

BYLINE:  By STU HACKEL; Stu Hackel, a former N.H.L. director of broadcasting, is a freelance writer.

 BODY:
Four weeks ago, the Los Angeles Kings fan Phil Propper sat in a Midtown Manhattan restaurant explaining how he became the first fan to examine a team's financial records. The Kings' president, Tim Leiweke, had claimed that his team would lose at least $10 million, and to mollify skeptics who feared that the club would soon trade star players in a salary dump, he offered to open his books. 
 Viewed from this coast, Leiweke seems an eccentric among hockey executives. He utters profanity on radio programs and publicly blasts the Rangers for driving up player salaries, claiming he cheers for the Rangers to lose games as hard as he does for the Kings to win them (Alas, neither made the playoffs.). Further, he actively courts his fan base, especially the zealots who congregate on the Web site www.LetsGoKings.com. But Leiweke may not have figured that one of those zealots, Propper, would be a trained financial analyst who would take him up on the offer to look at the team's books. 
 Between bites of Asian duck, Propper explained, "I'm just a fan trying to help my team," and revealed he was no longer a skeptic about the Kings' financial situation. His examination showed the Kings were indeed losing money. His report, posted April 3 on LetsGoKings.com under Propper's nom de Web, Piston, is a complicated, intriguing hybrid of fact, analysis and opinion on the Kings' and the National Hockey League's business. It's the product of a passionate fan with a specific expertise and an agenda -- to avert a work stoppage when the labor agreement expires after next season. His report doesn't get all the facts right, tortures some analysis and is, in spots, as blunt as a puck in the face. But it's not all wrong, either.
 You can bet that the N.H.L. gave the report, and a yellow highlighter, to a knowledgeable staff member to punch holes in it. The league has reason for concern, for Propper singles out N.H.L. policies and programs as the fountainhead of the hockey's river of red ink.
 The league's first spin on the report was, predictably, to dismiss it, saying a glance at one team's numbers doesn't translate to the whole league. True, Propper didn't see all the books, but he understands more than most about the hockey business model and how the cash flows. From publicly available sources, he has estimated ticket revenue, player salaries and other key variables to get a picture of the N.H.L.'s economics. The picture is not pretty.
 Whatever flaws reside in Propper's report, he has articulated the core truth of today's N.H.L.: hockey's economics are broken, a claim the owners have made, but he puts the blame squarely on their expansion to 30 teams from 21. The owners, he writes, spent their $570 million in expansion fees, a nonrecurring source of revenue, on players, exploding the average salary from $271,000 in 1991 to $1.6 million today, a higher average than the far healthier National Football League. Since the 1994 lockout, salaries jumped 240 percent while revenue grew only 171 percent. Those expansion fees have now ceased, but the players must still be paid. It is a recipe for disaster.
 Propper has words for the N.H.L. Players Association, too. He found no evidence that the Kings hid revenue through transfer payments, a legal bookkeeping tactic that shifts money between subsidiaries of a company to decrease tax exposure. If that's true for other teams as well, admittedly a big if, it smashes a cornerstone of the N.H.L.P.A.'s appeal to its members, that the owners habitually cry poverty and hide profitability in negotiations. That charge lay at the heart of "Net Worth" (Viking), a 1991 book by David Cruise and Alison Griffiths that chronicled an exploitive history of owner-player relations. Although also flawed, "Net Worth" served as a primer for the 1992 players strike and sustained them through the 1994 lockout. Propper believes the union today seeks "to correct legitimate grievances from two decades ago rather than focusing on current problems."
 Propper's answer to hockey's problems is eliminating four to six failing teams. Neither labor nor ownership would welcome this economic Darwinism. The players could lose 150 jobs; the owners would most likely suffer a decrease, at least temporarily, in franchise value and an erosion of their television footprint. But however odious, Propper argues it is the most sensible way to a new agreement. He reasons that if the league aims to save the fiscally weak teams through a salary cap lower than current salary levels, it would be "the height of arrogance on the part of the owners" to assume that the players would accept a rollback. Furthermore, an artificially low cap would allow wealthy teams to reap huge profits and ultimately perpetuate the disparity between the haves and have-nots. Theoretically, Propper's trimmer N.H.L. maintains present salary levels and restores healthy, competitive franchises.
 Propper suggests the possibility of merging the two Florida teams (the Miami-based Florida Panthers and the Tampa Bay Lightning) and the two Alberta teams (Calgary Flames and Edmonton Oilers) and splitting home games between two sites. It's an example of his occasional fuzzy thinking, because players and members of management can live in only one city and it burdens those clubs with 50 percent more road games and escalated costs associated with a second market. Still, credit Propper with creative attempts to solve difficult issues.
 The perils of real world contraction can't be underestimated. In addition to legal hurdles and broken hearts, both players and owners would have to sacrifice and abandon long-held positions. Commissioner Gary Bettman has displayed great perseverance attempting to save weak franchises; he was less inclined to do so early in his tenure. Executive Director Bob Goodenow reformed and strengthened the union after an era of accommodation by Alan Eagleson. Bettman and Goodenow might balk, but their business is in a bad spot. 
 Propper believes they owe fans a dispassionate examination of his report, assessing its value to the game's future. On that, he is certainly right.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
At Augusta, Burk Has Just Cause but Naive Blueprint

BYLINE:  By SELENA ROBERTS 

DATELINE: AUGUSTA, Ga., 

 BODY:
REMOVED from the fairway dogwoods with snowflake petals, a grassy pit alongside Washington Road became a Valley of the Dolls as Martha Burk's posse filed off a bus yesterday. 
 In a scene that was one Incredible Shrinking Head short of a carnival, polished patrol cars shone like hard candy under the sun, parked in rows to divide the protest freaks (the Ku Klux Klan's pro-Hootie contingent of one) from the protest meek (the two dozen Martha assembled for change). 
 Satellite trucks sent out the kooky contrast, each parked across from a Methodist church with a marquee that read: "Personality can open doors, but only character can keep them open." 
 Not true. It takes a good strategy to pry open some barriers. Burk's group had a just cause in protesting the all-male membership at Augusta National Golf Club, but a naive blueprint to process the message. 
 Burk underestimated the local hostility of Augusta residents who believed she was the one to blame for the dip in their annual economic boom even though Hootie Johnson instigated the fray by disclosing her private letter to the club last summer. 
 "She can't get out of here fast enough for me," said Maureen Robinson, a bystander taking in a view that included a police paddy wagon. "She has made us look bad." 
 Genius, that Hootie. For the last 10 months, the Augusta National p.r. machine has successfully demonized Burk, casting her as an attention-seeking troublemaker without addressing the issue of sexism at all. 
 Brilliant, that Hootie. He also used his 2-iron will on local politicians to push for a protest ordinance that kept the noise from disturbing Augusta National's peace. (Shhh Tiger is putting for the cut.)
 Burk never saw the bully tactics coming. And that brings us back to the soggy field on Washington Road, site of inconsequence. 
 After the volume from Helen Reddy's "I am Woman" was lowered over the loudspeaker, Burk pointed out that women can march in front of the White House, but not in front of the gate at Augusta National. "Even Bush let us get closer than a half-mile away," she said. 
 Out in the pit, Burk's band would be neither seen nor heard by the corporate club members they picketed. Kept from the menfolk, they would not be noticed, nor be relevant to any golfers who played.
 Marginalized on the outside of the gates to Augusta National as they have been on the inside by the club's all-male policy, they were powerless and pointless.
 As club members might cackle, "You would think a bunch of gals would know a vacuum when they saw it." They were operating in one. The only bold lady capable of affecting change at the event was in the shape and form of a Big Bertha driver by Calloway. Every other dangerous dame was corralled by patrol cars in the abyss. 
 Perfect placement. Wonderful lie. Only those with the perfectionist gene that was passed from Clifford Roberts, the holy creator behind the making of Augusta National, to Hootie Johnson, the current caretaker of its antebellum tradition, could appreciate the juicy juxtaposition. 
 Outside, chaos. Inside, calm. As long as the progressive real world and Hootie's version of Pleasantville didn't commingle, as long as there was not a gate-crashing demon in Burk's demonstration, the dividing line would remain intact. Men in, women out.
 To understand this savored degree of gender separation, realize that the difference between Hootie and Martha comes down to the tape measurements and chalk marks of a tailor: size 44 regular versus size 8.
 To allow a woman as a member would require putting darts in the sacred green blazer. To give a woman the secret password to power would mean altering the design of a pair of shoulder pads. To add a woman to the lineup of American influence would throw a female curve into the barrel-chested club pictures.
 Variances are not welcome here, a fact in every detail of this club's history, beginning with Roberts and ending with the man who embodies Roberts's spirit, Hootie Johnson.
 As the author David Owen explains in his book, "The Making of the Masters," Roberts was misperceived as a "tyrant who ejected a player from the Masters for a trivial infraction, sent members bills for course improvements they had been rash enough to suggest, withdrew the memberships of men who had dared to cross him, and administered nervous breakdowns to a succession of executives at CBS."
 Many accounts were tall tales, but Roberts was a man who couldn't tolerate the slightest visual imbalance. As Owen describes, "pictures at the club are still hung on two hooks, because crooked pictures drove him to distraction."
 When Roberts played the course, he took note of everything, from broken tree branches to wilting azaleas. Owen writes, "While playing the ninth hole once, he decided that the frame of the dormer that was then under construction on the west wing of the clubhouse was not plumb.
 "By the time the group had finished the round, there were carpenters on the roof banging hammers against two-by-fours."
 This is what Burk needed to execute her message: a few hammers on the inside to be heard. Infiltrators wanted. As history makes clear, alterations only come from within the gates of Augusta National Golf Club. By peaceably remaining in the Valley of the Dolls, Burk was too ladylike in her meekness.
 By shouting from the carnival midway, she was also exactly where Hootie wanted her: on the outside of the club, in an imperfect world.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
LIEBRADER, MYRON LAWRENCE

 BODY:
 LIEBRADER-Myron Lawrence, Passed away Friday, January 31, 2003, age 73, after intrepid battle with leukemia. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y. Former resident of Sunnyside and Bayside, Queens. Son of Sol and Estelle Liebrader, beloved husband of 13 years to the late Barbara Liebrader. Survived by his son Andrew, daughter Donna, sister-in-law Ginny, brother-in-law Rick, and friend/companion Patricia Kobetts. His father, Sol, was a C.P.A. and his mother Estelle worked in real estate and for an attorney, named Lawrence Brinn. His parents also owned two candy stores in Queens. After his wife passed away in 1976, Myron Liebrader served as two parents to Andrew and Donna since Andrew was eleven yrs. old and Donna was eight. His family moved to Sunnyside from Brooklyn when he was eight years old. He graduated from Brooklyn Tech. H.S. He earned a B.A. Economics and M.A. Social Studies from N.Y.U. He also minored in math while in college. He spent two years in the Coast Guard during the Korean War. He also earned all the credits for a doctorate although never completing his dissertation. ABD, (All But Dissertation). Myron Liebrader started teaching social studies at Grover Cleveland H.S. in Ridgewood, Queens, N.Y. in 1954. His career at Cleveland lasted 47 years, which is a record for the most years spent by one person in the same high school building in the history of the N.Y.C. School System. He became Cleveland's principal in 1971 and remained in that position for 30 yrs. before retiring in 2001 as the most senior high school principal in the N.Y.C. School System. 
More teachers working under his direction went on to become supervisors and principals than any other principal in the history of the school system. He also taught a course at Q.C.C. at night for 37 years to prepare school secretaries for the N.Y.C. school system. Thank you, Dad, for teaching us to be decisive, not to look back too much, and to get the most out of life that we could get. Thanks also for teaching us to bring things to a closure and for being the exemplary man that you were. Contributions, in his memory, can be made to the Leukemia Fund, L.I.J. Medical Center, 270-05 76th Ave., New Hyde Park, N.Y. 11040 Attn: Dr. Kanti Rai.

HEADLINE: SENIORITY; 
Lost in the Shuffle, a Sign of Strength for Social Security

BYLINE:  By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach and arrival of retirement appears the second Sunday of each month. E-mail: fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE trustees of Social Security issued their annual report on March 17 -- the day President Bush gave Saddam Hussein an ultimatum to leave Iraq within 48 hours. Two days later, the war began.
 The Social Security report was little noticed in the news media, which were busy covering the conflict. That oversight was unfortunate, because the trustees had some good news. They extended by a year two important deadlines often cited by critics as evidence that the system faces real trouble: 
 * The projected point at which tax revenues will fall below expenses, forcing the system to dip into its trust fund to pay benefits, was moved to 2018 from 2017.
* The point at which the trust fund will be exhausted was put at 2042, instead of 2041 as cited in the report last year.
Oddly, the headline on the news release summarizing the report -- "Social Security Not Sustainable for the Long Term" -- seemed a tad pessimistic, given that a trustee report as recently as 1995 had put the date for the trust fund to be depleted at 2030. That's 12 years earlier than is now expected.
Sure, it's technically true that if nothing changes -- if Social Security taxes are never increased no matter how much the economy grows, and if all economic and demographic projections are perfectly on target -- then the system in 2042 will be able to pay only 73 percent of scheduled benefits. But that's a lot of ifs spread out over almost four decades.
The trustees' report actually peers 75 years into the future. To fill the gap created by the expiration of the trust fund in 2042 and to keep the system going until 2077 would require an additional $3.5 trillion, it says. That's $200 billion more than was estimated in the report last year.
That $3.5 trillion sounds like a lot of money, but it covers a 75-year period. To put it in perspective, Social Security taxes would have to rise today by 1.92 percentage points, half paid by workers and half by employers, to fill that gap. That would mean that both workers and employers would pay a rate of 7.16 percent; they now pay 6.2 percent. Of course, the longer we wait, the steeper the increase would have to be.
But there are alternatives. The government could enact a smaller tax increase, for example, but also raise the amount of a person's annual income that is subject to Social Security taxes. The ceiling is now $87,000; earn more than that and it's free of Social Security taxes. Raising the ceiling, however, would involve raising taxes on wealthier people -- not a popular idea in Washington these days.
All of this, of course, is based on very long-term projections by a government that has often had trouble predicting budget surpluses and deficits a year or two in advance.
"There is a tremendous amount of uncertainty in a 75-year projection," conceded John L. Palmer, one of two appointed public trustees for Social Security and Medicare. Mr. Palmer is an economist and the dean of the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University.
THE Social Security system pays benefits out of current taxes, with the surplus going into a trust fund so money will be available for the expected large numbers of retirees as the baby boomers start collecting benefits in a few years.
That trust fund, which is invested in government bonds and is often misunderstood, has become a political football. Its expected depletion is cited by critics who want to "save" Social Security by privatizing it or are ideologically opposed to the concept of government-sponsored social insurance. That the fund is expected to start redeeming its bonds in 2018 to help pay benefits is often decried as a huge problem for Social Security because the payout would come from the Treasury.
But that's not Social Security's problem. It's a fiscal problem for the government, which has borrowed the money by issuing the bonds. Through 2002, the fund contained nearly $1.4 trillion in bonds, which earned interest of 6.4 percent last year -- or $80.4 billion. If Congress doesn't want to repay the money, it shouldn't have borrowed it. To see the redemption of those bonds as Social Security's problem is akin to borrowing money from a bank and then, when the debt comes due, declaring it the bank's problem.
Mr. Palmer agreed with that assessment but noted that the exhaustion of the trust funds in 2042 would be Social Security's problem.
Viewing those bonds as a Social Security problem also flirts with the assumption that the government could default on them, something that has never happened in the nation's history. A lot of people own government bonds; some rich people own a lot of them.
"Ross Perot has invested in U.S. Treasury bonds, and nobody is talking about his not being paid," said Mark Weisbrot, co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research and co-author of "Social Security: The Phony Crisis" (University of Chicago Press). "Why should 150 million workers be treated any differently?
"What if Social Security had invested this money in private corporate bonds? We wouldn't even be having this discussion. They would just be cashed in."
Mr. Weisbrot also thinks that the Social Security system is basically in good shape and that future problems will be minor and readily solved.
"By 2042, people will be making 40 percent more than they are today, in real inflation-adjusted terms, according to the trustees' own projections," he said. "Is anyone really worried about paying an additional
1 percent of their income for a system that keeps our old people out of poverty? Maybe people who are ideologically opposed to the concept. But the Social Security tax has been raised by more than this is the past. The projected shortfalls are less than the shortfalls that were taken care of in the 50's, 60's, 70's and 80's. The system is more sound than it's been throughout most of its 67-year history."
He added: "I just wish the critics would be honest and tell people there is a small problem 40 years down the road that can be easily fixed. If it weren't for the powerful influence of Wall Street, which wants the commissions privatization would bring, and politically active ideologues, this wouldn't even be an issue."

HEADLINE: The War Goes Well. So Where's the Dividend? 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
THE images of military triumph from Baghdad last week, as Saddam Hussein's statue and his regime toppled, brought a measured sigh of relief from the business world. Economists' worst fears about the impact of the Iraqi war had not materialized. American casualties were limited. There were no big oil-field fires, and no terrorist reprisals yet on American soil. So far, so good, it seems. 
 Yet business executives and economists said in interviews last week that while the progress of troops in Iraq was unquestionably good news for the economy, as one source of uncertainty recedes, it remains to be seen whether the battlefield success will prove to have been a turning point. Still unclear is whether consumer confidence and business investment will not only revive from their war-jitter depths but also begin a more sustained recovery. 
 The answer, the executives add, will depend partly on the longer-term geopolitical ripples that extend from the conflict in the Middle East. Can the United States military greatly reduce its involvement in Iraq soon, or will the troops be mired there in a lengthy police action? Will ousting Mr. Hussein be a step toward greater stability in the region or bring an anti-American backlash and fresh waves of terrorism? 
Echoing the views of several executives, James M. Zimmerman, chairman of Federated Department Stores, said that it was "way too early to tell how the end of the war" would affect his company's chains, which include Bloomingdale's and Macy's. Yet Mr. Zimmerman said he was struck by the fact that stock prices barely moved after American troops seized control of the major government offices and the Hussein family palaces in Baghdad last Wednesday -- a Wall Street shrug, he said, that "clearly indicates that there are other factors at work in the economy that have as much, if not more, impact on what we can expect to see in the weeks and months ahead."
The economy, executives and economists note, faces a litany of uncertainties beyond the war -- including an alarming rise in jobs lost, rising state and federal deficits, and signs of a retreat from the commitment to free trade and globalization. Individual industries are confronting their own challenges, from the falloff in travel to Asia because of fears of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, to the enduring slump in the information technology and telecommunications businesses.
"We had this big cloud in front of us called Iraq," said David Wyss, chief economist of Standard & Poor's. "But we're still not sure what smaller ones are behind it."
The war has clearly hit American business -- trimming perhaps half a percentage point off economic growth in the first half of this year, economists estimate. 
The prospect of war in the early months of the year added to the uncertainty in an already shaky economy, prompting companies to put off some investments and some consumers to forgo costly purchases. Once the bombing began on March 19, the distraction effect took hold as people stayed home more to watch television news of the war. Advertising and retail sales fell.
Companies have issued profit warnings recently, saying quarterly earnings would be less than Wall Street had expected and blaming the war. Some, like Barnes & Noble, point to the war as the main culprit. Others, like Siebel Systems and PeopleSoft, which sell expensive software to corporate customers, cited the war as a contributing cause. "The environment for capital spending worsened in the first quarter with added concerns about the war and its impact on the already weakened economy," said Craig A. Conway, chief executive of PeopleSoft.
Now that a crucial chapter of the war seems closed, the outlook will hinge largely on consumer and corporate attitudes, according to the executives and economists. Since last fall, consumer confidence has dropped sharply. One widely watched confidence index produced by the Conference Board, a business research group, fell from 93.7 last September to 62.5 in March, an unusually steep slide.
Despite the soft economy of the last couple of years, the auto industry has held up comparatively well. "But we are definitely seeing a weakening of demand, and it tracks very closely with consumer confidence," said Rick Wagoner, chief executive of General Motors, who was among a few dozen executives who met with President Bush at the White House last Thursday. Mr. Bush was trying to garner business support for his tax-cut proposals. The House has approved the president's plan for tax reductions of $726 billion over 10 years, but the Senate trimmed the package to $350 billion.
Some critics of Mr. Bush, as well as some economists, fear that the administration's plan will mortgage the economy's future by drastically increasing the federal deficit.
Mr. Wagoner said he came away from the White House convinced of the wisdom of the Bush administration's recipe for recovery. A "very aggressive package," he said, will "greatly heighten the chance that the economy can get back on a more rapid growth pace."
CONSUMER confidence appears sure to rise with some of the uncertainty of the war in Iraq removed. The University of Michigan, which, like the Conference Board, compiles a widely followed barometer of confidence, reported on Friday that its preliminary confidence index for early April rose to 83.2 from 77.6 in March, which was the lowest level in nearly a decade. Indeed, after the Persian Gulf war in 1991, consumer confidence surged for a while but soon fell again because corporations continued to trim payrolls. Over longer periods, consumer confidence tends to track closely with job prospects.
Companies have been cutting their payrolls sharply the last two months, eliminating 465,000 jobs. Out of the two million jobs that theeconomy shed in the last two years, nearly a quarter of the loss came in the last two months.
With business weakening and some economists warning of a double-dip recession, executives have focused on cutting costs to try to shield profits before the situation worsens. The impulse is understandable, but some executives worry that the conventional wisdom -- that you can't go wrong by avoiding risk, cutting costs and trimming workers -- could bring a self-reinforcing deflationary cycle.
"A lot of people in business today feel frozen in the headlights of uncertainty," said Eric P. Best, a managing director at Morgan Stanley. "They feel that the only smart strategic decision is to do nothing, which may well not be the case."
Still, there are hopeful signs that things may improve somewhat as war uncertainty recedes. At Trammell Crow, the commercial real estate firm in Dallas, Bill Concannon, president of the global services unit, said, "The market was actually slower before the war started. We see some renewed sense of optimism that the nation is getting back to business now that some certainty has been brought to the Iraq standoff."
For Hyundai Motor America, which has 600 dealers, sales in March were the second best in its history. The only local markets where sales fell were ones with military installations, like San Diego. Robert Cosmai, vice president for national sales, said he was cautiously optimistic that the fall of the Hussein government would improve the business climate.
At Carlson Companies, a travel business whose holdings include the Regent and Radisson hotel chains, the military victories in Iraq last week were seen as an encouraging indication that the worst of the travel industry's woes were over. "I think with the war ending, we're going to have people more confident about travel and corporations more confident about putting people back on the road," said Marilyn Carlson Nelson, the chief executive.
DOMESTIC travel, she said, will improve first. "People are concerned especially about a backlash against Americans," she said. "We'll need a little more time before the number of Americans traveling abroad increases." In East Asia, Mrs. Nelson added, SARS, not war, is the chief preoccupation.
The slump in technology spending began in fall 2000 -- long before troops headed to Iraq and about a year before 9/11. The added uncertainty because of Iraq put a damper on all capital spending, and investments in information technology -- computer hardware and software -- are about 40 percent of all private capital expenditures.
"The economic uncertainty attributable to the war comes up in conversations with customers, and it casts another layer of doubt," said Bruce Claflin, chief of 3Com, a producer of computer networking equipment. "But it's not the core issue in technology capital spending."
Mr. Claflin says the industry is in a long period of slower growth, greater reliance on standard parts and relentless pricing pressure. 3Com's employment has fallen to about 4,000 from 12,000 in fall 2000.
Having pared back and farmed out most of its manufacturing to low-cost producers abroad, 3Com, Mr. Claflin said, is ready to pursue promising growth areas, which will mean renewed investment and selective hiring in the future. "But our industry," he said, "is never going to grow as it did before."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
A Walk On the Supply Side Of a New Iraq

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
BY the Bush administration's reckoning last month, the cost of waging the war against Iraq will run about $62 billion. By contrast, the cost of rebuilding that country afterward is estimated at only $3.6 billion.
 For those who argue that the United States is either being stingy or unrealistic about the postwar costs, administration officials have invoked an analogy of the supply-side economic philosophy that they are using to sell tax cuts at home. 
 Just as President Bush's package of $726 billion in tax cuts can at least partly pay for itself by stimulating faster economic growth, they say, much of Iraq's reconstruction can be self-financed by the country's own postwar economic expansion. 
"Iraq is a relatively wealthy country," said Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., director of the White House Office of Management and Budget. "There is a lot of upside potential."
Rebuilding Iraq, administration officials say, is different from rebuilding a country like Afghanistan, which has fewer natural resources and a primitive infrastructure. Afghan leaders pleaded for $10 billion in assistance and got pledges of $4.5 billion from foreign governments and organizations.
By contrast, Iraq has 112.5 billion barrels of proven oil reserves. Its oil fields, though in need of extensive refurbishing, were pumping about two million barrels daily before the war and could be revved up to at least 2.5 million barrels a day in less than a year. 
Iraq's population is largely urbanized, its health care system is relatively advanced and it has much more than Afghanistan in terms of highways, electricity grids and telephone networks.
Administration officials have not said how much the Iraqi economy might expand. But they note that Iraq would benefit almost immediately from a lifting of the United Nations sanctions imposed since the end of the first Persian Gulf war. That, combined with an end to the corrupt repression of the government of Saddam Hussein, could mean that Iraq's economy is poised for a substantial rebound.
What administration officials do not mention are the elements of "downside potential" to Iraq's economy. Iraq still faces $172 billion in unsettled compensation claims that stem from its invasion of Kuwait in 1990. Under Saddam Hussein, the government also ran up foreign debt of $62 billion to $130 billion, according to analysts at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a research group.
Most of the foreign creditors wrote off their loans as uncollectible many years ago, but they have not abandoned their claims and are still looking to get back at least a few cents on the dollar. Iraq, meanwhile, faces compensation claims from Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and other countries that lost property during the first Persian Gulf war.
Under the United Nations' oil-for-food program, Iraq has been required to surrender 28 percent of its revenue from oil exports, much of that to pay down compensation claims. That has translated in recent years to annual payments of about $4 billion, or about $166 a person in a country with a per capita annual income of $2,500 in 2001.
"That is hard cash going to people outside Iraq," said Frederick D. Barton, an analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.
White House officials have acknowledged that they will have to deal with the debt issue, but they have yet to hint at what they might do.
Even assuming that Iraq escapes most of its foreign debt -- Kuwait and Saudi Arabia account for 47 percent of the claims pending against Iraq at the United Nations Compensation Commission -- it needs to build a new financial system, along with a credible currency and legal infrastructure in order to gain investor trust.
 THOSE who anticipate a rapid rebound of Iraq's domestic economy can point to the so-called economic miracle of West Germany after World War II. 
But there is a more troubling analogy: Russia after the collapse of Communism in 1991. Like Iraq, Russia had vast oil reserves -- and many other natural resources. Even more than Iraq, it had an educated population and substantial industrial infrastructure. And Russia, much like Iraq, had been suffering from a toxic mix of totalitarianism, militarism and corruption.
But after "regime change," Russia's economy faltered. It contracted by a third in the mid-1990's, and the financial system all but collapsed in 1998. Only in the last two years has the economy begun to improve, thanks in part to rising prices for oil exports, though it still appears to be smaller than it was when the old system ended in 1991. Real wages for workers were twice as high then as they are now.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Iran Warily Confronts New Neighbors: Americans

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

 BODY:
AN American rocket killed a 13-year-old boy. A second injured three people; a third struck an empty Oil Ministry depot. These were not precision strikes in Iraq. They were rockets gone astray, landing in Iran.
 Yet Iran's Islamic Republic has chosen to ignore the attacks. Despite its troubled history with the United States, it has shown no inclination to provoke it militarily. 
 During the war next door, in fact, the official policy has been one of "active neutrality," which allowed the United States to prosecute the war even as Iran's officials denounced it. 
But last week, as the war appeared to be nearing a moment of decisive victory for the Americans, Iranians at all political, economic and social levels were asking one question: What happens to us now?
Certainly no one in Iran knows. But Iranian officials are determined to survive by getting along with whatever government emerges in the aftermath of an American victory -- and perhaps even by talking to the United States.
The civil disorder that followed the collapse of Saddam Hussein's authority was deeply disturbing for Iranians, who worried that it might spill across their borders. Iran fought its own eight-year war against Iraq two decades ago, a conflict waged largely on Iranian territory that crippled Iran's economy and killed at least 300,000 Iranians. That experience has left many Iranians ambivalent about America's triumphal entry into the center of Baghdad. Mr. Hussein, who was often described in Iran as "bloodthirsty," has no Iranian defenders. But the fact that he seems to have been so swiftly defeated by Iran's other arch-enemy is unsettling.
Night after night in the war's opening days, the conservative state-run television ran reports of heroic opposition by the Iraqi people to American tanks and fighter planes, predicting that the United States would fall into a quagmire.
But Iran is a place where, despite episodic repression, there is also a lively press -- both reformist and conservative -- as well as easy Internet access and illegal satellite television. After the Americans reached downtown Baghdad, the reformist newspaper Yas-e-No published the headline, "Saddam Ran Away," and the conservative paper Resalat wrote, "Baghdad was taken over without a fight." So the propaganda fell flat.
The official unease with the war was clearly illustrated in the stance of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's spiritual leader, who had referred to it as a "new form of Hitlerism." In a sermon on Friday, after saying that Iran is "happy about Saddam's departure," he added that American plans to install a transitional military administration in Baghdad amounted to "a bigger dictatorship" than that of Mr. Hussein.
Iranians at all levels know that their next-door neighbor is about to be occupied for an unknown period by the United States, and that this may change a great many things. Iran is still technically in a state of war with Iraq; both sides still hold prisoners of war, and Iran is still demanding billions of dollars in war reparations (an unrealistic goal given that Iran continued the war for years after Iraq wanted to end it). A grim illustration of the unfinished business of the Iran-Iraq war was the discovery by British soldiers last week of the remains of 200 people at a military base near Basra. They turned out to be Iranian soldiers killed in the 1980's.
Another major issue will be access to Najaf and Kerbala, two of the holiest shrines in Shiite Islam -- the faith to which 80 percent of Iranians subscribe. Mr. Hussein kept the shrines largely closed to Iranian pilgrims. A new government that represents all Iraqis, about 60 percent of whom are Shiite Muslims, would find it hard not to open up the shrines to the hundreds of thousands of Iranians a year who would want to come.
The fate of the Mujahedeen Khalq, an Iranian opposition group long based in Iraq under Mr. Hussein's protection, is unclear. Iran will also need a working relationship with Iraqi Shiite groups, who stand to gain a degree of political power. Finally, the fall of Mr. Hussein has raised the prospect of legally recognized autonomy for Iraq's Kurds, which frightens Iran as much as it does Turkey and Syria. All three have Kurdish populations bordering Iraq.
The war has also reignited an intriguing debate among Iranian officials and intellectuals about whether it is in Iran's interest to begin a diplomatic dialogue with the United States. The coordinating council of groups in the reformist camp issued a declaration last Thursday warning that "authoritarian regimes create the context for foreign involvement," adding that talking to the United States does not mean acceptance of its behavior. On the same day, a Web site connected to the reformist Mosharekat party, quoted Iran's elected president, Mohammad Khatami, saying in a closed meeting of cabinet and parliamentary leaders that "talking with the United States is in the interests of Iran." Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former president who is head of the powerful government oversight body known as the Expediency Council, is quoted by the same Web site as saying that if the parliament proposed talks with the United States and sent a plan to his council, "we will consider it."
There are, of course, huge issues that aggravate the American-Iranian relationship. The United States has long demanded that the Islamic Republic halt what American officials say is an active program to build nuclear weapons, and that it end support for anti-Israeli militias like Hezbollah. And many Iranians wonder whether, as part of what Mr. Bush has called an "axis of evil," they will be next on the list for a pre-emptive attack.
Many Iranians remember a C.I.A.-led coup half a century ago that overthrew the government of Prime Minister Mohammad Mossadegh and reinstated the monarchy. And such fears were only heightened two weeks ago, when Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld warned Iran not to allow Iraqi opposition troops based on Iranian soil to enter Iraq, saying that the United States would treat them as combatants and hold the Iranian government responsible.
Last week, though, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell tried to calm the waters, telling the London-based newspaper Al Hayat, "There is a constant desire by everybody to accuse us of invasion operations." That, he added, "won't take place."
No matter what the United States does, Iranian officials insist they will find a way to deal with whoever comes to power in Iraq. 
"We don't have a choice of neighborhood," said Javad Zarif, Iran's ambassador to the United Nations. "We have to do the best we can to live in peace and tranquillity with our neighbors."
