HEADLINE: A Basketball and a Dream 

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
Relishing the occasion of his American professional debut and a moment he recognized as classically Kodak, the rookie from the Republic of Georgia sauntered onto the court to face a player who certainly needed no introduction.
 "You know who I am?" Kevin Garnett, the Minnesota Timberwolves' All-Star forward, asked the bewildered rookie, just to make sure.
 Of course he knew. Back home in Tbilisi, Georgia, Nikoloz Tskitishvili's long-distance hero, his stylistic role model, had been Garnett. Now, face to face at the Target Center in downtown Minneapolis, Garnett was suddenly his snarling antagonist, filling the air with profanity, taunting Tskitishvili, a 19-year-old rookie with the Denver Nuggets: "You think you can guard me? You can't guard me." 
 With no time to think, much less back down, Tskitishvili returned four-letter fire, only to wonder later why Garnett had challenged him at all. "I love the American black players and I always want to be like them," Tskitishvili said. "But how can you say such thing? You are All-Star and I am just kid."
 The Nuggets, one of the worst teams in the N.B.A., bet the fifth pick of the 2002 draft that the 7-foot Tskitishvili (pronounced TSKEE-tish-VEE-lee) would grow into stardom, as have other imported players like Dirk Nowitzki (Germany) of the Dallas Mavericks and Pau Gasol (Spain) of the Memphis Grizzlies. For a team in need of wholesale help, Tskitishvili was a radical choice, considering that months before he was drafted, even N.B.A. insiders had never heard of him.
 His selection emphasized the increasing confidence and even preference N.B.A. teams are showing for international players. Nearly 20 percent of the N.B.A. is foreign-born, more than double the number five years ago. In a league with about 348 active players, 66 international players from 34 countries have appeared in games this season. The 2002 draft began with Houston selecting Yao Ming, the 7-foot-6 Chinese center; current projections indicate that as many as eight first-round picks could come from outside the United States in the June draft.
 Tskitishvili's on-court impact this season has been negligible compared with Yao's, and even compared with that of Tskitishvili's rookie teammate, the Brazilian forward Nene Hilario. But if Tskitishvili, known affectionately as Skita around Denver's home court, the Pepsi Center, eventually lives up to his draft standing, teams will no doubt expand the search for the most obscure potential talent. The prediction once made by Tskitishvili's Connecticut-based agent, Marc Fleisher -- that the N.B.A. will eventually be half foreign-born -- will appear more unavoidable than audacious.
 "You have great life here," Tskitishvili said in his stiff yet confident English, one of six languages he speaks. "You have opportunity. Everybody wants to come."
 He was speaking of a generation of young foreign players raised on televised images of Michael Jordan and American popular culture. Finishing a rookie season that ends tomorrow while watching bombs rain on Baghdad has been unsettling, he said. Childhood memories of civil war in Georgia remind him that television reports resembling coverage of a sports event are far from reality.
 During his first year in the United States, Tskitishvili has embraced everything American, from his favorite city (San Francisco) to his favorite singer (Tupac Shakur) to his favorite television show (Jerry Springer). This is understandable for a young man who was left fatherless at 2, who at 15 considered himself his family's breadwinner and who was handed a three-year, $7 million contract just months after his 19th birthday, along with the perks of celebrity immigrant status.
 In late October, the Nuggets helped his 12-year-old half-brother, Giorgi Kipiani, obtain an education visa that allowed him to leave Georgia, where publicized wealth created kidnapping fears. Hours after Garnett rudely introduced Tskitishvili to the American form of athletic diplomacy known as trash talking, he parked his Lincoln Navigator outside a hotel in downtown Denver. It was early Halloween morning, a blanket of snow already down.
 He walked briskly through the lobby, his boyish face reddened by the cold and the excitement of his family reunion. When the door of Room 303 opened, a 12-year-old rushed past his mother and took wide-eyed measure of the brother he had not seen in more than a year.
 "Nika!" Giorgi cried. "You got taller."
 In size and in stature, for Nikoloz Tskitishvili, a kid from Tbilisi, a product of that N.B.A. global generation, had made it to America against incalculable odds. Back home in Georgia, and in countries worldwide, young boys were reminded that all they needed was a ball, a dream and the chance to be seen.

Scouting for Players, Selling a Dream
 Pushing 100 miles an hour, his left hand steady on the wheel of his BMW, Reed Salwen glanced at the dash to determine the origin of the incoming call, then mixed and matched the appropriate language and greeting.
 From Italian to Russian, Spanish to French to an occasional "My man," Salwen, a 36-year-old New Yorker and the main European operative for the agent Marc Fleisher, chatted into his wireless headset with a fraternal recognition, a cool confidence. Factoring in the easy smile and the stylish shades, the most flattering imagery was Tom Cruise. Or truer to character: Jerry Maguire, gone continental.
 The calls were constant: a Ukrainian playing basketball in France in need of a pep talk, a Frenchman in Bologna deserving a lecture, a Croat in Trieste begging for a bed.
 Young men relocated across cultural lines required an agent's comforts, coddling and companionship, and not necessarily by phone. "My second home," Salwen called the autostrada, as Milan, his base, faded in the rearview mirror on the way east. In Treviso, a city of 85,000 just south of Venice, another Georgian gem would be making his Euroleague debut for the powerful Benetton club, as Tskitishvili had the previous season.
 "From a basketball perspective, Skita just came out of nowhere," said Jeff Weltman, the Nuggets' assistant general manager, who scouted Tskitishvili when he played, sparingly, for Benetton last season.
 Salwen had first seen Tskitishvili at a tournament in Slovenia after being tipped by a Georgian sports entrepreneur on a boy soaring toward 7 feet tall who had the raw but unmistakable skills of a 6-footer and whose lightness afoot was traceable to youthful years performing in a Tbilisi dance troupe.
 Now that Tskitishvili was safely delivered to the N.B.A., it was time to nurture Manuchar Markoishvili, also hailing from Tbilisi, and following in Tskitishvili's choreographed steps, from dance stage to slam dunk. Markoishvili, all of 16, was already signed and sealed to Fleisher.
 Everywhere, it seems, boys barely adolescent are being "tagged and identified" -- as Weltman put it -- though the difference abroad is that the talent hunt is unburdened by ethical debate regarding the need for a purely amateur experience, much less a college degree or even a high school diploma.
 Outside the United States, and especially in the Republic of Georgia, little doubt is left that it is truly about the money. "I remember reading that Shaquille O'Neal signed for $76 million a few years ago," said Markoishvili, a 6-foot-6 guard with the face of a cherub atop the body of an adult fitness fanatic. "They said in the paper that O'Neal has more money than the whole Georgian economy."
 At La Ghirada, a stretch of land on the outskirts of Treviso on which the Benetton clothing giant operates an impressive sports complex it even calls its campus, Markoishvili was studying Italian, absorbing English and living in an austere, dormlike room, where the only visible reading material was an Italian-Georgian dictionary, an Italian N.B.A. magazine and the Bible he brought from home.
 "He doesn't have to worry about anything except basketball," said Ettore Messina, the Benetton coach this season and a fixture around the Italian game. "He is lucky to be here."
 This is the inverse of the American system, where ostensibly amateur high school and college programs profit as showcases for the gifted and talented. Extreme case in point: LeBron James, the Akron, Ohio, scholastic star, whose games for St. Vincent-St. Mary High School this season became news media spectacles, national referendums on ethics in sports. The view from Europe is that the American system has become inimical to comprehensive player development, lavishing undue enticements and empowerment on impressionable teenagers when what they most need is an apprenticeship to better grasp fundamentals and team play.
 "That's what I find college coaches telling me," Messina said. "They get to a point where they can't stand it. The players are too spoiled. They've got leverage: 'You don't want me, no problem, I'll go someplace else. I'll go to another team, another school. I'll get drafted.' The coaches have to beg. Once the big pride of Americans was the education and teaching, but it's no more like that."
 As an 18-year-old last season, Tskitishvili averaged 12.7 minutes a game for Benetton. On the night the team won the Italian League title, he served teammates Gatorade and the only moves he made were the graceful Georgian pirouettes he performed as a child -- "strong dance, with knife, no tutu," he said -- at a team celebration. Only at practice could Tskitishvili flaunt the size and skills that sent American scouts home raving about him as the next Nowitzki.
 In December, Weltman, the Nuggets' assistant general manager, returned from another scouting trip to Italy with the opinion that Markoishvili had the potential to follow Tskitishvili to the N.B.A. -- more good news for Fleisher, Salwen and even Mauricio Gherardini, the Benetton general manager, who in the fall of 2001 signed Tskitishvili, then with a Slovenian team, to a seven-year, $1.2 million contract with a $1 million buyout clause.
 This is now standard practice, as European teams adapt to the mining of their market by deep-pocketed Americans. "When you go after young players like Skita, you make the investment, mature the player and hope he gives you two to three good years," Gherardini said. In Tskitishvili's case, Gherardini got half a season of service -- 11 games, 73 points -- but the return of $1 million.
 Tskitishvili, for his part, lived the good Italian life last season, toured the Continent and, in effect, won the American basketball lottery. "He calls me all the time, saying, 'Thank you, Reed, thank you so much,"' Salwen said. "These kids, they're amazing, how grateful they are, what they'll do, and the obstacles they have to overcome."
 Salwen could still picture the small, decrepit gym in St. Petersburg, Russia, where Andrei Kirilenko, the Utah Jazz's long-limbed forward and the first client he signed for Fleisher, learned to play. "He took a trolley 45 minutes every day and walked in snow knee-high to get there," Salwen said. "Let me tell you, for all the talk about how bad things are in urban America, I lived a year and a half in Los Angeles, I've seen Compton. It's still not Russia."
 Salwen studied Russian, economics and political science at McGill University and Oxford, and moved to Moscow during the early 1990's, working in tennis and hockey and later for Nike. He met a Georgian, Zurab Bokolishvili, who was trying to establish a sneaker outlet in Tbilisi, and who would later summon him to Slovenia to see Tskitishvili in a junior tournament.
 Only when Salwen signed with Fleisher in 1999 did he leave Russia after seven adventurous years in the new cradle of capitalism. If Italy and Spain were not the big European basketball markets, he would never have left the region he calls "the wild east."
 "Sometimes I miss the States," he said, "but I don't know where I fit into that fat, S.U.V. culture anymore. I love to hustle."
 Treviso one night, Bologna the next, Siena, Rome -- or jetting off to Barcelona, Belgrade or Vilnius, Lithuania. It is a hectic, crazy life, Salwen acknowledged, even sacrificial, considering 40 is not far ahead on life's autostrada.
 He keeps going, Salwen said, because the physics of basketball have changed forever, and somewhere out there is another Tskitishvili, a teenager ready to bound improbably onto the radar and maybe all the way into the N.B.A. draft.
 When Tskitishvili went from nowhere to No. 5 and all the way to Denver, it told Salwen that anything was possible, that the world was shrinking and that an agent had better be willing to go anywhere, anytime, even places like Tbilisi, in the heart of the Caucasus, which Salwen had already mined as a fertile hunting ground with the best of conditions.
 "Great people," he said. "No rules." 

Beginnings in Art Give Way to Sports
 Guliko Tskitishvili craned her neck outside on the narrow terrace of her apartment on the sixth floor of 2 Nutsubidze Plato on the outskirts of Tbilisi. The steady pounding of a basketball could be heard on the cracked cement of a ramshackle play area below, but she had to see for herself, make sure her younger son was still there.
 "I don't worry for me, only if they will take Giorgi," she said, as her sweet-faced boy with the shock of dark hair and a Denver Nuggets jersey with "Tskita" on the back hoisted shots with friends at a netless rim attached to a fraying wood backboard. "When he plays in the yard, I am always near."
 As if contradicting her concern, the afternoon sky was cloudless, conceived for the carefree. A tall, robust woman, Guliko Tskitishvili was laying out a Georgian-style holiday spread, or supra, under a striking chandelier. Behind the table stood an upright piano. Tasteful paintings adorned the walls.
 "We are people of art," she said, explaining that she, like Nikoloz, had danced as a younger woman, while her husband, Misha, sang and acted before a fatal auto accident in 1985. Their daughter, Nino, had been a model and competed in a European beauty pageant as Miss Georgia.
 When their Soviet-style housing complex was built more than 20 years ago, the location, on a hill with a view of the Mtkvari River running through the heart of Tbilisi, was a sign of prestige, a reward for the artistic. Now, as they are all across the city, such buildings are architectural blemishes across the undulating landscape, their exteriors giving the appearance of rotting hulks.
"After the Communists fell, nobody has the money or the desire to do anything," Guliko said.
 Conversely, she knew the name Tskitishvili in Georgia was now synonymous with new wealth, and while there had been no formal threat made by organized crime, it was not difficult to conjure up fear. At a downtown soccer stadium that same week, Zurab Bokolishvili, the Georgian sports agent who had led Tskitishvili to Reed Salwen, pointed out the captain of the Georgian national team, Kakha Kaladze, who is a well-paid star for the Italian power. 
 "His brother was taken more than a year ago," Bokolishvili said. The kidnappers, believed to be bandits operating near the border with Chechnya, demanded $600,000. The brother, a medical student, has not been heard from since.
 In Georgia, the state of affairs as it struggles to establish democracy might best be described as murky, and occasionally dark. At halftime of the soccer match, a 0-0 European qualifying grudge match with Russia, the stadium lights died.
 "Maybe politics," Bokolishvili said, considering that the Russians were controlling play, a defeat for Georgia would have meant elimination and lights were shining elsewhere in a city infamous for power failures.
 Almost an hour later, the no-frills stadium, having survived the rampant lighting of newspapers into flaming torches in a crowd of chain-smokers, emptied despite no announcement of the game's postponement. With a way-of-life shrug, Bokolishvili made his way to a Dodge Durango, parked across the street, right on the sidewalk, with apparent police blessing.
 His brawny driver proceeded to tear through town at hair-raising speeds, ignoring traffic lanes and red lights. "No problem for us," Bokolishvili said -- either a boast that men with connections in the right places and handguns in their waistbands need not worry about potential consequences, or a simple assurance that this was what passed here for expert driving.
 Whatever the mores, whatever the unseen dangers, the city these days was practically Singapore compared with Tbilisi in the early 1990's, when street fighting broke out after the fall of the Soviet Union and armed rival gangs roamed the streets.
 The preadolescent Nikoloz Tskitishvili was then following his mother's lead in the Georgian national dance. But by his 12th birthday, already 5 feet 9, he was outgrowing the disciplines, and the modest basketball court Giorginow roamed became his new stage, until he was good enough to venture downtown, to places like the Vere Basketball Hall, with its regulation court, 2,500 seats and no heat.
 "No coaches in America would train in such cold," said Vaja Kvarachelia, while watching a scrimmage of young boys.
 Bundled in old sweats, Tskitishvili had trained under Kvarachelia, his first coach and volunteer surrogate father, who himself had been an orphan at 5. "It is why there became such a relationship between Nika and me," he said. "I was always jealous of those children who had fathers, so when I saw how gifted a child he was, I always wanted to somehow substitute for his loss."
 In the dark and cold, he would walk his prize pupil home, a couple of miles, so Tskitishvili's mother would not worry. He would fill the disbelieving teenager's head with possibilities of going beyond the Georgian league and Europe, and all the way across the Atlantic. Kvarachelia's eyes moistened when he said: "Because of the dance, I could see his movement. I felt it was destiny."
 He also knew that the transition to the N.B.A. would be difficult for a still-developing young man from a country incapable of fitting all its players with appropriate footwear. Kvarachelia hoped people in both countries would have patience, but back at 2 Nutsubidze Plato, where Giorgi had returned from the basketball court and Guliko's guests had sat down to eat, Zurab Bokolishvili -- the table's tamada, or toastmaster -- raised his glass and said, "To Nika, our great natural resource." 
 To a guest he added, "In one or two years, better than Nowitzki."

Seeking Sense of Home Amid Trappings of Wealth
 On the night Mike D'Antoni came to visit in Denver, Tskitishvili was excited to show off the trappings of his new, suburbanized American life, which included the Lincoln Navigator with the customized television, the $2,800-a-month condo in trendy Cherry Creek and his regular dinner haunt, the local sushi restaurant.
 D'Antoni, who was Tskitishvili's coach with Benetton last season, had also made the jump to the N.B.A., as an assistant coach with the Phoenix Suns. Tskitishvili had a special fondness for D'Antoni; as a parting gift, he had presented him with the special knife he used for his Georgian dance at the team's championship party.
 While Guliko picked at a salad and Giorgi at his brother's California rolls, D'Antoni and Tskitishvili reminisced and caught up.
 "Are you still in touch with Laura?" D'Antoni asked.
 Tskitishvili blushed. Laura Mori, a 17-year blonde Benetton hostess and model, had been his girlfriend in Treviso, apparently without his mother's blessing. ("No Laura, Georgian girl!" Guliko had declared when asked in Tbilisi about the budding romance.)
Tskitishvili smiled shyly. "You know, I break girls' hearts all over the world," he said. "Georgia. Slovenia. Italy."
 "You need to find one here," D'Antoni said.
 Tskitishvili shook his head, and explained that he and the other rookies had been warned at the league's orientation program about women who prowl the N.B.A. circuit to exploit young players for money. "I am so scared of American girls," he said.
 With an affectionate laugh, D'Antoni told another dinner guest: "Typical Skita. His charming innocence."
 And yet this teenager whose only home appliance during his first four months in the United States was a PlayStation for his video games had also eased into the roles, from the moment his mother and brother landed in Denver, of family provider, mother's helper and father figure. 
 He awakened many mornings at 7 to drive Giorgi to school, and made time on weekends to attend his brother's middle school basketball games. He helped his mother, who spoke little English and for months would not test the maze of suburban roads, with neighborhood shopping or the Russian market downtown.
 "I feel like young man but already old man, in the mind," Tskitishvili said. "I am so busy, sometimes so tired."
 In Europe, he had played no more than two games a week, with far less travel. "It's more time to relax in Europe," he said. "Here, it so much, all the time."
 His one Georgian friend in Denver -- a 28-year-old insurance contractor named Nick Chachkhiani -- said the most difficult adjustment for a Georgian in America was the fast pace of life. "Here, life is work, pay bills, make so much to afford anything," Chachkhiani said. "In Georgia, the economy's not so great but the culture is old, the relationships are good."
 Tskitishvili conceded as the season dragged on that he sometimes missed his home turf, his old friends. This was obvious one wet and otherwise dreary night when the Nuggets were in New York, as Tskitishvili stood on the sidewalk deep in the heart of immigrant Brooklyn, looking up with elation at the sign atop the storefront restaurant that said "Tbilisi." 
 Inside, there were wall-to-wall murals of hometown landmarks. Familiar aromas filled the air. A crooner belted out Georgian folk songs. A large table of diners, recognizing Tskitishvili, insisted he join them. Soon, a 300-pound bald giant named Kakha Gogoladze toasted him in grand Georgian style, long and fervent.
 "He is telling him that America is good for earning, to make the money," a young woman translated, as Gogoladze -- entirely believable when identifying himself as a former bodyguard of the Georgian President Eduard Shevardnadze -- clasped a massive hand around the misty-eyed player's neck. "He is telling him to succeed here with his strong Georgian heart."
 Through a numbing repetition of Nuggets defeats, it was Tskitishvili's head that the Nuggets most worried about, his many rookie mistakes and one embarrassing civilian misadventure.
 Tskitishvili was driving his Lincoln Navigator to the airport for a team flight to Los Angeles on Feb. 10 when a police officer pulled him over for having expired license plates. Upon running a check, the officer discovered that he had an outstanding violation for speeding, reckless driving and failing to yield to an emergency vehicle.
 Tskitishvili had, after all, learned to drive in Tbilisi. "If the police stop you in Georgia, you give them five bucks, everything's O.K.," Tskitishvili said. He wisely offered no bribe but was handcuffed and detained. The headlines circulated nationwide, and across the Atlantic, the underlying message suggesting that Tskitishvili's days of American innocence had ended. His American dream was in reverse: first came the rewards, then the harsher realities of N.B.A life.
 It did not help that the unquestioned Nuggets star of the 2002 draft, at least for this season, was Nene Hilario, the seventh overall pick from Brazil, with his samba-like footwork and inside power game. Playing behind other, less-heralded young players for most of the season, Tskitishvili has posted modest averages of 3.8 points and 15.8 minutes. A veteran Denver sports columnist, unimpressed, labeled him "The Big Bust."
 "How can someone say this about me and I am only 19?" Tskitishvili, who turned 20 yesterday, wondered. "Of course it has been harder in N.B.A. than I thought, but I am smart. I have talent. I trust future."
 KikiVandeweghe, the Nuggets' general manager, who made the final draft call on Tskitishvili, drew on his experience of having worked in Dallas as the rookie Nowitzki stumbled about. That was in 1998, before there was precedent, before places like Treviso, Italy, had become as much a stop on the talent-hunting trail as Tobacco Road. 
 Now two N.B.A. scouts could sit courtside in Denver and watch the Georgian with the tongue-twister last name drive the ball at the Chinese center, Yao, and coolly pass off to his Brazilian teammate, Hilario, for a slam dunk. And from that one Tskitishvili move in an otherwise undistinguished cameo role, one scout could tell the other: "That kid's some athlete. He's got a chance."

Learning the Ways Of the N.B.A.
 It takes a visionary basketball mind to imagine the finished product, a highly skilled 7-foot "small" forward, especially when Tskitishvili has this season been the diffident Georgian, drifting out by the 3-point line, symbolically positioned on the N.B.A. threshold, as if waiting for an invitation to step inside.
 His coaches have tried to accelerate the process of making an N.B.A. man out of him, with extra workouts and a training regimen that has packed a dozen pounds onto the 212-pound frame with which he began the season. But far from the distorted sense of entitlement plaguing many American players, Tskitishvili has never been the star of any team, arriving more as an N.B.A. fan than a player, reaching out and touching Jordan during a preseason game because, as he explained, "I just had to."
 "He's got to get over the star-struck phase and realize he's being paid to do a job,"' Jeff Bzdelik, the Denver coach, said.
 They had a private talk in January, after which Tskitishvili vowed, "I'm going to be more aggressive, play like American guys." It was a New Year's resolution the Nuggets would not hold him to, at least not until next fall, when another highly regarded draft pick -- possibly even LeBron James -- struts into camp. Then Tskitishvili will have to begin throwing gratitude and caution aside. He will have to start shedding the passivity that froze him one wintry afternoon, when, browsing with his brother in a Denver record store, he looked up to find a familiar and intimidating sight.
 Partially camouflaged but unmistakably cool in a furry hat and long dark coat was, of all people, Kevin Garnett.
 While Giorgi pressed his brother to say hello, Tskitishvili wavered, as if he were an indecisive rookie running down the shot clock. Soon Garnett was gone and the social opportunity was lost, at least until the next night, when a Nuggets official ushered Giorgi into the Minnesota locker room for a formal meeting with the big, bad Timberwolf.
 "So now you come over," Garnett woofed, before dropping his veneer, charming the fear out of the child. Later, Garnett set his sights on the older brother. After Minnesota rallied to win the game, he made a beeline cross-court and once again positioned himself in Tskitishvili's face.
 This time, he offered his hand. "Not regular way but this way," Tskitishvili said, thumb up, fingers bent -- the brotherly shake of choice for many African-Americans.
 There was delight in Tskitishvili's face as he recounted the moment he had been waiting for. Welcome to the N.B.A., Garnett seemed to be telling the stranger with the strange name. Welcome to the league of opulence in the land of opportunity, where you can live large and loud, for as long as you survive.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
SMEAL, FRANK P.

 BODY:
 SMEAL-Frank P., 84, died April 8, 2003 at his home, after a long illness. Mr. Smeal was born in Sykesville, PA. He lived in Jackson Heights, Queens, NY and New Shrewsbury before moving to Rumson, NJ in 1969. Mr. Smeal, a 1942 Phi Beta Kappa graduate in economics at Pennsylvania State University, went on to earn a Master's in Business Administration from Harvard University in 1947 and a law degree from New York University in 1952. A retired partner of Goldman Sachs, Inc., he spent his 38 year career on Wall Street as an expert in the municipal bond market. As Executive Vice President and Treasurer of Morgan Guaranty Trust Co., he was instrumental in counseling New York City through its 1975-76 fiscal crisis. He became a partner and member of the Senior Management Committee of Goldman Sachs in 1977 and retired in 1985. Frank was a past-president of the Municipal Bond Club of New York and former Chairman of the Government and Federal Agencies Securities Committee of Public Securities Association. He was treasurer of the United Chapters of Phi Beta Kappa and of the Phi Beta Kappa Foundation. Frank also served as Chairman of the Greater New York Councils of Boy Scouts of America, Chairman of the Penn State Development Councils, and Chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, NYC, NY. He was also a member of the Board of the Mount Nittany Society. Frank was named a Distinguished Alumnus of Penn State University in 1974 and an Alumni Fellow of the College of the Liberal Arts in 1986. 
Penn State's Smeal College of Business Administration was named in Honor of Frank and his wife, Mary Jean. They were also recognized by the National Center for Disability Services, Albertson, Long Island, NY where the Frank P. and Mary Jean Smeal Learning Center was established. Mr. Smeal was predeceased by his wife of 55 years, Mary Jean (nee Popp); his brother, Ted; a sister, Pauline Alexander, and his parents Samuel and Mary Smeal. He is survived by his daughter, Mary Margaret "Maggi" Smeal, MD; his son, Henry "Hank" F. Smeal; two grandchildren; sisters Dorothy Schwabenbauer and Olga Stormer; and three nieces, Janice King, Josephine Caylor, and Judy Olsen. Funeral service will be private and under the direction of the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ 07701 (1-888-747-0332). The family asks that, in lieu of flowers, memorial contributions be made to: Boy Scouts of America, New York Council Office, 350 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10018 (212-242-1100) or Inner-City Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Avenue, Suite 1400, New York, NY 10022-4134 (212-753-8583) or Smeal College of Business Administration, Penn State University, Development Office, 501 Business Administration, University Park, PA. 16802 (814-863-0345). Expressions of condolences may be sent to 12 Beekman Place, New York, New York 10022.

HEADLINE: Profit Up at Bank of America; Fleet's Results Meet Estimates 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A strong retail banking performance helped the Bank of America Corporation record a first-quarter profit above analysts' estimates, it reported yesterday. But profit at FleetBoston Financial fell though it was in line with projections. 
 Spurred by a 21 percent increase in consumer loans, Bank of America reported earnings of $2.42 billion, or $1.59 a share, up from $2.18 billion, or $1.38 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. This easily exceeded the $1.48 a share forecast by analysts. 
 Revenue rose to $8.89 billion, up 3.5 percent from $8.59 billion in the first quarter of 2002. 
The bank, based in Charlotte, N.C., benefited from low interest rates on mortgages, which have encouraged home purchases and refinancing. 
Kenneth D. Lewis, the chairman and chief executive, said that profit increased at all three of the bank's major businesses in the quarter. 
James H. Hance Jr., the chief financial officer, said in a conference call with investors that he expected quarterly profits to rise modestly through 2003. "Once the geopolitical uncertainty is resolved," Mr. Hance said, "we believe the economy will slowly regain its momentum. We have positioned ourselves to benefit from that occurrence." 
But David West, an analyst at Davenport & Company in Richmond, Va., said some investors had hoped for a more optimistic forecast from the bank. "Their remarks were pretty cautionary in an uncertain economy and subject to event risk," he said. "The bank did not say its outlook was bad, just that it would be lumpy." 
Bank of America said that credit losses eased, and its loan-loss provision ebbed to $833 million from $840 million a year earlier. 
The bank began treating employee stock options as expenses this quarter and reported a pretax impact of $26 million. 
FleetBoston cited the sluggish economy as one factor in a 23 percent decline in earnings. The company earned $567 million, or 54 cents a share, in the quarter compared with net income of $735 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. 
Income from continuing operations totaled $577 million, or 55 cents a share, compared with $736 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. That matched the consensus forecast of analysts.
Revenue for the period was $2.76 billion, down from $3.135 billion a year earlier. 
"All in all it was a decent quarter, with the highlight being the improvement in credit quality," said Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with RBC Capital Markets in Portland, Me. "The company most significantly showed a meaningful decline in nonperforming assets in the last quarter."

HEADLINE: Citigroup Reports Strong Results For First Quarter 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
Citigroup reported strong results for the first quarter yesterday as a recent acquisition in California bolstered results in its consumer banking business and low interest rates encouraged consumers and corporations to borrow more. The bank was also able to set aside less for problem corporate loans.
 Despite the encouraging news, which contributed to a rise in stock prices over all yesterday, net income at the bank declined 15 percent because the results a year earlier had included a one-time gain. Stock analysts also worried that the company's earnings growth could slow later this year, particularly if interest rates rise and the demand for mortgage refinancings wanes. 
 Citigroup reported net income of $4.1 billion, or 79 cents a share, down from $4.8 billion, or 93 cents a share, a year earlier. The quarter in 2002 included a one-time gain from the public offering of stock in the Travelers Property Casualty unit. Profits from continuing operations rose 18 percent in the latest period from a year earlier.
Stock analysts as well as the company's executives expressed relief that the company appeared to have finally put a long list of problems behind it.
"Earnings should be better in 2003 because the environment has gotten less bad," said Henry McVey, an analyst at Morgan Stanley.
Last year, Citigroup had to cope with losses in Argentina and the bankruptcies of large companies like Enron and WorldCom. The company was also distracted by a long investigation by regulators into conflicts of interest by research analysts. A settlement in principle was reached at the end of last year, and the final details are expected to be completed soon.
"Over the last 20 months, we have been bombarded by a whole host of issues," Sanford I. Weill, Citigroup's chief executive, said in a conference call with analysts yesterday. "We think this year is off to a good start."
With many problems behind it, Citigroup's shares rose $1.08 yesterday, to close at $38.43, on a day when the stock market overall posted strong results. Citigroup's shares have risen more than 9 percent this year.
But some analysts are worried that the the bank will have slower growth in some of its consumer businesses, which have been dominating its results for the last several quarters. "There is not much revenue growth in financial services now," Mr. McVey said. 
Expenses increased 5 percent, or $496 million, for the quarter, largely a result of costs associated with the acquisition of Golden State Bancorp last year. Other factors included higher severance payments, changes in accounting for options, and more conservative assumptions related to the company's pension plan.
The Golden State purchase bolstered Citigroup's consumer profits, which were up 26 percent. The strongest performance in this area came from retail banking, where earnings rose 54 percent. 
The bank's credit card business, the world's largest, reported a 27 percent profit increase, but expenses rose 9 percent as Citigroup spent more on marketing. Earnings fell 8 percent at the consumer finance business, partly a result of rising losses in Japan.
Analysts worry that Citigroup's consumer profits may have peaked, especially if a rise in interest rates slows mortgage financings later this year.
"The second half of the year on the consumer side is going to be tough," said Michael Corasaniti, head of research at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a brokerage firm specializing in financial services.
But Todd Thomson, Citigroup's chief financial officer, said the bank had anticipated that problem. 
"At some point rates are going to go up, and you'll see an end to the refinancing boom," he said in an interview yesterday. If fewer individuals refinance their mortgages, Citigroup will make more servicing those loans, he said. 
An improving economy could also encourage consumers to use their credit cards more. "This quarter was pretty weak for consumer spending," Mr. Thomson said. Outstanding credit card balances rose 8 percent, possibly indicating that the bank's marketing campaign was showing results.
Another piece of good news for the bank came from signs that problems had peaked among large corporate lenders. Citigroup set aside $506 million less for loan losses than it did a year earlier. In the first quarter of 2002, the bank took $644 million in write-downs and additional reserves related to Argentina. 
Mr. Thomson said the bank had already seen the worst of its problems among borrowers in the technology and telecommunications industries, and that encouraging steps were being taken by energy companies to refinance their debts.
Citigroup, which issues a credit card tied to American Airlines' frequent-flier program, is expected to lead a $1.5 billion financing for the company if American files for bankruptcy, according to executives briefed on that plan.
Profits rose 22 percent for Citigroup's corporate lending and investment banking business, aided by strong results from bond trading as well as new bond offerings. Revenues dropped for stock offerings and mergers and acquisitions advice.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: POLITICAL STRATEGY; 
Bush to Use Ratings in War To Sell Proposed Tax Cut

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14 

 BODY:
With hostilities in Iraq apparently winding down, the White House signaled today that it would put President Bush's wartime popularity to work immediately on behalf of his beleaguered tax cut plan, reflecting deep anxiety among Republicans about the political peril in the weak economy.
 Administration officials said Mr. Bush would re-engage in the fight over economic policy in earnest on Tuesday, when he gives his first speech focused on domestic matters since the start of the war, an address in the Rose Garden intended to build support for his proposal to cut taxes by $726 billion over the next decade. They said he would follow up on Wednesday by talking about jobs, as well as the war, in a visit to a Boeing fighter-jet factory in St. Louis. 
 The administration also disclosed plans to blanket the country with its argument for deep tax cuts on Tuesday, the federal tax-filing deadline, by sending cabinet secretaries and lower-ranking officials to appearances in 10 states. They said they would keep up the public relations offensive for the two weeks that Congress remains on its Easter break.
The point, they said is to re-establish Mr. Bush's authority on the economy after several weeks in which the centerpiece of his domestic agenda, his plan to cut income taxes and eliminate the taxation of stock dividends, was whittled down on Capitol Hill over his objections.
Administration officials and Republican strategists said the quick pivot from the war to the economy was also driven by the continued loss of jobs in recent months and by polls showing that less than half of Americans approve of the way the president is handling the economy, even as they give him high marks over all.
The president's quick return to the economy stands in marked contrast to the course chosen by his father, who played down the nation's economic problems after the 1991 gulf war and did not begin serious consideration of a legislative package to get the economy back on track until six months later.
"The state of the economy now moves to the front of the line among everyone in the White House," said Scott Reed, a Republican consultant. "The challenge is to harness the president's strong national poll numbers and leverage them with the razor-thin margins in Congress to get a growth initiative."
If the president cannot get a substantial tax cut out of Congress this year to give the economy a boost by Election Day 2004, Mr. Reed said, "next year's campaign could be very difficult, because at the end of the day people vote their pocketbook."
White House officials said Mr. Bush remained focused on Iraq, and was not ready to return to politics as usual. But if he is reluctant to shed his above-the-fray, commander-in-chief role for the give and take of domestic politics -- the ground on which Democrats are eager to confront him -- he has little choice, some Republicans said.
Not only does he face difficulty winning a tax cut of more than $350 billion from the Senate, but also Americans have made clear again where their priorities are; the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, conducted Friday through Sunday, found that 33 percent say the economy and jobs are the biggest problems facing the country, while 16 percent say it is foreign policy, war and terrorism.
Acutely conscious of how a weak economy helped doom his father's re-election in 1992 after the American victory over Iraq a year earlier, Mr. Bush has kept a close eye on the economy and the impact of the war on jobs and markets, even as he has focused on the military situation. 
While his war council meets downstairs in the White House situation room, his economic team has been gathering regularly several floors above, even calling in Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to bring the latest economic data.
So far, the war, by itself, does not appear to have had a major negative impact on the economy. But it has not helped, and many forecasters are predicting slower economic growth, fewer new jobs and bigger federal budget deficits than they were a few months ago, raising the prospect of the presidential campaign next year being fought against the backdrop of an economy too weak to bring down the unemployment rate. Unemployment is currently 5.8 percent, up from 4.1 percent when Mr. Bush took office.
Administration officials have been increasingly forthright in describing the economy in negative terms in recent weeks, in part to build pressure on Congress to give Mr. Bush as big a tax cut as possible. But some White House officials profess to be sanguine about the politics of the economy, saying there are many differences between Mr. Bush's position and his father's 11 years ago.
One senior White House official said the president had an economic plan and was fighting for it, while his father had not had much of an economic agenda -- and spent considerable time in 1991 fighting an extension of unemployment benefits, hardly a step that helped signal sympathy with rising unemployment.
The first President Bush raised taxes in 1990, deflating his party's conservative base, while the current president has proven to be a committed tax cutter, the official said. 
"The dream of 1992 is the best dream the Democrats have, so let them dream it," the official said.
The current White House has also proven not shy about using the wartime nature of this presidency to its political advantage. Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman, has linked the economy directly to the war, saying Mr. Bush wants to make sure the troops have jobs to come home to.
Mr. Bush has avoided addressing domestic politics on trips to military bases, but on Wednesday he will use a quasimilitary setting -- a factory that produces F/A-18 fighters -- as a backdrop for a speech in which he is expected to put pressure on the Senate to heed his call for a bigger tax cut while also drawing attention to the success of the Iraq campaign.
The White House has also signaled that it plans to start turning up the heat, though only slightly, on the two Republicans most responsible for the Senate limiting the tax cut to $350 billion, Senators Olympia J. Snowe of Maine and George V. Voinovich of Ohio. Samuel W. Bodman, the deputy commerce secretary, will speak about Mr. Bush's tax cut on Tuesday in Portland, Me., and William Lash, an assistant commerce secretary, is to speak in Ohio.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE NATIONAL MOOD; 
Americans See Clear Victory in Iraq, Poll Finds

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY and JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
Americans overwhelmingly consider the war in Iraq a success, and a majority say the victory will stand even if Saddam Hussein remains at large or if the United States fails to unearth chemical or nuclear weapons, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. 
 But a majority remains opposed to a policy of pre-emptive attack like the one President Bush invoked in invading Iraq, and see the White House, emboldened by its success, as now very or somewhat likely to turn the nation's military might on North Korea, Syria or Iran. 
 At home, the fall of Baghdad has fortified President Bush's political standing. The poll found that 73 percent of Americans approve of his job performance -- up from 59 percent the week before the war -- and that his approval rating among Democrats was 61 percent. The finding is reminiscent of the spike in popularity Mr. Bush's father enjoyed for the first few months after the Persian Gulf war of 1991. 
 The poll, taken over the weekend, found that for the first time since 2001, a majority of Americans, 62 percent, believe that the nation is winning the war on terrorism. And there has been a sharp drop in the number of people who fear terrorist reprisal attacks in the United States because of the invasion in Iraq. The poll found that 79 percent of respondents approve of Mr. Bush's handling of Iraq, the most support Mr. Bush has received on his Iraq policy.
 From a political perspective, the Times/CBS News poll pointed to a number of signs, on both the domestic and foreign policy front, of the difficulties the Democratic Party faces as it tries to win the White House and Congress next year.
 The nation has rallied around its president and is confident about the state of the country, a not-uncommon occurrence at a time of war. But beyond Mr. Bush's approval rating, a figure that typically gyrates with changing times, the number of Americans who believe the country is heading in the right direction has jumped nearly 20 percentage points since February, to 56 percent. That measure is closely watched by pollsters as a reliable indicator of the re-election prospects of an incumbent. 
 The Times/CBS News poll found evidence that the Democrats are not in as strong a position as they presumably would like on the issue that they believe could return them to power -- the economy. Americans are exactly divided, 42 percent to 42 percent, on which party would do a better job in managing the economy.
 And there has been a jump of 7 percentage points since January, to 54 percent, in the number of Americans who said they had confidence in Mr. Bush's ability to make the right decisions about the economy. That sentiment was voiced even as respondents expressed concern about the decline of the economy under Mr. Bush, and even though just 46 percent said they approved of his handling of the economy. 
 The improving view of Mr. Bush on the economy appears to be a dividend of the overall jump in Americans' perception of Mr. Bush during the war. Mr. Bush's political advisers have argued that any voter concerns about the economy would ultimately be outweighed by a perception that Mr. Bush is a strong and grounded president, created by his handling of the war in Iraq. 
Mr. Bush's father, at a similar point after the previous war in Iraq, also enjoyed relatively favorable marks for his management of the economy. That perception, along with his own approval rating -- which was even higher than the figure enjoyed today by his son -- swiftly deteriorated as images of the war were supplanted by concerns about a troubled economy.
 The Times/CBS News telephone poll was conducted Friday through Sunday, and involved 898 adults. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
 Several Democrats have suggested that Mr. Bush's standing would begin to erode if American troops were stranded in Iraq, or if the United States failed to find or kill Mr. Hussein, or find the weapons of mass destruction that Mr. Bush said was the rationale for his invasion.
 But nearly 60 percent of respondents said the United States would have won a clear victory in the war in Iraq even if no weapons of mass destruction were ever found, and 51 percent said they would consider it a victory even if Mr. Hussein is neither caught nor killed.
 "We have all of Iraq right now," said Carol Hayward, 59, a Democrat from New York City. "We don't need Saddam Hussein or his weapons. "We have all the oil fields under control and the cooperation of the people."
 And, there does not appear to be any great pressure on Mr. Bush to end the American presence in Iraq any time soon, a finding that could prove significant as the presidential race begins. Forty-six percent of respondents said they expected American troops to remain in Iraq for at least a year.
 The poll found that Americans believe that their nation would continue its aggressive effort to police the world. About 6 in 10 said they thought it was very likely or somewhat likely that the success of the war in Iraq would prompt the United States to intervene in Korea or Syria, while 3 in 10 said it was not very likely. Half foresaw a very or somewhat likely military intervention in Iran.
Ina Urness, 71, of Higginsville, Mo., said in a follow-up interview that she approved of the administration's moving pre-emptively against nations that posed a threat to the United States. "We ought to nip it right in the bud, because it's better them than us," she said. "Get over there and get them before they can have a chance to turn those missiles loose on us over here."
Adam Coleman, 25, a Democrat from Alexandria, Va., also said he expected the United States to intervene in one of those countries, though he said he was not happy at the prospect. "This current administration doesn't particularly follow through on diplomatic policies, therefore I think they're rather quick to rush to military action, particularly against nations that they really do have a strong hold over," he said. "We kind of bully them."
Still, a majority of Americans said future interventions should be done as part of an international coalition. And while most Americans said that the United States had the responsibility to ensure that a new government is put in place in Iraq -- and to police the country to guard against looting -- they said the rebuilding effort should be led by an international coalition. Two-thirds of respondents said the United Nations, rather than the United States, should have lead responsibility in rebuilding Iraq.
And the nation has yet to embrace the tactical doctrine of pre-emption Mr. Bush advanced to justify the war in Iraq and, potentially, an invasion of Syria, North Korea or Iran. For example, 51 percent said the United States should not invade another nation unless it was attacked first. And 48 percent said it was wrong for the United States to try to change a dictatorship to a democracy.
The White House yesterday stepped up its criticism of Syria, accusing it of harboring Iraqi fugitives. But the Times/CBS News poll found that among Americans who said they believed another country posed a serious threat to the United States, North Korea was of far more concern than Syria: 39 percent of those respondents named North Korea, compared to just 5 percent who cited Syria. One percent named Iran.
That could change soon. The poll found that 81 percent of respondents said that Iraq probably had weapons of mass destruction, and of those in that group, 27 percent said they believed the weapons had been spirited off to another country. The White House yesterday suggested that that country was Syria.
By most measures, Americans feel triumphant about the way the war has gone. Even as Americans view further military action by the United States in the Mideast as likely, they say they believe the ousting of Hussein would lead to more stability in Iraq and throughout the region. 
And if there were any concerns about how the White House was waging this war, they fell with Baghdad. For example, in the space of two weeks, there has been a turnaround in the number of Americans who believe the United States correctly assessed the resistance it would encounter from the Iraqis. Fifty-nine percent now say the United States was accurate in its prewar assessment, compared to 31 percent who said it underestimated the fight the Iraqis would put up. And 44 percent said there were fewer casualties than they had expected.

How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Friday through Sunday with 898 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country. Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to listed and unlisted numbers alike. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variation in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the margin of sampling error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variation in the wording and order of questions, for example, may lead to somewhat different results. Complete results are online at nytimes.com/washington.

HEADLINE: The Road to Damascus 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is right to be alarmed and angry about Syria. There is reason to believe that both military equipment and potential suicide bombers have been sent from Syria for use in Iraq against American troops. Now, American officials are convinced that Syria is permitting Saddam Hussein's top lieutenants to escape across its border. As the United States begins to exercise its new role as godparent of a new, freer government in Iraq, it will have to figure out how to handle many hostile neighbors, starting with Syria. 
 Syria, like Mr. Hussein's Iraq, is a totalitarian state run by a religious minority that has not shied away from relying on repression to maintain power. The former president, Hafez al-Assad, was often a shrewd operator, however, who joined the American-led coalition in the first war against Iraq in 1991 and later considered a peace deal with Israel while financing and arming anti-Israel groups in Lebanon. 
 It is a tribute to Hafez al-Assad's reasonableness as a diplomat and irresponsibility as a leader that Syria is the only country called a sponsor of terrorism by the State Department that has diplomatic relations with the United States.
Mr. Assad's son, Bashar, who assumed power after his father's death in 2000, was at first viewed as a potentially more progressive and thoughtful leader, but he has failed to meet those expectations. He did offer cooperation against Al Qaeda after Sept. 11, but he has also raised anti-American and anti-Israel feeling to new heights while doing nothing to improve Syria's pathetic economy or oppressive political regime.
One of the biggest concerns facing American troops in Iraq is that a combination of suicide bombings and internecine warfare could paralyze efforts to stabilize the country. Syria helped engineer just such a nightmare for Israel in Lebanon in the 1980's by financing and arming Shiite Muslim groups. In addition, Syria has long given refuge to anti-Israel terror groups, like the Palestinian Islamic Jihad. It may also have an active chemical weapons program.
War against Syria, however, makes no sense. The United States has its hands full in Iraq. More important, Washington will only live up to the worst expectations of the Arab world if it now adopts a belligerent military approach to every nation in the region that it dislikes. It may be possible, however, to use the threat of diplomatic or economic sanctions to encourage Damascus to reconsider its hostile policies in the wake of the fall of Mr. Hussein. 
But President Assad, like his father, has shown little interest in pulling his people out of the misery in which they exist, and Syria may turn out to be one of the most complex problems facing the Bush administration as it rebuilds Iraq.

HEADLINE: The Mayor's Mistake on Workfare 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael Bloomberg was widely praised last year when he said that the city was moving away from a welfare policy whose main goal was bouncing people from the rolls by any means necessary. Instead, the mayor promised an approach that would embrace training and education programs to move people from dependency into real, lasting jobs. After more than a year, his administration's actions have yet to match its words. 
 Mr. Bloomberg came down on the wrong side when he vetoed a City Council bill that would broaden educational opportunity for welfare recipients. His opposition is confusing given the positions he supported in a welfare speech given not long after he took office. 
 Nearly 60 percent of New York City's welfare recipients do not have even high school diplomas and will remain locked out of the economy without education.
The new law, passed by the City Council over Mr. Bloomberg's veto, seeks to expand training opportunities and offers aid to the small, but significant, number of welfare recipients who have the drive and the ability to better themselves by going to college, usually to get two-year degrees.
Current federal and state rules allow localities to let welfare recipients satisfy work requirements by counting class time, work-study jobs and internships. These programs are working well, not just in liberal parts of the state, but in some of New York's most conservative upstate counties. The law passed by the council takes a similar approach. The mayor's charge that the council does not require enough work -- and that some welfare recipients will get by without doing any -- relates to an exceedingly rare kind of case, like that of a single mother who carried a heavy courseload and got credit for study time as well.
Mr. Bloomberg's contention that the city may lose federal money for failing to comply with the welfare laws also seems unfounded. The new law specifically states that welfare recipients can participate only in education and training programs to the maximum extent permitted in state law, a provision that is in keeping with federal regulations.
The administration is caught between those who favor the educational approach and those who fear that it would allow critics to label this administration as "soft" on welfare. So far, those who wish to cling to the status quo appear to be winning.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Unions at American Airlines To Conclude Voting Today
The three major unions at American Airlines said that they would conclude voting on $1.8 billion in labor concessions by this morning and try to get results to the company before 11 a.m.
 That is the deadline American has set for a vote tally. If the votes are not counted by then, or if any group rejects concessions, the company will file for bankruptcy protection "very soon," said Bruce Hicks, a company spokesman. Page C2. 

Bush to Campaign for Tax Cut Plan
With hostilities in Iraq winding down, the White House signaled that it would put President Bush's popularity to work immediately on behalf of his beleaguered tax cut plan, reflecting deep anxiety among Republicans about the political peril in the weak economy. B10.

Resignation May Hurt Merger Talks
Stephen Fraidin, a partner at the New York law firm Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, has defected to Kirkland & Ellis. The departure is said to complicate merger negotiations between Fried, Frank and London-based Ashurst Morris Crisp. C3.

Hotels Doing Well, Despite Slump
The same forces that are hurting the airline industry are taking a toll on the hotel business. Even so, the industry is expected to earn $15 billion this year, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers. Business Travel. C6.

Kmart Plans to Exit Bankruptcy
Kmart said the majority of its creditors had approved its plan to emerge from bankruptcy, and if the court approves the plan, it could emerge from bankruptcy in 10 days. C2.

Capellas Steering Leaner WorldCom
WorldCom filed a reorganization plan that envisions it emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection "later this year as a leaner, stronger competitor," chief executive, Michael D. Capellas, left, said. WorldCom also plans to change its name to MCI, the name of the residential long-distance company it purchased in 1998. C4.

Plan Uses Software to Fight Piracy
A computer security research group has proposed a technical solution aimed at forging a middle ground in the battle by Hollywood and Silicon Valley over the best way to protect digital content from consumer piracy. C5.

Stock Gauges Up More Than 1.8%
Investors sent stocks soaring. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 147.69 points, or 1.8 percent, to 8,351.10. The Nasdaq composite index rose 26.10 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,384.95, and the Standard & Poor's 500 advanced 16.93 points, or 2 percent, to 885.23. C8.

Profit Climbs 60% at Fannie Mae
Fannie Mae, the nation's largest mortgage financier, said that its earnings surged 60 percent as Americans took advantage of low interest rates and signed up for more home loans in a busy housing market. C5.

Inventories Rose 0.6% in February
Business inventories rose 0.6 percent, to $1.6 trillion, in February as snowstorms led to a drop in retail sales, the Commerce Department reported. But total business sales fell 1 percent, to $836.4 billion. C8.

E-Mail Is a Big Factor in Recovery
Airlines, hotels and other travel suppliers have discovered that frequent travelers, who tend to be people who are also high users of the Internet, want to receive e-mail messages from these companies, according to Henry H. Harteveldt. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. C7.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR/AN OVERVIEW: APRIL 14, 2003; 
End of 'Major' Combat, Fall of Tikrit, Anxiety Over Syria

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
The northern city of Tikrit fell without a battle and American military commanders declared that major fighting in Iraq had come to an end. American forces started to pull out of Iraq and those that remained began a transformation from combat to postwar reconstruction. The work of keeping the peace and forming a new government proceeded slowly, but the victory in Iraq pushed up President Bush's approval ratings at home. 
 MAJOR COMBAT OVER -- The Pentagon said that major combat operations in Iraq were over and it began sending some some forces home. Some combat troops are to be replaced by military police officers and civil affairs soldiers. 
 Air Force officials said the four B-2 bombers that were in the region had already flown home, as had half a dozen F-117 stealth fighters and other warplanes. Navy officials said two aircraft carriers, the Kitty Hawk and the Constellation, had received orders to sail for their home ports. A third aircraft carrier, the Abraham Lincoln, is already on the way home and has been replaced by the Nimitz.
Although they will have to root out remnants of Iraqi forces, troops stationed in Iraq will increasingly assume peacekeeping duties. Other nations may be willing to help. The Netherlands said it might send 600 Dutch Marines to stabilize Iraq. 
TIKRIT OVERRUN -- It was expected to be a fight to the bitter end, but when thousands of marines finally stormed Saddam Hussein's ancestral home, Tikrit, they found empty streets and vacant buildings. Marines entered a lavish presidential compound, one of the grandest of the many palaces that Mr. Hussein had built for himself throughout Iraq. 
The opulence of Mr. Hussein's Xanadu stunned Iraqis and Americans alike. Two miles of lush riverfront property with about 90 buildings, all once off limits to the ordinary Iraqis who came by to gape at the extravagance, or to carry off everything that was not cemented down. 
Outside the palace, the marines tightened their control of the city, still wondering what had happened to the 2,500 troops loyal to the government that they had expected to encounter. There were a few firefights overnight, but then nothing. "We're not sure where they all went," said Maj. Chris Snyder of the Marines. 
TERRORISTS AND SYRIA -- American intelligence officials said members of Hezbollah, a terrorist group, entered Iraq from Syria in recent days and could threaten a new government backed by the United States. Officials also continued to accuse Syria of taking in members of the former Iraqi government. 
Among the Iraqis who American intelligence officials believe have taken refuge in Syria in recent months are scientists trying to avoid questioning by United Nations weapons inspectors. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell warned Syria it could face economic or diplomatic sanctions if it did not stop providing "safe haven" to former Iraqi leaders. 
MILITARY AND POLITICAL VICTORY -- A New York Times/CBS News poll found that Americans overwhelmingly view the war in Iraq as a success, and that has helped push up President Bush's approval rating to 73 percent, compared with 59 percent the week before the war started. 
Despite that strong level of support, a majority of Americans remain opposed to a policy of pre-emptive attacks like the one invoked in the invasion of Iraq. And a majority believes that the White House, emboldened by the victory in Iraq, is now more likely to consider attacking North Korea, Syria or Iran. 
The poll, taken over the weekend, also found that for the first time a majority of Americans believes that the nation is winning the war on terrorism.
POLICING BAGHDAD -- To help solidify the return to order in Baghdad, 20 Iraqi police officers patrolled neighborhoods in East Baghdad jointly with marines. They reportedly arrested several looters. It was but a small step toward normality in the sprawling city, and mayhem persisted in many areas. In the Iraqi Health Ministry, vandals ripped out and hauled away the large refrigeration units that held Iraq's entire supply of vaccines against polio, German measles and other childhood diseases. 
With criticism mounting over the looting of the National Museum of Iraq in Baghdad, Mr. Powell said the United States would help recover the priceless antiquities and assist in rebuilding the museum. 
REMAKING IRAQI POLITICS -- Lt. Gen. Jay Garner, picked by the Bush administration to run postwar Iraq, flew to Nasiriya for meetings with more than 70 Iraqis and exiles who were invited by American officials to help establish a representative government. 
One of the most prominent exiles, Ahmad Chalabi, leader of the Iraqi National Congress, will not attend the meeting but will send a representative. American military commanders have not given General Garner the go-ahead to set up his operation in Baghdad because the city is too dangerous. ANTHONY DePALMA

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE POSTWAR TASK; 
U.S. OVERSEER SET TO REMAKE IRAQ

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: KUWAIT, April 14 

 BODY:
The retired American general who will run post-war Iraq for the Bush administration flew to Iraq today on a mission to remake the country's politics, a process he predicted would be messy and contentious.
 But Lt. Gen. Jay Garner insisted that American-style democracy could sprout on the shards of President Saddam Hussein's government. "I don't think they had a love-in when they had Philadelphia" in 1787, he said in an interview here before his departure. "Anytime you start the process it's fraught with dialogue, tensions, coercion, and should be." Iraq, he suggested, could be the richest country in the Middle East within a few years. 
 The general will preside over a meeting of Iraqis and Iraqi exiles in Nasiriya on Tuesday, the first of many meetings that the Pentagon says are intended to form the basis of a representative government for Iraq. 
The invitations to about 70 to 80 people, including prominent exiles like Ahmad Chalabi and Iraqis unknown to the outside world, were issued in the name of the war commander, Gen. Tommy R. Franks, to whom General Garner reports.
For General Garner, who will spend his 65th birthday in Nasiriya, greeting and cajoling Iraqis he has never met before, the politics of Iraq is just one of the major tasks ahead.
General Garner, appointed by President Bush in January to oversee aid, reconstruction and civil government in Iraq, will be the most visible American face on what many in the Middle East and Europe view as a singularly American enterprise which, in their opinion, should be more international in scope and sensibility. Many European governments believe that the United Nations should play a more central role.
General Garner will oversee how $2.4 billion authorized by Congress last week will be spent in Iraq. He will pass judgment on problems like setting up television stations and selecting a police force for a population of 24 million in 17 provinces. His voice will be important when Washington decides how to revive the Iraqi oil industry and how quickly to seek to lift United Nations sanctions. One of his deputies, Lewis Lucke, a former official of the United States Agency for International Development, is in charge of the bidding process for reconstruction contracts. 
The major irritation among the general's staff today seemed to be that the Central Command, citing security concerns, was keeping him in Kuwait instead of letting him go to Baghdad. After presiding over the conference on Tuesday, the general will return to Kuwait. 
Once he gets to Baghdad, the general acknowledged, "there will be a lot of problems" -- law enforcement, getting services working, preventing revenge killings, particularly "if severe Baathists try to return to communities." 
The general appeared confident that, with help from talented Iraqis, he would succeed.
"Arabs are very proud people," he said. "Proud as we are." In particular, the Iraqis are "pretty sophisticated" and have a "lot of wealth, it's just not been shared among them."
"There's an intelligentsia," he added. "The Arabs are great traders, they're organized." He believes, he said, that the Iraqis are "motivated, even though they've lived under a mushroom for 25 years." 
He is prepared for resentment at the American presence. "The way you get over that is by your actions," he said, "by showing that things will get better, that we will give it back to them as rapidly as we can."
"Within 90 to 120 days" he would like to "transition elements back to the Iraqis," he said. "In my heart of hearts, I think it will go fairly rapidly."
The role of the United Nations has not figured much in the general's planning for Iraq, according to some of the several hundred retired generals and officers, diplomats and aid experts who are with him here. 
But today, General Garner said he was in favor of a Security Council resolution that would allow the revenues from Iraq's rejuvenated oil production to be used for "reconstruction of the country and the betterment of the citizens of Iraq." 
Those revenues, he said, should be "managed by a neutral agency, like the World Bank" where it could be properly audited and "transparent." 
No decision has been made on who should run the oil industry and how it should be structured, officials in Washington said.
But there is little question, the general said, that oil will be the basis of new wealth in Iraq. "In the next few years they will be able to double, triple their production of oil," he said. "They may become the richest country in the Middle East."
The general said he believed that Iraq needed a new currency, and advisers from the Treasury Department who have come to Kuwait with him are considering the question. "One of the things I'd like to do is ask them, What do you want as a currency and whose picture do you want on it?" he said. The dinars now in circulation, with Mr. Hussein's image on them, were easily counterfeited, he said, noting "We don't know where the plates are." 
Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld chose General Garner for his position. The two men know each other well from the late 1990's when the general served on a missile defense commission headed by Mr. Rumsfeld. They now talk every other night by video teleconference, and sometimes Mr. Rumsfeld calls directly, the general said. 
By getting out of Iraq fast, the general said, the United States can avoid repeating past mistakes. "We're notorious for telling people what to do," he said. An example? "Start with Vietnam and the strategic hamlet concept." 
General Garner served two tours in Vietnam, first in 1967-68 as an infantry adviser in the central highlands, and as a district senior adviser in 1971-72 in the strategic hamlet program, which involved relocating Vietnamese in remote villages into areas heavily defended by American forces, he said. Over all, he said, the war in Vietnam was a failure because the United States had the "wrong military objective."
"It took too long," he said. "We should have taken the war north instead of waiting in the south. Just like here. If President Bush had been president, we would have won."
The general retired from the military in 1997 after serving from 1994 to 1996 as commander of the Army Space and Strategic Defense Command. He joined SYColeman, a missile systems contractor that gives technical advice on a variety of systems, including the Patriot, which was deployed in Iraq. It was bought by L-3 Communications last year. He enjoyed his business career, he said, because "most of the guys are former military, and you make a lot of money." 
After the 1991 Persian Gulf war, the general ran a mission that helped the Kurds and resulted in the creation of the semiautonomous Kurdish enclave in northern Iraq. At that time, General Garner worked closely with an experienced civilian expert in delivering aid, Fred Cuny, who was later killed in Chechnya. The effort was deemed by many in Washington to be a success. 
General Garner appeared unperturbed at the prospect of running all of Iraq, under much more intense scrutiny. He is prepared, he said, for bickering on Tuesday among Iraqi exile groups and local Iraqis. Mr. Chalabi, the head of the Iraqi National Congress who was flown to Nasariya almost two weeks ago by the Special Forces, will not attend, but has said he would send an adviser.
The general seemed to relish the prospect. The Tuesday meeting represents, he said, the first time in perhaps "several hundred years" that Iraq has had such an "open season" for dialogue.
