HEADLINE: Bloomberg Names 5 New Members to Rent Guidelines Board 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appointed five new members to the city's Rent Guidelines Board yesterday, giving the board the quorum necessary to hold its first meeting of the year and barely avoid canceling a second meeting in a row.
 While the appointments got only mixed marks from some housing groups, they nonetheless eased some anxiety surrounding the board, which determines how much rents should rise or fall for the million or so apartments in New York City that are subject to rent regulation. And this year, many housing groups anticipate political pyrotechnics over what could be the biggest rent increase in many years because of higher costs for property taxes, fuel and insurance. 
 The board's first scheduled meeting, on March 25, was canceled because five of the nine previous members had either resigned or were not reappointed by Mr. Bloomberg. Even yesterday, a sense of haste still reverberated, because the mayor's office issued a news release announcing the appointments shortly before the meeting started.
"I didn't know who was on the board until I saw the name tags for them this morning," said Adriene L. Holder, one of the tenant representatives on the board and a holdover from last year.
The board, whose members are all chosen by the mayor, has a chairman, two tenant advocates, two landlord advocates and four members of the public who are supposed to represent the middle ground. Each member is supposed to have experience in housing, economics or finance. No one is allowed toown rent-regulated apartment buildings.
The new landlord representative is Steven J. Schleider, a senior vice president at KTR Newmark Real Estate Services. The four public members are Betty Phillips Adams, a consultant for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Organizations; Gale D. Kaufman, managing director at Duvernay & Brooks, a real estate finance and development company; Elizabeth Lusskin, a lawyer and former deputy commissioner for operations with the city's Department of Business Services; and Martin Zelnik, an architect and retired professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology.
Asked about the new board, Jack Freund, executive vice president of the Rent Stabilization Association, which represents rental owners, said that while "it's nice to have a board," the new members were "all mysteries to me."
And Michael McKee, associate director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, expressed disappointment that all the public members except Ms. Adams had backgrounds in the real estate business.
Beyond the introductions of the new board members yesterday, the board reviewed the first two of several research studies that it uses to decide how much to adjust rents. One of the reports, the Income and Expense Study, found that in 2001, owners of rent-stabilized apartment buildings reported a 5.9 percent increase in their operating income.
To tenant groups, that number strengthened the argument that landlords had been among the few groups to fare well during the economic downturn. But to landlord groups, the number was misleading because it did not incorporate the city's new 18.5 percent property tax or other rising costs.
Last year, the board raised rents by 2 percent for a one-year lease and 4 percent for a two-year lease. A preliminary vote is scheduled for May 5; the final vote is on June 19.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE STRONGHOLD; 
Tale of Hussein's Last Sighting Takes On a Life of Its Own

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 15 

 BODY:
He was here, and then, like a shadow, he was gone. 
 At the Adhamiya Mosque in northern Baghdad, people have made a legend of the half hour last Wednesday, around the time of the noon prayers, when they say Saddam Hussein appeared in public, in the square outside the mosque, and offered what may prove to have been his last promise, or his last deceit, to the people of Iraq. 
 "I am fighting alongside you in the same trenches," he told a cheering crowd in the square outside the mosque. 
And then, people who were in the square at the time said today, the Iraqi leader and a small group of loyalists climbed back into their cars and drove off. Within 12 hours, American aircraft bombed the neighborhood, destroying part of a cemetery behind the mosque. American troops followed up with an assault on the mosque in which the minaret took a direct hit from a tank round and a shoulder-fired rocket was used to blast open the door to the catafalque containing the body of Abu Hanifa, an eighth-century Muslim saint, apparently in the belief that Mr. Hussein might be hiding somewhere in the darkness within. 
But he was not. Where he went is almost certainly the most important unresolved issue of the American war in Iraq, now that even Mr. Hussein's hometown, Tikrit, is under American military control. 
Saying the evidence of their own eyes belied the notion, common in American intelligence circles, that he was killed in the American airstrike that opened the war on March 20 or another one on April 7, some Iraqis believe the 65-year-old Mr. Hussein may still be somewhere in Baghdad, perhaps in Adhamiya, which has been a stronghold of support for him and the ruling Baath Party for decades. 
Men who joined the Baath Party when it was an underground organization in Iraq in the 1950's and early 1960's say that many of its earliest cells were founded in Adhamiya, and that crucial party meetings were held there in secret. The social and economic makeup of the district -- working class and overwhelmingly Sunni Muslim, like Mr. Hussein and most other top Baath leaders -- made it a bedrock of the party's support, these people say. 
Even today, crowds gathered in the streets of Adhamiya to praise Mr. Hussein, to deny that he ever was a murderous dictator and to pledge, proudly and defiantly, that if given the chance they would do all they could to hide him from American forces. 
"Yes, we will defend him to the last drop of our blood, we will all be fedayeen in the service of our leader," said a man who gave his name as Muhammad Abdel Karim, though hours of discussion in Adhamiya indicated that few men were eager to give their real names or any other information that could help the Americans track them down. 
As to where Mr. Hussein might be, the men, and in several cases their wives, said they did not know but if they did they would not be likely to tell an American reporter. 
"Saddam Hussein was our country's leader, he was a statesman, and he was in authority over us," Maythem Shihab, the 55-year-old custodian of the mosque, said. "We don't know his whereabouts now, but even if we did, we would not betray him. What right do the Americans have to invade our country and overthrow our legitimate leader?" 
In the streets and alleyways of Adhamiya today, nobody could remember any previous occasion, before his sudden appearance outside the mosque last week, when Mr. Hussein had visited the district, other than to disappear inside the high walls of one his many palaces, built in the district about 15 years ago. 
But other things about the shrinking geography of Mr. Hussein's Baghdad make the reports that he appeared here more credible. By Wednesday, American troops had seized control of much of central and southern Baghdad, east and west of the Tigris. American success in seizing the main presidential compound around the Republican Palace had forced many diehard paramilitary fighters north up both banks of the river, into the Atifiya district on the west and Adhamiya on the east. 
Reporters who returned to the mosque today found Iraqis initially reluctant to say anything about the events of last week. Instead, local leaders wanted to focus attention on the Adhamiya cemetery, behind the mosque. There, they showed the visitors a deep crater where they said an American bomb had fallen on Wednesday night and a cluster of graves where they said 18 people killed in the fighting, some civilians and some fedayeen irregulars, had been buried. 
Some of the graves were marked with bottles stuck into the freshly turned earth, with pieces of paper stuck into the necks identifying those buried as martyrs for Islam. 
Sitting on a wall at the edge of a cemetery in the hot spring sunshine, the reporters opened a discussion on Mr. Hussein and his years of rule. Within minutes, the eagerness to defend the toppled Iraqi leader appeared to get the better of the Iraqis' unwillingness to speak about what they had seen on Wednesday. Suddenly, one man after another began giving his account of the excitement in the square when, they said, Mr. Hussein suddenly appeared. 
The accounts, offered by a dozen men in the next three hours, varied little in their details. 
All the men said that Mr. Hussein and his party arrived in three cars, and that the Iraqi leader -- unmistakably the real McCoy, not one of the doubles he is known to employ -- was accompanied by his second son, Qusay, and by his ubiquitous bodyguard, Abid Hamid Mahmoud. 
All the accounts spoke of Mr. Hussein appearing in his field marshal's uniform, and climbing on the hood of one of the cars and making a speech. "I salute the Iraqi people," one man recalled him as having said, "and I ask them to defend themselves, their homes, their wives, their children, and their holy shrines." The man who gave this account said that he noticed that Mr. Hussein had tears running down his cheeks. 
"And then he said, 'I am fighting alongside you in the same trenches,' " the man said.
But what about all the killing by Mr. Hussein's secret police? What about the torture and executions? A man in a flowing gray dishdasha gown who refused to give his name, smiled indulgently. 
"We are only ordinary citizens, we know nothing about this," he said. Catching a look of incredulity from his questioner, he added: "In any case, there are political mistakes made everywhere. Saddam Hussein's were very small."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Local Iraqis loyal to Saddam Hussein gathered in a cemetery in the Adhamiya district of Baghdad. (Alan Chin for The New York Times)(pg. B4)

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE ASIAN FRONT; 
North Koreans And U.S. Plan Talks in Beijing

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15 

 BODY:
President Bush has approved a plan for the United States to begin negotiations with North Korea in Beijing next week, the first talks between the countries since the government of Kim Jong Il threw out international inspectors and restarted its main nuclear weapons plant, United States and Asian officials said today.
 White House officials refused to comment on the negotiations. But officials in several countries said China has promised the United States that it will act as a full participant in the talks rather than just convening them. The Chinese had hoped to conduct the initial meetings in secret, officials said. 
 The agreement to enter the negotiations with both China and the United States marks a major concession for North Korea and an apparent victory for President Bush. Mr. Bush's strategy of not engaging in one-on-one talks with North Korea had been widely criticized by Asian allies and by many Korea experts. 
North Korea, in turn, had insisted on talking only with Washington, a reflection, experts said, of its obsession with being treated as an equal. 
Mr. Bush refused, insisting that the North Korean nuclear program was a major problem for all of northeast Asia. He argued that if the United States negotiated alone, North Korea would try to split Washington from its Asian allies, who would pressure the United States to strike a deal on North Korea's terms.
But by keeping the Japanese, the South Koreans and the Russians out of the room next week, the North can make the argument that only one other nation -- one that has served as the North's economic lifeline -- is involved.
"This is what the traffic would bear," a senior American official familiar with the secret negotiations with the North said tonight. 
The official described the participation of the Chinese as a breakthrough. "What's new here is that there is an active, bold participatory role for the Chinese," the official said. China's agreement to take on such a role began to take shape in the last days of former President Jiang Zemin's government. His successor, Hu Jintao, has continued Mr. Jiang's approach after becoming president last month. 
China briefly cut off North Korea's oil last month, after what the Chinese called a technical problem. But the move was interpreted by American officials as a warning to the North about the price of intransigence.
The senior American official said tonight that the United States "reserved the right" to bring in other nations as the talks progressed. Japanese and South Korean officials, while initially unhappy at being excluded, said tonight they were promised by the administration that they would be updated daily on the talks and would help forge negotiating positions.
The negotiating position that the United States and its allies take will be an early test of America's strained relations with South Korea, whose new president, Roh Moo Hyun, has vowed to accelerate a policy of trade and engagement with the North. Mr. Roh visits the United States for the first time next month. 
The American envoy conducting the talks next week will be James A. Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for Asia. Mr. Kelly visited the North's capital, Pyongyang, last October and told North Korea that United States intelligence agencies had caught the country building a clandestine uranium-production facility. 
To Mr. Kelly's surprise, the North Koreans said they broke out of their nuclear "freeze" because the United States had threatened the country when Mr. Bush cited North Korea as part of the "axis of evil." But the North's effort to secretly import uranium-enriching technology, intelligence officials say, began when Mr. Bush was governor of Texas.
In the six months since the United States and North Korea last met, the North Koreans ejected inspectors, withdrew from the nuclear nonproliferation treaty and restarted the plutonium reprocessing facility that was frozen under a 1994 agreement with the United States.
They also tried to force down an American intelligence-gathering plane over international waters, though the senior official said tonight that "they have made it clear we won't see that again" while negotiations are under way.
As described by officials from the United States, Japan and South Korea today, the outlines of the agreement for next week's talks were struck before the war in Iraq started. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell traveled on Feb. 24 to Beijing, where the Chinese tried to persuade him to engage in one-on-one talks with North Korea. At a second meeting at the United Nations, on March 7, "we persuaded the Chinese" that Mr. Bush would never agree to those conditions, the American official said.
The next day, a very senior Chinese official -- it is unclear who -- told North Korea's leaders that they had no choice but to accede to Mr. Bush's demands, several officials said.
American officials said that in their talks with the Chinese, they did not explicitly say that any deal would be impossible if the North Koreans began producing weapons. "But we said that obviously, as we go through this, the entire political environment would be totally contaminated if missiles started flying or reprocessing started," the senior official said.
American officials have gone to some lengths to keep the approaching negotiations from becoming public: both Mr. Powell and Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, said in separate comments today that the United States was continuing to talk to its allies. 
There is no assurance that the talks themselves will succeed at anything other than slowing the North's progress. In the late 1990's it took part in multilateral talks, but withdrew.. 
Yet some Bush administration officials suspect that the North will not trade away its entire nuclear program, for fear that it would lose all its leverage. "They may be just testing us out with these talks," another official said. "If they don't get as much as they want, perhaps they think they can go ahead with their programs. But the environment is changing."

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: WHITE HOUSE; 
BUSH SAYS REGIME IN IRAQ IS NO MORE; SYRIA IS PENALIZED

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15 

 BODY:
President Bush declared today that "the regime of Saddam Hussein is no more," and his administration used America's rapid success in overthrowing the Iraqi leader to put new pressure on Iran and Syria, neighbors of the newly occupied nation.
 At the Pentagon, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said the United States was moving to cut off an important oil pipeline running from Iraq into Syria, the first major economic penalty against Syria. 
 Mr. Rumsfeld's statements, as well as remarks by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, were part of a declared strategy to consolidate the allied victory in Iraq by beginning to reshape the Middle East, while Mr. Bush said he planned to make the new Iraq a model for democracy in the Middle East. 
Since the fall of Mr. Hussein, Mr. Bush's aides have begun talking publicly about the "demonstration effect" of the victory in Iraq.
The swiftness of the victory, one senior administration official said in an interview, "opens all sorts of new opportunities for us." But the official said that "the trick in coming days" would be to press America's advantage "without sounding threatening."
"Our victory in Iraq is certain, but it is not complete," Mr. Bush said today. He said a final victory would not be declared until Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the senior commander in the war theater, had determined that all of Washington's military objectives had been met -- a process that could take months.
But already today the Pentagon made arrangements to halt the planned deployment to Iraq of about 24,000 troops of the First Cavalry Division based at Fort Hood, Tex. -- except for 700 military police and civil affairs specialists, officials said.
Mr. Rumsfeld's announcement about the oil pipeline, which is capable of carrying 200,000 barrels a day, is the clearest signal the administration has sent to President Bashar al-Assad that the United States is willing to use its new position on Syria's border to press the country, which the White House declared Monday as a "rogue state." The administration has accused Syria of harboring Iraqi fugitives and of developing chemical weapons.
The pipeline has been a huge source of revenue for the Syrian government, which has paid Iraq with goods, in two-way trade conducted in violation of United Nations economic sanctions against Iraq.
At the same time, Mr. Powell said the United States had no broader military ambitions in the Middle East. He said there was "no war plan right now" for Syria and Iran, signaling that he planned to use diplomacy, economic pressure and the potent symbol of the quick American ouster of the Iraqi government to make his point.
However, Mr. Powell's use of the phrase "right now" seemed likely to fuel concerns in the Middle East about Mr. Bush's ultimate intentions. It carried echoes of White House statements last fall that Mr. Bush had no war plan for Iraq "on his desk."
"We have concerns about Syria," Mr. Powell said. "We have let Syria know of our concerns. We also have concerns about some of the policies of Iran," referring to Iran's fast-moving nuclear weapons development program. "We have made the Iranians fully aware of our concerns.
"But there is no list," he said, to overthrow the leadership of any other country in the region.
In the interview tonight, the senior American official said Mr. Powell had not intended to issue any warnings of military action. The secretary, the official said, "simply didn't want to shut down every option" for the future.
In Damascus, the Syrian government issued a statement after a cabinet meeting today, denouncing the escalating charges against it, saying they were baseless and intended to promote Israeli goals in the region. The statement also called on the United States to end its occupation of Iraq. 
Other Arab countries chimed in with support for Syria's position. The foreign ministers of the Gulf Cooperation Council, meeting in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, decried the attacks on Damascus and said the ministers accepted Syria's statements that it had not helped senior Iraqis escape and that it did not possess chemical weapons.
Editorial writers around the Arab world rallied to Syria's defense, many viewing the Bush administration threats as a prelude to a repeat performance of what the United States did in Iraq. 
"The region is on the verge of yet another disaster," saidAl Ahram, a semiofficial Egyptian daily newspaper. "There must be immediate Arab action based on the lessons of Iraq. This is not only necessary to safeguard Syria itself, but to stop the U.S. scheme." 
In the Rose Garden today, Mr. Bush insisted that his intention was "to liberate every corner of Iraq."
He acknowledged that it would take time. "The immediate tasks involve establishing order, as well as delivering food and water and medicines," he said. "We'll help Iraqis to restore electrical power and other basic services. We'll help destroy the former regime's weapons of mass destruction. We'll help the Iraqi people to establish a just and representative government."
But Mr. Bush also hinted at his broader agenda, saying, "I believe that a free Iraq can be an example of reform and progress to all the Middle East." Administration officials say they know those words raise concern among the rulers of the region. But as one official said, "We have to make it clear that we didn't just come to get rid of Saddam. We came to get rid of the status quo."
President Bush also took a phone call today from President Jacques Chirac of France, the first time the two leaders have had an extensive conversation since their public breach over France's refusal to back American military action in Iraq. The White House termed the call "businesslike," but said Mr. Chirac joined the president in urging Syria not to harbor former Iraqi leaders.
"We have differences," Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, said today. "We still have some of those differences. But that won't stop the president from working in a businesslike and professional way with an ally like France." In Paris, Mr. Chirac's spokeswoman, Catherine Colonna, described the conversation as "positive."
Mr. Rumsfeld said today that American military engineers had been told to work with Iraqi technicians to shut down the Iraq-Syria oil pipelines, and that it appeared the task had been accomplished.
"We do know that they were instructed to shut it down, and they have told us that they have," Mr. Rumsfeld said at a Pentagon news conference. "Whether it's the only one, and whether that has completely stopped the flow of oil between Iraq and Syria, I cannot tell you."
With the conclusion of major military operations in Iraq, Mr. Rumsfeld was poised to cancel some ongoing deployments of forces to Iraq and to adjust others, Pentagon and military officials said today.
The First Armored Division, based in Germany and at Fort Riley, Kan., will continue its deployment to Iraq, but without its field artillery elements, which include about 1,300 troops, officials said.
"We're also on a very active effort to attract and encourage other countries to offer forces" for the stabilization process, Mr. Rumsfeld said.
In Iraq, officials at the Army's V Corps headquarters near the Kuwait border said that the military situation had stabilized around Baghdad and south of the capital, and that there were no clashes with Iraqi troops or paramilitary units in the area.
An Army officer said the 82nd Airborne Division, which has been patrolling southwest of Baghdad, near Karbala, Samawa and Najaf, was almost entirely involved in civil affairs activities, like restoring electricity and delivering food. Soldiers from the division delivered 2,000 meals to a Najaf children's hospital.
In the Baghdad area today, except for encountering sniper fire, soldiers of the 101st Airborne Division and the Third Infantry Division faced little or no contact with Iraqi fighters.
Officials said Iraqi units continued to surrender to the Americans. Today, the Third Infantry Division accepted the peaceful surrender of the 12th Armored Battalion, west of Baghdad. Among the prisoners taken were an Iraqi major general who also surrendered the tanks and weapons of the unit, officials said.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook; 
Presidential Yacht Sequoia

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN S. PICKERING

 BODY:
A finely crafted motor yacht that witnessed key historic moments in American history languishes at a marina near the Tidal Basin in Washington. There it is susceptible to vandalism, weather and larcenous souvenir seekers. It ought to be in a safer place where it can be revered rather than rented. 
 The yacht, the U.S.S. Sequoia, was auctioned off by President Jimmy Carter in 1977 as an objectionable symbol of the imperial presidency. The boat is now in private hands; its decks, wood surfaces and brightwork appear to be well kept, but the Sequoia is also available for high-end charter trips along the Potomac or into Chesapeake Bay, liable to the wear and tear that come with such party-boat use. 
 It is a sad plight for such a graceful piece of the furniture of our history. The Sequoia, 104 feet long, was built in 1925 by John Trumpy, a respected boatwright of the period, for a Philadelphia banker. It was sold to the federal government in 1931, during Prohibition, to be used in a long-running Commerce Department sting against rumrunners along the Chesapeake waterways. But it was soon recruited as a presidential yacht by Herbert Hoover, when it occurred to him that the 318-foot vessel he had been using for summer cruises might have appeared unseemly to a public enduring the depths of the Depression. It was an act of parsimony that proved to have been lost on voters.
Hoover's successor, Franklin Roosevelt, spent a great deal of time on the Sequoia, fishing and entertaining during the pre-air-conditioning Washington summers. He is said to have conferred with Gen. Dwight Eisenhower about the D-Day landings while on board the yacht, and Winston Churchill joined him for an occasional cruise. Harry Truman is supposed to have made the decision to use the atomic bomb against Japan while aboard. Richard Nixon and the Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev worked on detente at a round table on the Sequoia's top deck. John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson, during their terms of office, both added customized features. The Sequoia was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1985.
Such a resume merits better treatment than the vessel is getting. The Sequoia Foundation was set up three years ago with the purpose of lobbying Congress for a grant to buy the boat, restore it and maintain it. But the group has had no luck so far, and in the current war-straitened economy, it has little hope of any appropriation coming its way soon. Still, economic crises come and go, but there is only one Sequoia, and such pieces of the nation's patrimony are unique and fragile things. It has earned safe harbor. STEPHEN S. PICKERING

HEADLINE: G.M.'s Quarterly Earnings Beat Forecasts 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
First-quarter earnings at General Motors beat Wall Street's expectations yesterday, but they were viewed skeptically because gains in the company's financing operation, particularly its mortgage business, offset weakness in its automotive operations. 
 G.M. said in a conference call that concerns about the economy persisted even as the war in Iraq appeared to be winding down, leading the company to scale back projections for auto sales and earnings. Executives said the company would have difficulty meeting its 2003 earnings target of $5 a share and warned that second-quarter earnings would come in at $1 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected $1.46 a share. 
 The company is also suffering in the United States market, where most automotive profits are made. In the first quarter, G.M.'s market share fell to 26.6 percent from 28.2 percent a year ago; at the same time, the company was spending more money on incentives but selling fewer vehicles. With only preliminary data available, sales did not appear to be getting a huge lift from the Big Three's April incentive spree, which has extended zero percent financing to 60-month loans on all vehicles except Hummers.
"We're getting the disadvantage of some stronger headwinds, certainly in the pricing area, certainly in the economic uncertainty, and that's leading us to be a little less certain about making our $5 for the full year," said John M. Devine, G.M.'s chief financial officer. He said that G.M.'s strong fourth quarter, which included big end-of-the-year deals, probably pulled some sales ahead from the first quarter. 
Shares of G.M. fell 95 cents, or 2.7 percent, to $35.17.
"To me, it's real depressing," said Ronald Tadross, an analyst at Bank of America, adding that G.M.'s ratcheting up of incentive levels seemed to be seeking "a knockout punch" when a more sustainable and less costly strategy was needed. 
Stephen Girsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said that despite the strong performance by General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the G.M. financing unit, automotive operations were problematic. "Their share was down despite the fact that prices were down and their fleet sales were up," he said. Sales to corporate and rental car fleets are less profitable than sales to retail customers and are often used to clear inventory. 
David Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities, who has a more bullish outlook, said "the pessimism is overdone," and called G.M. stock well valued at its current price. 
"As we have an economic recovery and people stop worrying about Iraq, the stock can creep higher," he said. "I feel that way pretty much about the whole group."
G.M. had net income of $1.48 billion, or $2.71 a share, in the first quarter, up from $228 million, or 57 cents, in the period a year earlier. 
The company generated $1.1 billion from the sale of G.M. Defense to General Dynamics; the unit makes light armored vehicles for the United States Army and for other governments.
Excluding gains from the sale of G.M. Defense, and results from Hughes Electronics, the company had net income of $1 billion, or $1.84 a share, for the quarter. That compared with adjusted net income in the first quarter of 2002 of $791 million, or $1.39 a share. 
Analysts had expected adjusted earnings of $1.54, according to the consensus estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. 
Revenue rose to $49.37 billion from $46.21 billion in the quarter a year earlier. North American automotive profits fell to $548 million from $654 million, while earnings at G.M.A.C. rose to $699 million from $439 million, bolstered by a record performance in the unit's mortgage operations, though the performance is "probably not sustainable" Mr. Devine said. 
This week, G.M. struck a deal to sell 20 percent of Hughes Electronics, which owns the DirecTV satellite service, to the News Corporation. The rest of the company's Hughes stake -- another 10 percent valued at $1.2 billion -- was used to address a perpetual issue for the company, financing its enormous pension plan, which was underfunded by $19 billion at the end of last year. 
The pension deficit puts all the more pressure on the automotive operations. Paul Ballew, G.M.'s chief sales analyst, said the company believed that industry sales in April would be around the rate of 16.5 million units, a good performance but also considerably below the huge market response in October 2001, when G.M., Ford and Chrysler offered similar zero percent, 60-month deals after the Sept. 11 terror attacks. 
"What we've seen so far is pretty consistent with what we've expected," Mr. Ballew said. 
For the year, he appeared to step back slightly from previous forecasts of sales in the mid- to upper-16-million vehicle range. 
"Right now I would anticipate the industry will be above 16 million units," he said. 
Mr. Devine said the company wanted to be cautious about its numbers. "We are less certain at least in putting a number out there," he said. "We're certain about our product lineup, we're certain about the internals of the company. The game plan is the same. The caution that we've provided is driven by the U.S. market, because it's our biggest, and where the market is going and where the consumer is going."

HEADLINE: Chief Ousted At Skandia Amid Tumult 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE WHITEHOUSE 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 16 

 BODY:
Unswayed by Lars-Eric Petersson's offer to work for just 1 Swedish krona (12 American cents) for the rest of the year, Skandia, the Swedish financial services company, dismissed him today as chief executive and brought Leif Victorin, a former deputy chief executive, out of retirement to head the company until a permanent replacement can be found. 
 Over the past year, Skandia's reputation has been badly damaged by a disastrous share price performance, the failure of a costly expansion into the United States and sustained criticism in the Swedish media over internal dealings between the parent company and its life insurance arm, Skandia Liv, as well as executive perks and bonuses. 
 Analysts view the Skandia board's removal of Mr. Petersson, who was appointed chief executive in 1997, as an attempt to restore investor confidence. 
"Someone has to pay the price," said Thomas Johansson, financial services analyst at Enskilda Bank in Stockholm. Whether Mr. Petersson was to blame for anything "is beside the point," he said.
The board also set up project teams to examine Skandia's practices on reporting, compensation, ethics and communication and information. A lawyer, Otto Rydbeck, will investigate transactions between Skandia and Skandia Liv.
Skandia, along with other life insurers, has seen its profits eroded by plummeting stock markets and rising benefit costs. The company has been especially vulnerable to the economic downturn because of its heavy dependence on equity-linked savings products. Its stock has lost more than 90 percent of its value from a March 2000 peak of 250 Swedish kronor. 
In December, the group sold its largest unit, American Skandia, which accounted for more than half its sales, to Prudential Financial for only $1.15 billion, for an after-tax loss of $511 million.
Analysts said they were surprised that Skandia had not yet found a permanent replacement for Mr. Petersson, given the length of time the problems had been mounting. Mr. Victorin, 62, a 33-year veteran of the company, is a "safe pair of hands," said Marc Thiele, an insurance analyst at Commerzbank Global Equities in London. But he added: "It's really a temporary solution. Skandia needs to convince investors that it has a clear long-term strategy. Until there's a new man in place, we won't have any idea how they will take the business forward."
Skandia's strategy of "rewrapping" other companies' equity-linked products and selling them through independent financial advisers and broker-dealers, leaving the company with almost no overhead, served it well in a bull market, Mr. Thiele said. The company now needs to become "a producer and distributor, rather than a packager," he said. "That will make it less vulnerable to the effects of falling equity markets."
Shares rose 0.30 Swedish krona, to close at 21.30 kronor, after news of the management change.

HEADLINE: An Industry Under Constant Scrutiny 

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, April 16 

 BODY:
With little fanfare, European authorities have conducted one investigation after another into anticompetitive behavior in the chemical industry. A dozen inquiries have now come to light over the last four years, with one previously unreported investigation already near completion and another just beginning. 
 The growing number of investigations and the number of companies figuring in multiple cases raise questions about why the industry seems so prone to collusion, and whether past enforcement actions had been tough enough to deter wrongdoing. 
 According to people close to the European Commission's antitrust division, the commission will hold a hearing in the next few weeks with companies that it has accused of operating a price-fixing cartel for 17 years in the world market for sorbates, a class of food additives used to prevent mold in cheese and baked goods. 
The United States Department of Justice has been investigating the same market and has levied finestotaling $132 million so far. The companies involved in the American case include Hoechst, now a division of Aventis of France; Celanese of Germany; Nippon Gohsei of Japan; and Eastman Chemical of the United States. 
The European Commission declined to say which companies it has accused. Nancy Ledford, a spokeswoman for Eastman Chemical, confirmed that her company is a part of the European investigation, but she said that the commission had given the company "indications that it does not intend to pursue the investigation." Eastman Chemical left the sorbates market in 2000, she said. 
An Aventis spokesman declined to comment, and calls to other companies thought to be involved in the matter were not returned.
The European Commission is also investigating a suspected cartel in the market for choline chloride, or vitamin B4, which is most widely used commercially as a growth-enhancing additive in livestock feed. The investigation was opened in 1999, involving BASF of Germany and UCB of Belgium.
"We have been cooperating in full with the European Commission," said Arnot Denis, a spokesman for UCB. BASF's spokesman, Michael Grabicki, said his company was also cooperating. 
People close to the commission said that its antitrust officials had not yet sent the companies a formal statement of objections; that step would turn an investigation into a lawsuit.
As with the sorbates case, United States regulators are also examining the vitamin B4 market; DuCoa, an American vitamin-making joint venture of DuPont and ConAgra Foods, and a Canadian rival, the Chinook Group, have been fined for their roles in a 10-year price-fixing cartel. Neither company was available to comment on whether it figures in the European inquiry.
A spokesman for the Dutch chemicals group Akzo Nobel, which is also suspected of participating in the vitamin B4 cartel, said that his company "is involved in several European Commission cartel cases" but would not comment further.
The vitamin B4 and sorbates cases have come to light just a few days after the commission confirmed that it had begun an investigation into the markets for hydrogen peroxide, used in hair dyes, and for various paint solvents and plasticizers. BASF and Solvay of Belgium confirmed that they are being investigated in that case, which is also understood to involve Degussa, Celanese and the Atofina unit of TotalFinaElf, the French oil company.
Two months ago, the commission confirmed that it had opened an investigation into companies that supply raw materials for making polyvinyl chloride plastic, including Akzo Nobel and TotalFinaElf. Last year, European regulators opened three other cartel investigations into niche segments of the oil-based chemicals sector. 
"There are many repeat offenders in the chemicals industry," said Catriona Hatton, a competition lawyer in the Brussels office of Hogan & Hartson. "It makes you wonder if the fines are large enough." 
The commission's largest fine so far has been 855 million euros ($924.5 million), imposed in 2001 against eight chemical manufacturers. Two other chemical cartels were broken up the same year.
"The chemicals industry is very incestuous," said Frank Mitsch, an analyst with Bear Stearns. In many cases, he said, "their competitors are their customers for different products, so there's a lot of inter-company contact."
Rapid consolidation, especially in the 1990's, may also have contributed to the cozy ties that exist between supposed rivals, he said, though he added that he did not think the chemicals sector was any worse than other industries.
Still, said the number of chemical-related cartel investigations was unusually high, according to Jacques Bourgeois, a competition lawyer at Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld. "It could partly be explained by the fact that it is one of the biggest industries in Europe," Mr. Bourgeois said. "There is more chance of a cartel occurring in a bigger industry."
A person close to the commission said that the rise in the number of new cartel investigations in recent years may be partly attributable to a change in the commission's rules, allowing it to offer immunity from penalties to a cartel participant that blows the whistle on the collusion.
Cartel members are famously disloyal, said a competition lawyer involved in some of the cases. "Now, with the added incentive of immunity, it is no surprise that more of them are turning on their co-conspirators."
The lawyer said two more cases involving food-related parts of the chemical industry are in the pipeline. He gave no specifics, but he said, "I anticipate more to follow them."
The European competition commissioner, Mario Monti, has called cartels "a cancer on the market economy," and he has put breaking up cartels high on his list of enforcement priorities. The cases that have surfaced in recent years, he said, are just a small part of the problem.

HEADLINE: As Japan Struggles, Pachinko Evolves 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 13 

 BODY:
Chang-Woo Han has never had it so good. As Japan, the world's second-largest economy, struggles to regain its footing, his business, running the country's largest chain of pachinko parlors, is growing by leaps and bounds.
 Mr. Han is the founder and chairman of the Maruhan Corporation, which presides over a 121-shop empire spread from Hokkaido to Kyushu that took in 576 billion yen ($4.8 billion) last year from the players who pump money into pachinko, a sort of vertical pinball game, the way Americans feed slot machines. While bankruptcies have soared in Japan, and deflation has chewed into many companies' profits, Maruhan's sales have almost tripled since 1998, and Mr. Han expects them to double again by 2005. Next year, he wants Maruhan to become the first pachinko chain listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. 
 Pachinko, a rare curiosity at best in the rest of the world, is a big business in Japan, with total revenue of about 28 trillion yen ($233 billion) a year, as much as that of Japan's five largest automakers combined. But it has been highly fragmented, with only a handful of companies achieving even a 1 percent market share. 
It was long regarded as recession-proof, but in the current downturn it has suffered along with other entertainment businesses in Japan. Rising unemployment and falling wages have left consumers with less pocket money to pour into a game in which players can lose $100 or more in a matter of minutes. Younger Japanese have been drifting toward video games, movies and sports like skiing and surfing.
The sour economy, falling land values and the growing risk aversion of the nation's struggling banks have combined to drive a growing number of mom-and-pop operations out of business, not just in pachinko but also in the similarly structured tavern and karaoke-bar industries. Even healthy operators have a hard time obtaining bank loans for expansion.
These misfortunes, however, have been a boon for the biggest companies in the industry, like Maruhan. As the bubble economy collapsed, Mr. Han saw potential for larger parlors and lined up financing to grab store space in busy central locations as it became available. With 48.7 billion yen ($406 million) in loans, he built multifloor emporiums that lure customers with no-smoking sections, free parking and, crucially, improved odds of winning cash. The cash flow from these successful, large parlors has helped Maruhan add more locations. It has also enabled it to diversify into movie theaters, bowling alleys and a doughnut franchise.
"Even if our industry faces a crisis, not all of us will fall into it," said Mr. Han, 72, prosperously turned out in a well-tailored gray suit with gold-tinted pinstripes, gold cuff links and a gold watch for a recent interview. His bubbling confidence makes him unusual here in more ways than one: he is also a rare example of a corporate leader from Japan's ethnic Korean minority, which is widely discriminated against.
"We have turned a crisis into a chance," he said of Maruhan's recent growth.
The crisis, though, is still evident. Though the industry still claims half of all leisure spending in Japan, or 6 percent of the gross domestic product, its sales have fallen by 10 percent from their 1995 peak, and the customer base is falling even faster: 19 million Japanese played the game last year, one-third less than a decade ago.
As the smaller and weaker companies have shaken out, the bigger entrants have taken a greater share of the remaining market. Despite a 5 percent reduction in parlors since 1997, the same number of machines are in use.
Mr. Han's five-story Maruhan Pachinko Tower in Shibuya, a trendy Tokyo neighborhood teeming with teenagers and young office workers, typifies the trend toward larger parlors. Ablaze with neon, the store packs in 1,000 of the latest machines, adorned with L.C.D. screens and blaring musical jingles, and it averages more than 4,000 customers a day.
To play pachinko, which originated in the United States in the 1920's but never caught on there, a player buys a supply of steel ball bearings, slings them to the top of the machine and watches them tumble down, deflected this way and that by dozens of metal pins. When some disappear into holes in the playing board, new balls are spit out from the bottom and can be played or redeemed for gifts or cash. 
The positioning of the pins on the board and the number of balls returned vary from machine to machine. Parlor owners adjust the memory chips in the back of the machines to fine-tune the payout rates. 
Committed players often line up outside their favorite shops before they open for the day, hoping to secure what they believe are the "hot" machines. 
But the parlor owners make higher profits from more casual customers who want to be pampered as much as they want to play the game. Parlor owners have experimented with amenities like having refrigerated coolers so that housewives can stow groceries and play on their way home from shopping. Where older players were happy to win items like golf balls and canned corned beef in small shops, the bigger new parlors try to attract younger players with prizes like leather handbags and Swiss Army knives.
"The service is what makes parlors different -- whether it's clean and you take your kids there and so on," said Takashi Kadokura, who tracks the industry for the Dai-ichi Life Insurance Economic Research Institute.
The amenities are also meant to help dispel the raffish underworld atmosphere that has tainted the industry for decades, much as a whiff of organized crime has tended to hang over the American casino industry. Gangsters have been involved around the margins of the pachinko business, as they have in many cash businesses here, but the government has been tightening regulation of the industry and improved tax collection in recent years, and many retired police officers now serve as guards and security advisers at pachinko parlors.
Some 70 percent of parlor owners are of Korean ancestry. Korea was a Japanese colony before World War II, and many Koreans brought to work in Japan during the war found afterward that they had little choice but to turn to self-employment because most jobs in government and at big companies were closed to them. Many worked hard to assimilate into Japanese society. Mr. Han, who left Korea as a teenager in 1945 and finished school in Kyoto, kept his Korean name but is now a naturalized citizen.
His story is not uncommon. He studied economics and considered a career in fashion, but began working in his brother-in-law's pachinko shop in 1953 because it was a steady cash business. 
As Japan prospered, pachinko thrived, and Mr. Han did well enough in the 1960's to branch out into another booming industry, bowling. At one time, he owned the nation's largest alley, with 120 lanes.
But bowling alleys need a lot of space in a country where land is scarce and expensive, and the economic downturn after the 1973 oil shock found Mr. Han badly overextended; he lost nearly everything he owned. With encouragement from his Japanese banker, he started again in pachinko, concentrating on prime locations near train stations, and was well positioned to ride the 1980's boom and to take advantage of the long slide in asset prices in the 1990's to keep growing.
Mr. Han has one last goal for his business: taking it public. "Just to survive is meaningless," he says. "We have to be winners." 
Pachinko operators are only just starting to win the respect of Japan's business establishment, despite the immense cash flow through the industry. But the growing sophistication of operators like Maruhan is winning more attention.
"Big companies are now coming in to run parlors," said one industry expert. "The business has a perceived cash value and the economy is not performing well. So as the bigger chains move into the business, it's become socially responsible."

PERSON: D. Gale Johnson 

HEADLINE: D. Gale Johnson Dies at 86; An Expert on Farm Economics 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
D. Gale Johnson, a pioneer in agricultural economics and later an expert on the Soviet Union and China, died Sunday in Amherst, Mass. He was 86.
 The cause was pneumonia related to Lou Gehrig's disease, according to his daughter, Kay Ann. 
 Professor Johnson's career in agricultural economics began in the 1940's, when that area was producing groundbreaking work. Several of his insights presaged other notions that are now hallmarks of macroeconomics and labor economics. 
His study of forward prices for farm commodities foreshadowed the doctrine of rational expectations, which holds that people do not make systematic errors when forecasting repeated, uncertain outcomes, like future prices for corn. 
His research on farm employment helped to pave the way for the concepts of human capital -- taking account of the native knowledge, skills and health of workers -- and self-selection in labor markets, which is the tendency to gravitate toward work that a person finds most fitting or most enriching.
He also contributed to the understanding of relative prices by explaining how farm incomes could rise even as crop prices fell, as a result of changes in productivity and labor costs.
Though he did not have a strong taste for formal models of the sort posited by today's economic theorists, Professor Johnson's thinking usually cut to the core of any issue, said Yair Mundlak, an emeritus professor of agricultural economics and management at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.
"He was a man of a great deal of common sense, and a great deal of no-nonsense," Professor Mundlak recalled. "He was looking for the real McCoy. He wanted to go right to the point."
Professor Johnson wrote more than 300 books, chapters and articles, including the Encylopaedia Britannica's entries on agricultural economics, food supply and famine. But speaking about his chosen field in an interview with the magazine of Iowa State University, his alma mater, Professor Johnson said, "Some good work has been done, but I have to say, it's a lot easier than being a farmer."
David Gale Johnson was born on his parents' farm in Vinton, Iowa, and lived there until he went to college. For much of his childhood, he was one of eight students in a one-room schoolhouse.
Attending high school during the Depression, he became active in debate and made presentations at farmers' meetings on New Deal programs. For one debate, he wrote to Theodore W. Schultz, a professor at Iowa State College, as the university was called then, to ask for recommendations of study materials. Professor Schultz took an interest in the young student, who soon enrolled at Iowa State.
At that time, the college boasted one of the top economics departments in the nation. Professor Johnson studied under Kenneth E. Boulding, who later won the John Bates Clark medal as the nation's leading economist under 40, and two future winners of the Nobel in economic science: George J. Stigler and Professor Schultz.
Professor Johnson continued his education at the University of Wisconsin and at the University of Chicago. He returned to Iowa State to finish his doctorate in 1941. Two years later, the president of Iowa State, reacting to pressure from the dairy industry, quashed the publication of a research pamphlet on the economic benefits of using margarine rather than butter during wartime. Incensed, Professor Schultz departed for the University of Chicago; Professor Johnson followed his mentor.
He stayed at Chicago for virtually all of the next six decades, rising to the university's highest endowed professorship in 1970 and serving as provost from 1976 to 1980. He was a frequent adviser to the World Bank and the federal government, including stints on two presidential commissions in the Kennedy administration.
According to a brief autobiography on Professor Johnson's Web site, his interest in agricultural reforms in the Soviet Union began in 1950. A similar penchant for China germinated in 1980. He became an emeritus professor in 1986 and served as director of the Center for East Asian Studies from 1993 to 1998. He received numerous professional honors and was president of the American Economic Association in 1999.
Professor Johnson was married to Helen Wallace from 1938 until her death in 1990. In addition to his daughter, he is survived by a son, David Wallace, of Beaver Springs, Pa., and four grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: D. Gale Johnson in 1991.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: EMERGENCY AID; 
Relief Groups Seek to Keep Pentagon at Arm's Length

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: KUWAIT, April 16 

 BODY:
The planning for relief assistance in postwar Iraq has been so dominated by the Pentagon that private aid groups say they are risking their neutrality by sending workers into the country.
 No major aid organization has declined to work in Iraq because of the Pentagon's role in the relief effort. As security has improved, some groups have entered the country in the last few days to see what is needed. 
 But some organizations have declined to accept United States financing for fear of being perceived by Iraqis and others as extensions of the American military. Other aid groups have accepted money but have sought assurances from the Bush administration that they would be reporting to the State Department, as has traditionally been the case, rather than the Pentagon. 
"As the United States has used its military more to reinforce foreign policy, it has need to win hearts and minds, and humanitarian assistance is one way to do it," said Sandra Mitchell, vice president of International Rescue Committee. The group has accepted American government funding for its Iraq programs, she said, but on the condition that it report to the State Department.
The strong hand of the Pentagon in relief work, she said, reflected "the continuing lack of confidence the administration has in the United Nations system, and its frustration with understanding the role of humanitarian groups and their principle of impartiality."
The Pentagon has wielded its power in every aspect of relief planning -- from running operations centers in Jordan and Kuwait to arguing in Washington over who manages government programs.
In a letter to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell last week, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld made clear his determination that the Pentagon control the delivery of emergency aid in Iraq. Mr. Rumsfeld told Mr. Powell that the Pentagon should manage approximately 50 experts from the United States Agency for International Development, whose work normally falls under the jurisdiction of the State Department.
These experts are supposed to lead Washington's civilian efforts to deliver aid in Iraq, and their leader, Michael Marx, is authorized to make emergency grants to private aid groups.
Officials at A.I.D. say it is important that these experts be kept independent from the military so that they can be free to deliver assistance on the basis of need, rather than as a part of any military objective of winning over the populace.
Mr. Rumsfeld's persistence on the relatively small matter of who controls 50 people symbolized the desire of the Pentagon to keep a tight rein on the relief programs, a senior State Department official said.
Here in Kuwait, the Pentagon and the Kuwaiti military opened the Humanitarian Operations Center, where aid organizations have been invited to register. A similar center is in Amman, the capital of Jordan, which, like Kuwait, is a gateway for aid deliveries into much of Iraq.
In most respects, the centers have taken the role of the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, which managed aid workers in the post-cold-war conflicts in Bosnia, Kosovo and Afghanistan.
Once registered at the operations centers, the aid organizations are allowed to attend morning briefings by the American military. Much of the information provided by the military is about the security situation inside Iraq. There are also broad discussions with soldiers from American civil affairs units about where aid might be needed, several aid workers said.
For leaders of aid organizations, such affiliation with the military even before aid deliveries begin has caused major debates.
"There is a large fear that everything will be seen as being done under the banner of the occupying force," said Nancy Lindberg, the executive vice president of Mercy Corps. "There is concern not only how the Iraqi people view it but how the international community views it."
"We're concerned about the precedent of the military being in charge," she added.
Mercy Corps had decided to accept A.I.D. money for its projects in Iraq, but on the understanding that the State Department would maintain control, she said.
The agency felt it could contribute in Iraq because of its experience in the Middle East, she said, and that its aid workers could maintain an independence from the military once they were in the country.
One aid group, Oxfam America, declined to accept A.I.D. funds for its Iraqi projects. The president of Oxfam, Raymond C. Offenheiser, said that the agency remained committed to a principle that it would not accept money from "belligerents on either side" of a conflict.
"We have not participated in the Humanitarian Operations Center, and will not be subject to taking direction from the United States military," Mr. Offenheiser said. "Our preference is to work with the United Nations structure, where there is impartiality."
One of Oxfam's first contributions would be water purification equipment that is scheduled to arrive Thursday in Kuwait for delivery into southern Iraq through Unicef, Mr. Offenheiser said.
The aftermath of the war was providing "a new template" for assistance, he said. "It is one in which the American military plays a significant role early on and marginalizes the roles of the nongovernmental organizations and the United Nations. It reduces them to subcontractors."
In deference to the nervousness among aid organizations, the military plans to rename the Humanitarian Operations Center when it reopens in Baghdad. It will be called Baghdad Forum, officials involved in its planning said.

HEADLINE: New Labor Realities 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
The airline unions had to swallow the bitter medicine sooner or later.
 Unions in other old-school American industries, notably automobiles and steel, have steadily become weaker over the last two decades as economic downturns and market pressures beat down the biggest companies, forcing them to revamp their business models. The same thing is happening now among the airlines, labor experts say, and the unions will have to adapt to new marketplace conditions or risk losing their relevance. 
 This situation is playing out at American Airlines, where executives struggled over the last couple weeks to obtain $1.8 billion in annual labor concessions. The company threatened to file for bankruptcy protection if it did not cut that much from its payroll. Though the pilots' and ground workers' unions voted in favor of their share of concessions on Tuesday, the flight attendants narrowly rejected $340 million in cuts that same day. 
Only yesterday did they finally agree to concessions after the voting period was extended and flight attendants were told they could change their votes.
The fact that several hundred flight attendants potentially held the fate of the world's largest airline in their hands would seem to point to the continuing power of organized labor. But the bottom line is that given the dismal state of the industry and the overall economy, none of the workers really had much leverage -- they likely would have lost much more if the AMR Corporation, American's parent, had gone into bankruptcy court. Unions and management were playing chicken, as they often do, but the unions were driving a Volkswagen Bug and the company an 18-wheeler.
"I think with the flight attendants, it could just be a cry of frustration," said David L. Gregory, a professor of labor law at St. John's University. "I wouldn't say it's powerlessness, but it's a last desperate cry."
The deregulation of the airline industry in 1978 unleashed market forces that have only recently spurred executives at the largest companies to consider overhauling their business models. The unions are not immune from that pressure to change. When the industry was regulated, high labor costs could be passed on to the consumer through government-fixed ticket prices, but that is impossible now if the big airlines want to compete with low-cost carriers like Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways.
The plight of the airline unions also mirrors broad trends in the American economy. Automation, outsourcing and increased worker productivity have resulted in large-scale layoffs in many industries. Workers have been asked to contribute to health care benefits, their pensions have been cut and they have received modest, if any, raises while top executives have in many cases received generous compensation packages. The airline industry is no exception, and this battering has contributed to the weakening of the unions.
In the late 1950's, about 35 percent of workers in private industry belonged to a union, said Charles B. Craver, a professor of labor law at the George Washington University. Membership plummeted over the decades to 8.5 percent last year.
"The thing that's so difficult is workers in this country in the last two decades have just fared very poorly," Professor Craver said. "In the airline industry, they'rebeing affected by competition from lower-cost carriers."
To compete, the big airlines are going to their unions for concessions. The companies, now in such shoddy shape, can wield the powerful cudgel of bankruptcy law. Section 1113 of the United States Bankruptcy Code allows them to ask for the power to void labor contracts if they can prove those contracts are seriously hampering their business. This frightens the unions, which then acquiesce -- if bitterly -- to the executives.
US Airways used this tactic during its eight months in bankruptcy court, and United Airlines, a unit of UAL, is trying it now. American almost certainly would never have been able to obtain its concessions without the threat of imminent bankruptcy. Industry experts expect the other big carriers -- Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines -- to adopt similar stances in seeking labor cuts.
Of course, unions in the airline industry have generally given concessions during downturns, then demanded generous contracts in return when the economy improves. That will likely be the case again during this cycle. But certain changes taking place now -- widespread layoffs, a revamping of work rules, increased automation -- appear to be permanent shifts that will dilute the power of the unions.
Over the last two decades, the traditional auto and steel companies made productivity changes to their operations that permanently affected the unions. The Big Three automakers went through rounds of layoffs and technological innovation to try to catch up to nimbler Japanese companies, which run nonunion factories in this country. The large steel companies had to do the same when minimills challenged their dominance with new business models.
There is no evidence in either industry that the unions will bounce back from all the cutbacks, even during economic upturns.
"I don't know that there are a lot of people predicting an upswing in union membership," said Paul F. Clark, a professor of labor studies and industrial relations at Pennsylvania State University. "The degree to which the unions survive has to do with their ability to change to these structural shifts. Unions, like other big organizations, don't change quickly."
But Professor Clark also noted that history shows there has always existed a "basic fundamental need for a countervailing power to employers." So though the traditional power of unions may be diminishing in the airlines and other industries, he said, they will most likely continue to serve as a voice of the workers even if they take a different tack. In the auto industry, for example, union leaders have tried to dampen their historic hostility to management to work more closely with executives battling foreign competition.
In the airline industry, unions at the large airlines -- beaten down by the current round of concessions -- might decide they need to cooperate more with management to stave off the growth of the low-cost carriers.
In the end, though, managers will still have to maintain cordial relationships with the unions because employees will always retain some power, especially since this is a service industry. Workers can organize a work slowdown or strike, despite preventive measures outlined in the Railway Labor Act. And they can act downright surly to travelers to show their displeasure at management.
How many passengers have said they bought a ticket on Southwest, JetBlue or a similar carrier because they did not like the attitudes of workers at the bigger companies? Way too many, say executives at the traditional airlines.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Ex-Chief Financial Officer Of WorldCom Is Indicted
Scott D. Sullivan, the former chief financial officer of WorldCom whose accounting maneuvers plunged the company into scandal, was indicted on additional federal charges that accuse him of defrauding a series of banks out of billions of dollars.
 Mr. Sullivan was first arrested in August and charged with using illegal accounting to hide expenses when WorldCom was struggling to meet forecasts. Page C2. 

Coca-Cola Posts Quarterly Profit
The Coca-Cola Company said that strong sales of Vanilla Coke and Diet Coke in the first quarter allowed it to reverse course and report a profit despite economic challenges in some places overseas. But a modest growth of 4 percent in worldwide volume disappointed investors, who had been expecting a larger gain. C2.

Morgan Reports Strong Earnings
J. P. Morgan Chase reported stronger-than-expected earnings as low interest rates led to record mortgage refinancings and robust bond trading profits. C3.

Driven by the robust environment for trading and underwriting bonds, Merrill Lynch recorded earnings of $685 million for the first quarter of this year, up 6 percent from the same period last year. C3.

Housing Construction Up in March
Housing construction rose 8.3 percent in March, almost twice as much as economists forecast. C5.

Sun Microsystems Has Small Profit
Sun Microsystems, the computer server maker, reported a small profit for its third quarter despite a 10 percent drop in sales. C13.

Loss Doubles at Northwest Airlines
The loss at Northwest Airlines more than doubled in the first quarter, to $396 million, as the war in Iraq and higher fuel costs battered the travel industry. Richard Anderson, the chief executive, said that he saw no signs that business would improve anytime soon. C4.

Chief Is Ousted at Skandia
Skandia, the Swedish financial services company, dismissed Lars-Eric Petersson, left, as chief executive and brought Leif Victorin, a former deputy chief executive, out of retirement to head the company until a permanent replacement can be found. Analysts view the move as an attempt to restore investor confidence in Skandia, which has been eroded by a disastrous share price performance and the failure of an expansion in the United States. World Business, Section W.

Financial Markets Are Mixed
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 144.75 points, or 1.7 percent, at 8,257.61. It was the biggest decline since March 31, when blue-chip stocks finished 153 points lower. The broader market finished mixed. The Nasdaq composite index rose 3.71 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,394.72. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 10.90 points, or 1.2 percent, to 879.91. C8.

Chemical Industry Under Scrutiny
Authorities in Europe have conducted one investigation after another into anticompetitive behavior in the chemical industry. A dozen inquiries have now come to light over the last four years. World Business, Section W.

A Deficit, Any Way It Is Sliced
When President Bush took office, the government was expected to produce a cumulative surplus over 10 years of $5.6 trillion. The Congressional Budget Office, using a variety of models, recently forecast that with a weaker-than-expected economy and another tax cut proposed by the president, the government would produce a deficit of $1.8 trillion over 10 years. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. C2.

As he turns his attention to the economy, President Bush is confronting a reality that many of his predecessors faced: a president cannot do all that much to strengthen the economy so that it is strong for his re-election. A22.

Bush Administration Tells Israel To Ease Palestinian Crackdown

Penalties Considered for Cuba

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: OIL; 
Iraq Pipeline To Syria No Big Secret, Experts Say

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE with FELICITY BARRINGER 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 16 

 BODY:
Although the Bush administration is moving to shut down a pipeline that provided Iraqi oil to Syria illegally, the United States and American oil companies have long imported Syrian oil, more of which became available after the pipeline opened about three years ago, oil industry experts here said today.
 Industry experts and oil traders said that about a week ago Syria told buyers of its oil that exports would decrease by 200,000 barrels a day for the rest of the year, indicating that it knew the pipeline would be closed or that it had been closed already. 
 Those experts and United Nations diplomats said that the pipeline, which carried 150,000 to 250,000 barrels a day, was an open secret in the industry and the United Nations Security Council. Council members' attempts to get an explanation from Syria were blocked by Russia, France and China, a United Nations diplomat said, and by Syria itself when it became a Council member. 
Both Syria and Iraq benefited enormously from the pipeline, said Fadhil J. Chalabi, a former acting secretary general of OPEC from Iraq and now executive director of the Center for Global Energy Studies in London, a research and consulting concern. "Saddam got cash outside the United Nations fund," he said.
The announcement of the American plans came on Tuesday, when Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said that the United States was about to cut off the pipeline, signaling the administration's willingness to pressure Syria. On Monday, the United States called Syria a "rogue state" after accusing it of harboring Iraqi fugitives and developing chemical weapons.
Under United Nations sanctions, Iraqi oil could be legally exported only through the oil-for-food program. Revenues from oil sales could be used only for food, medicine and other necessities. But the government of Saddam Hussein found several profitable ways to circumvent the program, among them the pipeline to Syria. The diplomat estimated that the Iraqi government reaped about $1 billion a year from the illegal exports to Syria.
The pipeline was built in the late 1940's to ship oil from Iraq's large Kirkuk field in the north to Banias in Syria and Tripoli in Lebanon, Mr. Chalabi said. But political tensions between Syria and Iraq led to the shutdown of the pipeline in 1982, he said.
The pipeline reopened "a couple of years ago," said Axel Busch, who discovered a big increase in Syrian exports as chief correspondent for oil markets at Energy Intelligence Group, an oil trade publishing house. According to assessments by the group and the oil industry, Syria produced about 495,000 barrels of oil a day, 300,000 barrels of it for domestic consumption. That meant the country could export only about 195,000 barrels a day. But based on oil loading contracts from Syria that Mr. Busch obtained, Syria was exporting more than 400,000 a day. 
"Where was the difference coming from?" Mr. Busch said. "A long unused pipeline had suddenly come into use." 
Syria refined the Iraqi oil for domestic use. It bought the illegal oil at a steep discount to world prices, perhaps for $7 or $8 a barrel, Mr. Chalabi estimated. But it exported its own production at the market price, in the process reaping huge profits.
"The great thing is that a whole list of American companies were buying Syrian oil, including ExxonMobil, but they wouldn't buy Iraqi oil," said one oil trader.
Among American buyers of Syrian oil are ExxonMobil and ConocoPhillips, said Mr. Busch. A spokesman for ConocoPhillips could not be reached for comment. But Prem Nair, a spokeswoman for ExxonMobil, said that it bought Syrian oil on the spot market, as needed, and that it constituted a small percentage of the oil it refines. She said the company adhered to United States restrictions on the kind of companies it does business with in Syria.
The United States imported Syrian oil and petroleum products in relatively modest volumes ranging from 10,000 barrels a day last October to 30,000 barrels a day in January, according to Energy Department data. 
For the past three years, British and American representatives on a United Nations sanctions committee have charged that the pipeline was being used to circumvent the oil-for-food program.The Syrians, when asked, said the pipeline was used for nothing but tests, or that Syria was "implementing all the resolutions of the Security Council," one Council diplomat said.
"People in the industry," a Council diplomat said, "knew what was going on -- they were buying Syrian oil while the Syrians used Iraqi oil domestically."
