HEADLINE: U.S. May Punish Cuba for Imprisoning Critics 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is considering a series of steps to punish the Cuban government for its recent crackdown on dissidents, officials said today.
 Among the more drastic are the possibility of cutting off cash payments to relatives in Cuba -- a mainstay for millions of Cubans -- or halting direct flights to the island, the officials said. 
 President Bush is likely to make a public statement soon about the crackdown, which has stirred grave concern among Cuba policy experts here and dampened the hopes of lawmakers and others seeking to ease the current trade sanctions.
At the same time, the president is expected to issue a stern warning to the Havana government that the United States will not tolerate another exodus of rafters, the officials said. Several times during Mr. Castro's 44-year tenure, most notably in 1980 and 1994, he has relieved internal tensions by allowing mass migrations to Florida. 
In recent weeks, the Castro government has jailed nearly 100 government critics, independent journalists, human rights advocates and others, and sentenced many of them to lengthy prison terms. In addition, Havana last week executed three men who commandeered a ferry and sought to reach the United States, the third such hijacking attempt in a month.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said on Tuesday that Cuba "has always had a horrible human rights record," but, he added, "It's getting worse."
"When you look at what they have done in recent weeks and recent months with respect to stifling dissent, with respect to arresting people and sentencing them to long years in prison, in jail, just for expressing a point of view that is different from that of Fidel Castro, it should be an outrage to everyone," he said. "It should be an outrage to every leader in this hemisphere, every leader in this world."
Administration officials said they were preparing a variety of options for the president, and no final decisions have been made. The harshest sanctions involve restricting or eliminating the transfer of cash payments, called remittances, to friends and relatives on the island. The payments, sent primarily from South Florida exiles, are a lifeline to millions of Cubans and, with estimates as high as $1 billion, a mainstay of the economy.
Also being considered is a move to limit the number of Americans who travel to Cuba by ending direct charter flights between the countries. Thousands of travelers -- mostly Cuban-Americans visiting family -- board charter flights each month from Miami, New York and other cities.
The Bush administration has already moved to curb other travel to Cuba, worried that it has increasingly become a popular tourist destination, especially for those who oppose American policy. Last month, the administration revoked authorization for travelers engaged in educational programs aimed at increasing contacts between Cubans and Americans.
The Cuban-American community, which has long been a bulwark of support for sanctions, is divided over whether to impose harsh measures. While some Cuban-American lawmakers back new sanctions, the Cuban American National Foundation, which is the most influential exile lobby, has called for protecting the tenuous links between Cubans here and civil society in Cuba.
Officials and Cuba specialists offer a number of explanations of why Mr. Castro has unleashed the most sweeping crackdown on dissidents in years.
Some say the Cuban leader was unnerved by the American-led ouster of an ally, Saddam Hussein in Iraq. Others note that the dissident community, long marginalized in Cuba, had made some strides in recent months, including the collection of more than 11,000 signatures on a petition to introduce democratic reforms. The head of the United States mission in Cuba, James Cason, infuriated Cuban officials by convening meetings of the government critics.
Dagoberto Rodriguez, the chief of the Cuban Interests Section in Washington, which serves as embassy in the absence of diplomatic ties, said that Mr. Cason and other American diplomats had been bankrolling and organizing dissidents, something American officials strongly deny.
"The U.S. government is spreading the notion that these people are imprisoned because of their ideas," Mr. Rodriguez said in an interview. "But they have conspired with the American government."
The repression has deflated efforts to increase contacts through trade and travel to the island. In Congress, majorities in both chambers favor lifting travel restrictions for Americans and advocate greater trade beyond the authorized sale of food and medicine.
But the White House opposes such moves and advocates of greater engagement concede that Havana has made their job much more difficult by locking up its prominent critics. 
Officials said that they were also preparing a strong statement for the president to make on illegal immigration. In recent days, rumors have swirled in various Cuban cities about the prospects for another rafters' exodus. 
"We will not tolerate rafters," said one policy maker.

HEADLINE: Bush's Next Test 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16 

 BODY:
As he turns his attention from the war to the economy, President Bush is confronting a reality that many of his predecessors, including his father, faced: a president cannot do all that much to strengthen the economy so it is strong for his re-election.
 In Mr. Bush's case, the Congressional Budget Office, which provides Congress with impartial, expert economic counsel, concluded in March that the overall effect on the economy of the president's tax cuts and spending plans would be negligible. 
 The important report, largely overlooked because of all the war news, stated: "Taken together, the proposals would provide a relatively small impetus in an economy the size of the United States'." 
This conclusion was especially striking because the study was supervised by Douglas J. Holtz-Eakin, new director of the budget office, who was chief economist at President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers. Republican leaders in Congress chose Mr. Holtz-Eakin because of his advocacy of tax cuts and his adherence to supply-side economics.
But economists' doubts that the Bush program could truly turn things around have not deterred the president from an aggressive campaign to persuade people that his proposals are the essential antidote to an ailing economy. 
In the same speech in the Rose Garden on Tuesday when he declared that "the regime of Saddam Hussein is no more" and that "our victory in Iraq is certain," Mr. Bush urged Congress to act quickly on his "pro-growth economic package."
In St. Louis today, the president called his tax proposals a "jobs package" that was crucial "in order for all Americans who are looking for work to find work."
Dozens of administration officials are fanning out across the nation this week and next, while Congress is in recess, to make the same argument. And after a long Easter weekend at his Texas ranch, Mr. Bush will focus on his plan in speeches around the nation, the White House said.
Why are the president and his team expending such an effort if the prospects are not strong that his program will turn the economy around in the next year? A leading Republican strategist said this week: "What is really crucial is that Bush be perceived as being engaged, that people feel he understands that times are not good, that he is deeply concerned and that he is doing everything in his power to fix it."
This reflects the lesson learned from his father's defeat in 1992, this strategist and others said. The senior Mr. Bush was unable to capitalize on his popularity after the 1991 Persian Gulf war because he seemed oblivious to the weak economy, fought Democratic efforts to extend unemployment benefits and did not propose an economic program of his own until many months after the war had ended when his popularity had already begun to slide.
Paradoxically, the Democrats in Congress who are fighting Mr. Bush's tax cut could be playing into his hands politically. If the president's $726 billion plan is whittled to $350 billion, as now seems likely, and the economy fails to improve, the president can blame Congress for not accepting his whole program. And, if the economy does get better, he can still claim the credit.
Even after the fact, economists agree, it is usually impossible to prove which policies led to economic strengthening and which caused deterioration. "There are always so many things going on at once," said Benjamin M. Friedman, a professor of political economy at Harvard. "If the economy does well, you can always say it did so for any of these five reasons, And if it doesn't, you can always say it did better than it would have otherwise."
But that has never stopped voters from rewarding presidents who preside over a strong economy and punishing those in office when the economy is weak.
Mr. Bush wants no part of the policies politicians usually advocate to give the economy a quick jolt: tax cuts for low-income families who are most likely to spend the money right away, public works projects to create construction jobs and job-training programs for the unemployed. 
Such steps are anathema to the conservative economic principles the president espouses. He and his aides even avoid the words "stimulus" and "stimulate," seeing them as Democratic words, and prefer to use the more Republican words "growth" and "grow."
Mickey D. Levy, Bank of America's chief economist, said the president might benefit because the parts of his plan that are likely to survive in Congress are ones that could improve economic performance somewhat from now to the election: an acceleration of rate cuts, new breaks for married couples and an expansion of the child credit and quicker write-offs of business investments.
The part of the plan that is most likely to fall by the wayside, the proposal to eliminate income taxes on most stock dividends, would have little immediate effect on the economy, Mr. Levy said.
If taxpayers have an additional $30 billion in disposable income this year because of various tax cuts and spend it all, Mr. Levy calculated, it could add half a percent to national consumption, change business expectations and lead companies to hire more workers.
But most of the Bush tax cut would be enjoyed by upper- and middle-income families, and much of that money would probably not be spent right away. In a poll this week by National Public Radio, the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation and the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, people nationwide were asked what they would do with a $300 per person tax cut. 
Forty-one percent said they would save or invest it; 40 percent said they would repay debts; and 19 percent said they would spend it outright, hardly enough to generate an economic boom for an election.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
EMC Posts Profit but Says Its Customers Remain Wary

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
EMC, the largest independent vendor in the business data storage industry, joined other major technology companies yesterday in reporting solid results for the first quarter. It announced that it had returned to profitability after more than a year struggling to cut costs and update its products. 
 EMC said revenues rose to $1.38 billion, up 6 percent from the first quarter of 2002, and profit margins expanded with the popularity of its latest version of Symmetrix, a refrigerator-size system that can cost $2 million or more. EMC's sales of products and software that are used in networks of less expensive storage devices, including devices made by rival vendors, also grew faster than expected. 
 The results were released before trading began, and investors responded by sending EMC's shares up 62 cents, to $8.39.
EMC, based in Hopkinton, Mass., had net earnings of $35.2 million, or 2 cents per diluted share, in the quarter compared with a loss of $76.9 million, or 3 cents a year ago. EMC said that the economic outlook remained very uncertain but repeated its earlier projections that it would be profitable every quarter of this year. And Bill Teuber, EMC's chief financial officer, forecast profits in the current quarter of 3 cents a share, a penny more than Wall Street's projections.
But Mr. Teuber said that most customers were interested only in products or services that quickly cut their current storage costs, rather than large investments to support major new computer projects. And Joseph M. Tucci, EMC's president and chief executive, said that customers continued to subject investments to more review than usual, causing delays.
In addition, because new technology continues to drive down the cost of storage, increases in the amount of data that businesses store do not automatically translate into growing revenues for data storage companies. "The only way to grow in this market is to take market share," Mr. Tucci said in a conference call with analysts.
EMC is doing just that, thanks to new products and a push to become more software and services driven. EMC said its overall equipment sales were $752 million for the quarter ended March 31, up 1 percent from a year earlier, with $575 million of that coming from its large Symmetrix systems. The Symmetrix sales were driven by the new DMX line, introduced in February, which also helped lift sales of related software.

HEADLINE: Sakharov's Widow Opposes Moscow's Plan to Build Monument 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 16 

 BODY:
A long-delayed proposal to erect a monument here to Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident who became the icon of resistance to Soviet oppression in the 1970's, has run into formidable opposition from an unlikely source: Mr. Sakharov's widow, Yelena Bonner.
 In an interview today, Ms. Bonner urged admirers of her husband "not to give a single kopek" for construction of a $600,000 monument to her husband being considered by Moscow's city legislature. Modern Russia, she said, does not represent the ideals that won Mr. Sakharov the Nobel Peace Prize in 1975. 
 "Today's Russia, with one-third of its population living below the poverty line, Russia waging a cruel and bloody war in which thousands of its soldiers and tens of thousands of peaceful citizens of Chechnya are dying -- this Russia is violently contrasting with the idea of erecting a monument to Sakharov," Ms. Bonner wrote in an open letter posted on several Russian Web sites.
Ms. Bonner said in a telephone interview that she hoped that Moscow "will live long enough to see the day when it would be fit to build this monument, and when Sakharov really will be needed by the Russian people."
That day has not come, she said, adding, "I don't know how long -- five years, 10 years, 20. But sooner or later the society will turn to Sakharov's ideas, to his legacy. Then there will be time to erect a monument."
Ms. Bonner, who now lives in Boston, is a frequent critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, the former head of Russian domestic intelligence.
Both Ms. Bonner and her husband were relentlessly persecuted by the K.G.B.'s domestic security arm in the 1970's and 1980's. Mr. Sakharov, a nuclear physicist who helped develop the Soviet Union's first hydrogen bomb, was sentenced to internal exile for seven years, from 1980 to 1986. 
Moscow's legislature first took up the proposal for a Sakharov monument in 1990, a year after Mr. Sakharov's death, as the Soviet Union was collapsing. Money was scarce, however, and the plans for the monument were shelved.
But Moscow is currently enjoying an economic boom, and its city legislature voted today to approve a proposal by Sergei Yushenko, a liberal federal legislator, to build the monument, but only if Ms. Bonner agreed to it.
In an interview with The Associated Press, Mr. Yushenko said he sympathized with Ms. Bonner's view that Russia has drifted back toward authoritarianism. "But we can't just silently watch it happen," he said. 
In a telephone conversation today, Ms. Bonner disagreed that erecting a statue of her husband would change anything.
She cited news reports of two street protests in Russia -- one against the United States invasion of Iraq and one against the war in Chechnya.
While the Iraq protest drew thousands, she said, the Chechnya demonstration attracted but a few hundred. 
"I ask you: which demonstration would Andrei Sakharov have joined?" she said. "I came to the conclusion that no monument can force society to re-evaluate its values." 
Sergei Kovalyov, another prominent Soviet dissident who is now a member of the lower house of Russia's parliament, said in an interview this evening that he supported Ms. Bonner's decision. Erecting a statue to Mr. Sakharov now, he said, would be "one more hypocrisy" by a government that does not subscribe to Mr. Sakharov's beliefs.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
The Congressional Budget Office's updated forecasting methods don't help the White House's argument for tax cuts.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and the journal Indicators, and he also teaches at Cooper Union and New School University. His new book is "Why Economies Grow," from Basic Books. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
WHEN the Bush administration took office in early 2001, the federal government was expected to produce a cumulative surplus over 10 years of $5.6 trillion. This March, the Congressional Budget Office, the bipartisan economic research arm of Congress, forecast that with a weaker economy than expected and still another tax cut proposed by the president, the federal government would produce a deficit of $1.8 trillion over 10 years.
 But some economists have long complained that the conventional forecasts do not take sufficient account of the many potential stimulative aspects of the tax cuts or budget deficits. I think they are right. 
 This year, at last, the budget office decided to provide alternative forecasts and analyze the "dynamic" effects of the president's budget and tax cut proposals. Many were suspicious. The budget office, now run by Douglas Holtz-Eakin, who had been a senior economic adviser to President Bush, sounded as if it might be trying to help justify the administration's policies, including the elimination of taxes on dividends.
But the numbers the budget office ran offered the administration no solace. It found under a variety of situations that the Bush policies, including the just-abandoned $726 billion tax cut proposal (which followed a $1.4 trillion tax cut in 2001), would more likely raise the expected 10-year deficit of $1.8 trillion further, not reduce it. The president's announcement this week that he would accept a tax cut of only $550 billion does not markedly change the analysis. In only a couple of cases did the budget office find the deficit might be reduced, and then at most by 15 percent or so.
How the budget office tackled the problem is a fascinating study in the advances of macroeconomic theory, and its many limitations. It used five different basic models of economic growth to make its forecasts. These models treated the effects of tax cuts, budget deficits, government spending and savings differently.
The first two models were those of two commercial firms, Global Insight and Macroeconomic Advisers -- models partly based on the principles of John Maynard Keynes. They assume that budget deficits can themselves stimulate economic growth by raising demand and creating incentives for businesses to invest. More savings will typically reduce rates of growth in the short run. 
The third model was a version of a long-term growth model derived from the original work of Robert M. Solow, the Nobel laureate. It assumes that technological progress will continue at a constant pace and that more savings on balance will mean more capital investment. 
The fourth and fifth models made assumptions based on theories that argue that rational people will offset the policies of the federal government because they take a long-term view of their own finances and the finances of their offspring. If deficits are high, for example, they will anticipate that the federal government will eventually raise their taxes so they will save more now. The budget office ran several variations of these. 
The models themselves generally cannot determine how some specific cuts, like the dividend tax cuts, would affect the cost of capital, and therefore capital investment. So the budget office made separate estimates. It concluded that the cuts, along with several other aspects of the Bush plan, would have stimulative effects for capital investment by reducing the cost of capital to businesses substantially. Thus, the potential impact of the dividend tax elimination was fully incorporated into the forecasts.
The budget office also estimated that reduced taxes would encourage people to work more. Not all economists would agree. 
Even given these fairly sympathetic assumptions, no model produced good news for the Bush plan. Both Keynesian models showed some stimulative effects in the short run because of the budget deficit, but not enough to reduce the deficits.
The textbook Solow model turned out to reduce the rate of growth and raise the deficit substantially. Higher deficits reduced total national savings and therefore undermined capital investment. 
The growth effects of the other two models were no more encouraging. In fact, the only cases in which the deficits were reduced by as much as 15 percent were when it was assumed that the government would raise taxes in 2014 to stabilize growing debt. The models then concluded that people anticipated this tax increase and saved more now. The higher level of savings resulted in more capital investment in the model, and therefore more growth and lower federal deficits. 
It would be fascinating to plug other government economic policies into these models to see what results they produced. My guess is that more short-term stimulus and tax cuts that are phased out over time would reduce deficits substantially and raise growth rates. 
But the models also highlight the limitations of macroeconomic forecasting. They are all deficient in one way or other, and what one makes of them depends on one's point of viewabout what makes economies grow. The Keynesian models used by the budget office, many argue, do not fully address how productivity can be raised over time. Some of the other models assume all government spending is waste.
At best, then, the models provide a range of sensible outcomes. As Mr. Holtz-Eakin cautions: "This was just the first step. It is by no means the last one."
Also, we should keep in mind that in the real world the basic deficit estimates of the budget office are all optimistic. It is charged only with making projections based on the proposed presidential budget. Many economists believe that the deficit, under more realistic assumptions about government spending and other policy changes, including war costs, will be significantly higher. 
What is clear from the budget office exercise in dynamic forecasts, however, is that the supply-side contention that the tax cuts will somehow pay for themselves is a pipe dream. Deficits will stay high. The Bush budget, with tax cuts, is hard to justify using any model of growth.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE ECONOMY; 
Baghdad Bank Plundered as Iraq's Economy Falters

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 16 

 BODY:
An axe rose and fell above a jeering mob in a narrow street behind Iraq's central bank here as a man worked to crack open a safe. Men with Kalashnikov assault rifles raised in the air shouted for others in the crowd to keep back, then set off a stampede down the street with an extended burst of fire.
 "Sometimes one group opens a safe and then another armed group shoots them dead and takes the cash," said Abdel Wahab Hamid, a 29-year-old unemployed Iraqi, after he had rounded a corner to flee the shooting on Tuesday. 
 Money continues to spill from Iraq's broken banking system, although the amounts are smaller now than they were in the first days after President Saddam Hussein's son Uday reportedly arrived at the bank to load sacks of cash into waiting cars. Since then, armed gangs have been slowly working their way through the strongboxes and vaults. Many people have died in the chaos. 
The rest of the country's formerly government-run economy is faring little better. Almost all of Iraq's thinly spread industry is at a standstill, its offices charred shells, its computers cannibalized or carried off by looters, its paperwork blowing down countless streets. 
The oil fields that provided almost all of the government's revenue and accounted for most of the country's economic output are not operating, largely because the people who ran them have disappeared. Agriculture is about the only part of the economy untouched, although dates and tomatoes do not provide much beyond subsistence. 
American military officials, hoping to jump-start the economy by restoring basic services like electricity and water, complain that the country's leaderless bureaucrats are paralyzed, waiting for commands that no one is giving. In the absence of a viable banking industry, the United States is even flying in dollars in small-denomination bills for emergency payments to workers.
"Ninety-nine percent of the economy was dependent on the government, and that has all stopped," said Mahadi Hindassi, 50, one of Iraq's largest egg suppliers.
Though parts of Iraq's economy are slowly returning to operation, all transactions are being conducted in cash, limiting the amount of business that can be done. And with the banking system devastated, the value of the Iraqi dinar sinking and the larger government economy unable to offer support, it is unclear how long those private businesses now operating can run before they stall again. 
Mr. Hindassi, speaking at his home in Baghdad's wealthy Zaiona neighborhood, said his chicken farm 30 miles south of the capital was facing a shortage of protein concentrate for feed, which he used to buy from government warehouses. But without a government to buy it from he fears his 300,000 chickens will die.
"We were always dealing with the state, but now there is no state," he said, sitting in the marbled receiving room of his palatial villa. 
As war approached, Mr. Hindassi said he and other businessmen began pulling money out of the banks and buying dollars. He used some of his cash to buy goods, including a new blue Mercedes, and some to gird his business for the shock of war. 
He bought generators to keep his egg operations running when the electricity stopped and hired 10 armed guards to keep looters at bay. He stocked a two-month supply of all the essentials he could find to keep his business running.
His egg prices rose briefly by 40 percent because of temporary food shortages caused by the war, but he said any gains had been wiped out by the sinking value of the dinar. Lawlessness has prevented him from buying more dollars, leaving him with a growing hoard of weakening dinars.
On Kefah Street, which is lined with the shuttered offices of currency-exchange shops, Khalid Muhammad, a money changer, said the dinar had dropped to 4,000 per dollar before the war but briefly recovered to about 2,500 dinars before sliding again to 3,500 dinars, "because the thieves have so many dinars that they have stolen from the banks and they want dollars."
Mr. Muhammad said he could not reopen his shop because it was too dangerous. A gun battle on Kefah Street on Tuesday left several people dead. Their bodies had yet to be picked up by late afternoon.
American officials have said they hope to have some Iraqi oil flowing again in a matter of weeks, and they are trying to round up former executives of Iraq's State Oil Marketing Organization to get the industry back on its feet. 
Even so, it will be almost certainly be years before the Iraqi economy recovers. Though Iraq has the second-largest oil reserves in the world, the pumps and pipelines that move the oil to market have been steadily deteriorating in recent years, and the country's production capacity has dropped by a third since the 1991 Persian Gulf war. Upgrading the oil fields will take time and money.
Revenue from Iraqi oil, meanwhile, will not be enough to meet all the competing demands on the country for cash. Iraq owes more than $200 billion in debt and reparations from the 1991 war, an amount that will drain the economy for years unless there is some form of international debt relief.
The question of how to deal with Iraq's foreign debt will be taken up next week at a meeting of creditor nations. The United States, which is owed little or nothing by Iraq, has proposed canceling the debt, but the idea has been resisted by Russia and some other large creditors. 
At the Doura refinery north of Baghdad, workers who have been guarding the refinery with weapons issued by Mr. Hussein's government say they have about one week's supply of gasoline left for the capital. But they say cannot resume their operations until oil starts flowing again in the pipeline from the northern oil fields near Kirkuk.
"The telephone lines are down so we don't even know whether the northern oil fields are operating or not, or whether it is the pipeline itself that is broken," said Raad Rafiq, 45, who is in charge of the pipeline.
For his part, Mr. Hindassi, sipping iced Pepsi from a gold-embossed glass beneath a crystal chandelier in his Baghdad home, said, "I'm hoping there will be a new national government soon, and that the dinar will strengthen as stability returns." 
But, he added, "only God knows" whether his chickens will still be alive then.

HEADLINE: A City on the Ropes 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Nineteen months after Sept. 11 there's still a gaping hole in the heart of Lower Manhattan, and New York City over all is still hurting.
 Instead of moving forward, the city is going backward. 
 This is not obvious. When the weather is nice, as it was yesterday, you get a real sense of the city's vibrancy. Just step outside and start walking and the throngs will carry you through New York's myriad currents. You'll have to detour around construction sites, and dodge a suddenly accelerating cab or a belligerent bus or two. But there'll be theaters and museums along the way, and the world's greatest restaurants, and Central Park and the Bronx Zoo, and riverfronts and oceanfronts, and an endless array of proud neighborhoods squeezed shoulder to shoulder in the miraculously constrained chaos that constitutes the world's greatest city. 
Still, it's a city in trouble.
So there was Mayor Michael Bloomberg at City Hall on Tuesday somberly explaining a budget plan that will throw thousands of city employees out of work and result in a sharp reduction in services. That's being touted as the best-case scenario, which gives you a sense of how rough a situation the city is in. New York's a tough town, but right now it's like a boxer who has been battered for several rounds and can no longer ward off the punches of his opponent. He has no choice but to absorb the blows and hope he doesn't get knocked out.
The mayor has a backup plan, a "doomsday" budget that will go into effect if he does not get the considerable help he says he needs from the state and the municipal unions. In that plan the city gets knocked out.
The governor of New York is George Pataki, a man who is quite capable, if it would serve his purposes, of looking at his watch and telling you it's high noon when in fact it's midnight. If Mr. Pataki is aware of how dire the budget situation is in New York City, he hasn't let on. All he does is mumble about his opposition to "job-killing tax increases."
As both the city and the state sink ever more deeply into fiscal quicksand, it's become clear to most sentient observers that broad-based tax increases of some kind will be necessary to ward off a real disaster. But Mr. Pataki, perhaps distracted by a desire to land a position with the fanatically antitax Bush administration, is not there yet.
Mayor Bloomberg is taking the crisis seriously. He's already pushed through a record increase in the property tax and is imposing billions of dollars' worth of budget cuts.
"There are no good answers," he said. He's asked Albany for a tax on commuters who work in the city and additional state aid. He is also seeking substantial concessions from the municipal unions.
Mr. Bloomberg acknowledged that the city "is having a tough time even maintaining its services," and he said there is a point at which further cuts are simply intolerable. His doomsday budget is frightening. Ten thousand municipal workers would be axed. Up to 40 firehouses would be closed. Sanitation services would deteriorate and municipal pools would be shut down. After-school programs would be eliminated. The police force would be reduced to dangerously low levels. Libraries would close and services for the desperately needy, including the hungry and the homeless, would be further curtailed. The city would be flirting with the kind of environment that almost led to its ruin in the 1970's.
New York City is the glittering jewel of American municipalities. It was attacked by a foreign enemy on Sept. 11, 2001, and it has suffered since then, as have other cities and states, from the effects of a bad economy and dreadful fiscal policies in Washington.
Eventually some help will come from Albany, but it won't be nearly enough and the deterioration of this splendid city will continue. Mr. Pataki's intransigence in the face of a genuine crisis is symptomatic of the reluctance of conservative officeholders to invest in the crucial services that help individuals, and thus a nation, to thrive.
Next year the Republican Party will hold its national convention in New York City, and it will go out of its way to exploit the powerful emotions evoked by ground zero and the memories of Sept. 11. The mayor of New York City, the governor of New York State and the president of the United States are all Republicans.
With that lineup you'd think this city, after all it's been through, could get a break. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: RECOVERY; 
BUSH URGING U.N. TO LIFT SANCTIONS IMPOSED ON IRAQ

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON with FELICITY BARRINGER 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, April 16 

 BODY:
Having declared Saddam Hussein's rule to be ended, President Bush called on the United Nations today to lift economic sanctions on Iraq, moving to allow greater sales of Iraqi oil to help pay for its reconstruction.
 In a speech here that combined elements of a campaign appearance with a solemn remembrance of lives lost in Iraq and a restatement of his foreign policy principles, Mr. Bush said that "the regime of Saddam Hussein has passed into history" and that it was time to end more than 12 years of sanctions, which have all but halted international trade with Iraq. 
 "Now that Iraq is liberated, the United Nations should lift economic sanctions on that country," he said.
Ending or suspending the sanctions should make it easier to sell Iraqi oil and raise money to repair the physical damage from the war and the economic damage from years of international isolation as well as neglect by Mr. Hussein. Iraqi oil sales are restricted by the United Nations oil-for-food program. 
But dropping the sanctions would require a Security Council vote. Raising the issue before the Council sets the stage for more debate, if not another diplomatic battle with France, Germany and Russia over the administration of postwar Iraq, the status of commercial contracts with Iraq and the awarding of reconstruction contracts.
Administration officials have not drafted a resolution to end sanctions.
"If you ask me, do we have a specific language or specific resolution to propose at this specific moment in time, the answer is no," Ambassador John D. Negroponte said at the United Nations. He said the specifics were still being discussed in Washington.
Scott McClellan, deputy White House press secretary, told reporters that the administration would seek a resolution "in the near future" that would help Iraq "restore a normal trading relationship with the global economy."
As recently as Tuesday, the Security Council committee monitoring the temporary operations of the oil-for-food program was consumed with debates over which contracts would be honored to buy food, supplies and medicines, with representatives of Russia and France often at loggerheads with the United States and Britain, according to two participants in the meeting. Still, some diplomats sent signals that they wanted to find common ground on Iraq and dispel the bitterness left by differences over military action against it.
One option, some Council diplomats suggested, would be to pass a resolution suspending sanctions, but delay a decision to lift them. It was unclear what effect that would have on the legal status of the oil-for-food program, which tightly regulates the use of Iraqi oil revenues.
Before leaving for the speech here and then a long holiday weekend at his ranch in Crawford, Tex., Mr. Bush lowered the domestic terrorism alert level to yellow from orange, where it had been for a month.
He also signed the $79 billion spending bill passed by Congress to pay for the war and the initial reconstruction costs in Iraq. The war has cost more than $20 billion so far, and Pentagon officials are projecting costs of $2 billion a month through Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year, a senior Defense Department official said today. Those figures do not include the costs of postwar reconstruction.
Dov Zakheim, the Defense Department comptroller, said military operations had cost more than $10 billion, personnel and personnel support costs had approached $7 billion, and munitions and equipment costs had topped $3 billion.
The 1991 Persian Gulf war cost about $60 billion, Pentagon officials said, but most of that was repaid by Kuwait, neighboring Persian Gulf states and other allies.
Appearing before an audience of about 1,000 Boeing workers in a fighter-jet assembly plant here, Mr. Bush said the successes of the United States military "begin right here on the factory floors," a crowd-pleasing line that he used to turn the subject to his tax cut plan. He called early this year for a tax cut worth $726 billion over the next decade, but opposition from Democrats and some Republicans in Congress has left him with a difficult fight to win a tax cut of more than $350 billion.
"I have sent to the Congress a jobs and growth package that will reduce the burden on our taxpayers, that will give you more of your money in your pocket so you get to decide how to save or invest and spend," the president said. "In order for all Americans who are looking for work to find work, the Congress must pass this jobs package as soon as they come back from their recess."
Asked whether the move to lift the sanctions was a signal that the war was over, Mr. McClellan said the military had made "tremendous progress, but there are still objectives that we are working to accomplish."
These include finding any chemical or biological weapons developed under Mr. Hussein. Mr. Bush only glancingly mentioned the banned weapons, which were his primary rationale for going to war with Iraq. Instead, he focused on freeing Iraqis from a government that he said had imprisoned children, tortured dissidents and built palaces for its leaders instead of hospitals for its citizens.
"In Iraq, the world is witnessing something dramatic and something important," he said. "We're seeing the deep and universal desire of men and women to live in freedom."
He did not mention Syria today, after it figured prominently in administration addresses in the last few days, but in Washington, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said he would probably travel to Damascus at some point to "have very candid and straightforward discussions" with President Bashar al-Assad.
After having redefined American foreign policy after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks to focus on pre-empting threats to the United States, Mr. Bush today gave equal weight to ending repression.
"American interests and American founding beliefs lead in the same direction," he said. "We stand for human liberty."
Mr. Bush pointed to the meeting on Tuesday in Ur, Iraq, of leaders from across Iraq as evidence of progress in bringing stability to the country. "They even had some protesters outside the meeting, a sure sign of freedom," he said with a smile.
Mr. Bush's appearance here reflected a White House effort to put the president's wartime popularity to use on behalf of his domestic agenda, and his political standing heading into the 2004 campaign, without giving up his above-the-partisan-fray role as commander in chief.
He was flanked by two F/A-18F fighters, a warplane that flew strikes against Iraq, and he spent much of his address discussing the defeat of Iraq's military and the collapse of Mr. Hussein's government.
"By a combination of creative strategies and advanced technology, we are redefining war on our terms," Mr. Bush said. "Terrorists and tyrants have now been put on notice: they can no longer feel safe hiding behind innocent lives."
Mr. Bush paid tribute to the courage and skill of American and allied military personnel, and especially to those who were killed, saying "these are the men and women who our nation will honor forever."
But while Mr. Bush used the event to show his concern for the American economy, he also has to worry about economic stability in Iraq, which the White House hopes can be transformed into a model of democratic capitalism in the Middle East.
The sanctions are the basis for nearly all the United Nations' ties to Iraq -- its control of billions of dollars of oil revenue, its control of the goods and services purchased by the Iraqi government, and its distribution of food staples relied on by at least 60 percent of the Iraqi population.
The sanctions were imposed against the nation of Iraq, not against any particular government, so they may be lifted before a new government is created.
With sanctions gone, the United Nations would have no legal authority in Iraq, other than what the allied forces give it. The $2.9 billion now in an escrow account would no longer be under United Nations control, and oil sales and other imports and exports could proceed without United Nations supervision.
The resolutions can be abrogated by passing another resolution. But since they were imposed to disarm Mr. Hussein, revoking them means finding that Iraq is free of illegal weapons. The resolutions allow, but may not require, the Council to rely on the judgment of United Nations weapons inspectors. Hans Blix, a chief weapons inspector, is to meet with the Council on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR/AN OVERVIEW: APRIL 16, 2003; 
Palatial War Room, Diminished Alert, Ruined Iraqi Economy

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the commander of allied forces in Iraq, met with his top officers inside one of President Saddam Hussein's palaces in Baghdad, marking a symbolic end to the war four weeks after it began. With the Mr. Hussein's government dismantled, President Bush asked the United Nations to lift economic sanctions on Iraq. At home, a decrease in the level of credible threats led the government to lower the terrorism alert by one level, to yellow. 
 LIFTING SANCTIONS -- President Bush flew to St. Louis, where he told 1,000 workers at a Boeing jet fighter assembly plant that Mr. Hussein's government was finished and that it was time for the United Nations to lift economic sanctions on Iraq. Removing the sanctions would make it easier for Iraq to sell its oil, which the administration believes will revive the nation's battered economy and help pave the way for the creation of a democratic government. 
 The sanctions prohibit Iraq from selling any oil except through the oil-for-food program run by the United Nations. 
But lifting the sanctions would require going back to the United Nations Security Council and facing the possibility of another diplomatic clash with France, Germany and Russia over Iraq. 
LOWERED THREAT -- Citing intelligence reports indicating that the threat of terrorist attacks had diminished, the Homeland Security Department lowered the terrorism alert level today to yellow, which puts it in the middle of the five-color warning code. The level had been set at orange, or "high risk," since March 17, the day President Bush issued a 48-hour ultimatum to Mr. Hussein to leave Iraq. New York City officials said the city would remain on orange alert.
ACTION IN IRAQ -- In a symbolic show of power, General Franks met with his top officers in the Abu Ghraib palace, one of Mr. Hussein's sumptuous retreats on the outskirts of Baghdad. General Franks said that the major combat phase of war had ended, but that troops were still rooting out guerrillas who might attack allied forces. 
Though the military mission in Iraq has changed substantially, it is likely to continue for some time, and the cost of the war will continue to rise. So far, Pentagon officials estimate that the United States has spent more than $20 billion, with costs continuing to rise by about $2 billion a month. 
While General Franks was on the outskirts of Baghdad, there was an uneasy calm in the capital's center. More stores reopened, and a Marine patrol caught Iraqi bank robbers. But looters calmly plundered a sugar warehouse and fearful residents stood guard outside their homes. American troops took up positions outside the National Museum, allowing curators to assess what had been lost to looters. The good news was that some pieces locked in the basement for safekeeping might still be there, though it will take months to tally the losses. 
In northern Iraq, a second day of clashes between marines and local townspeople left four Iraqis dead and 10 injured. American officers and local Iraqis disagreed about who fired first. 
SEEKING THE DISAPPEARED -- Every day, scores of people in Baghdad crowd around the old state security complex, which is now guarded by American troops. They shout out the names of relatives and the year they disappeared, begging for some scrap of information in the government's files about where they were taken and how they might be found. It is a quest repeated all over Iraq as the realization sinks in that Mr. Hussein's government has truly dissolved. But the records in Baghdad, as well as in towns and villages, contain only the long list of those who disappeared, and the Iraqis whose willingness to inform on them led to their disappearance. 
COLLAPSING ECONOMY -- The collapse of the huge government agencies that ran Iraq's oil industry and directed almost every aspect of Iraq's output has left the country's economy a shambles. The oil fields that provided most of the government's revenues are shut down and are likely to remain that way for weeks because the people who ran them have fled. Banks have been looted and the few businesses that have reopened operate on a cash-only basis. The United States has decided to fly in American currency to pay workers and jump-start the economy. 
IRANIANS IN IRAQ -- Military commanders revealed that American forces had attacked the bases of an Iranian opposition group that has been based in Iraq for more than a decade. The group, the Mujahedeen Khalq, has thousands of troops backed by tanks and artillery and is considered one of the best-armed opposition groups anywhere. Senior administration officials said the group had been attacked because it served as an extension of the Iraqi military and was used as a de facto security force for the former Iraqi government. But the attacks angered members of Congress from both parties who saw the group as an effective source of pressure against Iran's government. ANTHONY DePALMA

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "MATTHEW BARNEY: THE CREMASTER CYCLE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through June 11). The most anticipated show by any American artist to emerge in a decade or more. "Cremaster," Mr. Barney's nine-year, five-film project, here presented whole for the first time, is an inspired benchmark of ambition, scope and forthright provocation for art in the new century. I recall Elizabeth Murray's describing how Philip Guston's crazy late works gave her heart to do her own mature paintings. Mr. Barney has brought to the art world a new freedom to explore narrative. He has introduced a new repertory of materials, gooey, strange, malleable and synthetic, which nobody thought of as germane before. Never mind that the films and many (not all) of his related sculptures, installations and photographs are very beautiful. The show, an installation itself, brings them together. The earliest "Cremaster" sculptures are film props, cobbled into installations that don't jell. But the latest are better: twin steel towers framed in plastic, a suite of abstract sculptures derived from automobile chassis. Vaseline and plastic combine with cement and steel -- pink and gray, rough and smooth, hard and soft -- the materials sustaining a narrative of formal eloquence. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $15; $10 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "MONTIEN BOONMA: THE TEMPLE OF THE MIND," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 517-2742 (through May 11). The art of the Thai artist Montien Boonma (1953-2000) combines many influences, from Southeast Asian Buddhism to Arte Povera and Joseph Beuys. But his art, by turns witty and somber, is not primarily about hybrid identities; it is about how to forge a life of psychic balance in an unbalanced and unbalancing world. In part he did so through the use of repeated, resonant symbols: the monk's alms bowl, the temple bell. He also turned art into an embracing sensual experience by infusing his installations with healing fragrances. There's nobody like him and nothing in town like this modestly scaled survey show. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

* "EGYPT REBORN: ART FOR ETERNITY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (permanent installation). The second and final phase in the museum's reinstallation of its world-renowned holdings of ancient Egyptian art, this dazzling display rounds up more than 600 objects -- from king-and-queen-size monuments to tiny rings and amulets -- from the predynastic period to the 18th Dynasty. Together with the first phase, which opened in 1993 and covers later Egyptian art, visitors will now be able to trace the entire course of this brilliant and complex civilization from its beginnings to its absorption by the Roman Empire in 30 B.C. The heart of the new installation is an introductory gallery that provides a wonderful summation, with a survey of sculptural styles and displays of weapons, pottery, cosmetics, jewelry, furniture and funerary arts. The adjacent galleries are devoted to an extensive chronological survey. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

"FIRST STEPS: EMERGING ARTISTS FROM JAPAN," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084, (through June 16). In Japan, as everywhere else, new art is going in many directions at once, and this biennial juried show gives a sense of what some of those directions are. The 2003 edition for the most part avoids techno-pop painting and sculpture in favor of large-scale installations (a domestic interior made entirely of cookies) and videos (pacing zoo animals, sex-and-violence psychodramas). The most interesting entries take a measured, even somber approach to personal and cultural neurosis, and intimations of mortality recur. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2 for students and 62+ (Cotter).

* "MANET/VELAZQUEZ: THE FRENCH TASTE FOR SPANISH PAINTING," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through June 8). The Met has clearly called in every chip to make this show spectacular. The first rooms are a virtual survey of great Spanish painting of the 17th and 18th centuries; after that comes a virtual Manet retrospective, with some Degas and Courbet thrown in for good measure; then a virtual 19th-century American overview of the most gifted portraitists influenced by Spanish painting via Manet, Degas and Courbet: Eakins, Chase, Sargent and Whistler. The thesis of Spanish influence on French art is hardly new, but it is explored in such precise and fresh detail, discreetly, without pushing comparisons (in that respect it's not like "Matisse Picasso" at the Modern, notwithstanding the coincidental titled pairings) that you would have to be churlish not to leave edified and amazed. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "MATISSE PICASSO," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 4520 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through May 19). If you're thinking of skipping it because of the crowds, that's not a good enough excuse. This is one for the ages: an eye-educating, often revelatory parlor game, with the fate of modern art as the stakes. The premise is a little dubious -- the two of them competing as if in stately isolation from everything else going on in art -- but the results look great. Choosing a winner is the sport of the event and the inevitable outcome of pitting titans mano a mano. Matisse comes out looking consistently good. To grasp 20th-century art, Picasso once said, "You ought to see side by side everything Matisse and I were doing." He was right about that. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; to 9 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays. Admission: $20; $15.50, students and 65+; under 16 with an adult, free. Reserved tickets: Ticketmaster, (212) 307-5577; or toll free, (866) 879-6662, with Ticketmaster surcharges (Kimmelman).

"ELIE NADELMAN: SCULPTOR OF MODERN LIFE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through July20). Despite the clarion title, this exhibition is too monotonous, stiffly installed and short on drawings to do full justice to the erudite, polymorphous achievement of the Polish-born American sculptor Nadelman (1882-1946). Still, don't miss this opportunity to see his work in quantity, especially the streamlined wood figures from the 1920's and the small truculent plaster figurines, which were found in his studio after his death. Their suave economy, ineffable stillness, delicate gestures and seamless blend of historical and popular sources make them among the most complex, fully visual sculptures in Western art. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Roberta Smith).

* "ST. ADOLF-GIANT-CREATION: THE ART OF ADOLF WOLFLI," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through May 18). The distinction between insider and outsider art is all but nullified by this stunning show of the densely patterned drawings that Wolfli (1864-1930) made in the last 35 years of his life at Waldau, a mental asylum in Bern, Switzerland. Brought to order by vast architectonic structures that allow several forms of communication to speak at once yet remain distinct, these works are embedded with saints, devils, written texts, mathematical calculations, musical scores and geometric symbols. They treat the eye to a ride through a multicultural terrain bounded by Piranesi, biblical myth, illuminated manuscripts, Tantric mandalas and Swiss cuckoo clocks. And they attest to a vision as ancient as it is modern that verifies both Wolfli's careful observation of his surroundings and Jung's theory of the collective unconscious. Not to be missed. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $9; $5, students and 62+ (Smith).

* "CHRISTIAN SCHAD AND THE NEUE SACHLICHKEIT," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through June 9). Schad's career effectively lasted only 15 years, from around 1915 to 1930, and for just two or three of those years was he doing what deserves to be remembered now. Not much time. But just enough. Schad at his mordant best precisely captured an anxious culture affected by war and the threat of it: his bloodless portraits in Vienna and Berlin suggest deep unease and foreboding beneath porcelain surfaces. They are explicitly unemotional, even when they are frankly erotic, as they frequently are. His drawing, akin to some done by Dix and Grosz, shy away from the issues of class conflict that inflamed both of those other artists. To the end, Schad remained aloof. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "THOMAS STRUTH, 1977-2002," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through May 18). This midcareer retrospective is the right event for right now: serious, traditionbound, circumspect about the world. Mr. Struth operates from a chilly peak, where the air is thin. But what results are obsessively meticulous photographs, some of them enormous, like mural paintings. They are hypnotic, silent, slightly claustrophobic, brainy and gorgeous, qualities that can seem in lively tension with one another. Art is a means of "locating yourself in your time," Mr. Struth has said. Standing before his crowded museums and churches, we can become absorbed in the chaos of culture, sacred places made profane. In the jungle we acquiesce tothe spiritual pleasure of solitude. We may find ourselves in our time. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

* "THE WORLD OF BUDDHISM: SELECTIONS FROM THE MR. AND MRS. JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER 3RD COLLECTION," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 517-2742 (Through Oct. 19). Anyone familiar with the Rockefeller collection is already feeling blissed out by its return to public view. Everyone else will have the delight of a first-time encounter with embodiment of the Buddha in many forms, from an earthly stone figure carved in fifth-century India, to the celestial eighth-century bronze Buddha of the Future, probably made in northern Thailand, and now one of the great art sights of New York. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

Galleries: Uptown

"LUXURIOUS ESSENTIALS," Kaikodo, 164 East 64th Street, (212) 223-0121 (through April 28). This show is composed primarily of dozens of painted paper fans, representing a minor but flourishing medium in Chinese art. Such respected Ming and Qing period artists as Qiu Ying, Tang Yin, Wen Zhengming, Yun Shouping and Wang Yuanqi are represented in an art that is intimate, affordable and portable (Cotter).

* AGNES MARTIN, "Five Decades," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through April 26). We're used to expecting nuances rather than revolutions in Ms. Martin's art. But this 10-painting capsule survey gives a sense of how varied she can be and has been. It also proves how right she is in referring to herself as an Abstract Expressionist when everyone else has been calling her a Minimalist all these years. She's an engaged, passionate gestural painter with a classicist's emotional tact, a reticent Abstract Expressionist, the way Philip Guston was (Cotter).

* "WEAVING CHINA'S PAST: THE AMY S. CLAUGUE COLLECTION OF CHINESE TEXTILES," China Institute Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181 (through June 7). This gallery has a sterling record in presenting small, fine-tuned scholarly shows and this one, imported from the Phoenix Art Museum, exactly fits the description. With precious examples of silk brocades, tapestries and embroideries, including Buddhist ritual pieces, dating from the Jin to Qing dynasty, it gives a vivid sense of the material past in a powerful imperial culture (Cotter).

Galleries: 57th Street

VIJA CELMINS, Susan Sheehan, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 489-3331 (through May 31). Unlike the many painters and sculptors for whom printmaking is a more or less casual diversion, Ms. Celmins invests as much painstaking concentration in it as she does in her paintings. This selection from three decades includes misty etchings of spider webs, rippling waters made in lithography and wood engraving, mezzotinted starry night skies and lithographs of desert fields (Ken Johnson).

LYNN DAVIS, "China," Edwynn Houk, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 750-7070 (through May 3). A photographer known for her spectacular pictures of icebergs and Egyptian pyramids takes on China. Towering pagodas, a giant Buddha in a cave, ancient stairs partly submerged in sand, a beautiful minaret with a surface of intricate brickwork: these and other subjects are rendered in large, smooth black-and-white prints. Her relentless monumentalism can make you wonder whether Ms. Davis has a more intimate side (Johnson).

* BILL JENSEN, Mary Boone, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 752-2929 (through April 26). Once biomorphic-bristly, Mr. Jensen's compositions seem to have mellowed over the years into softer, less defined forms, his surfaces more grounds for colors than for shapes. The forms in these latest works are really markings, sprawly scrawls and calligraphic gestures that play splashily over contrasting or close-valued grounds, sometimes to gorgeous effect. The star of the show is "Untitled (Ocher and Red)," in which a more definite form, that of a red partial cross, occupies the top half of a glowing field brushed thinly enough to show glints of red beneath it. Harking back to medieval and Byzantine sources, it is a mini-cathedral (Glueck).

Galleries: Chelsea

FERNANDO BERMEJO, "Lights," Generous Miracles, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 352-2858 (through May 13). The light box is popular with photographers but rarely used to illuminate handmade pictures. Black-and-white paintings on paper mounted on light boxes by this Spanish artist suggest possibilities worth exploring. Lighted from behind, his small, brushy pastoral landscapes have a remarkable naturalistic luminosity and his surrealistic visions of trees growing from small boats have a dusky, melancholy poetry (Johnson).

ALEXANDER CALDER, Van de Weghe, 521 West 23rd Street, (212) 929-6633 (through May 23). This sampler includes a huge mobile that is too big for the gallery's main room and a bright red nonmoving abstraction of a winged lion. Best are the smaller mobiles, some hung from the ceiling, some balanced on low structures on the floor. These harmoniously choreographed, Miroesque constellations of sweeping lines and biomorphic shapes might be Platonic models for an ecology of mind and soul (Johnson).

LINDA FLEMING, "Parallel Universe," Linda Durham, 210 11th Avenue, at 24th Street, (212) 337-0025 (through May 8). Ms. Fleming, a California sculptor, develops complex patterns of layered and interwoven bands that are meant to have metaphysical implications. Whatever they mean, a large, intricate, fanlike structure of bolted-together rusted steel parts; a shadow of that sculpture made of puzzled-together black rubber pieces, lying flat on the floor; and a balsa-wood maquette under a glass bubble all have considerable terrestrial presence (Johnson).

VINCENT HAMEL, Howard Scott, 529 West 20th Street, (646) 486-7004 (through April 26). This Dutch artist makes slablike, single-color pictures in which the paint is applied in various ways -- brushed, combed, troweled, rubbed in -- and compels close study of the greasy, crusty or stony-smooth surfaces. Paradoxically, suave colors, ranging from cement gray to raspberry ice cream and powder puff blue, seem at once inextricably embodied and free-floating like a separate spiritual energy (Johnson).

* ELIZABETH MURRAY, PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, (212) 929-7000 (through April 26). A life lived the way Ms. Murray paints would be nirvana. Her recent works are airy constructions in low relief: ad hoc jigsaw puzzles of freewheeling shapes that lean, nuzzle and jostle one another to make unlikely harmonies of pungent color and abstract pattern. Compositional equilibrium, laboriously achieved but seemingly effortless, looks fleeting: there's always the sense that these improvisatory jumbles might break apart and out of their frames. Ms. Murray loves to paint. That's still the bottom line. It is useful to be reminded that there are still veterans like her, steeped in the medium, its difficulties and pleasures, who work so hard and make such beautiful art (Kimmelman).

HELEN TORR, "Works on Paper," JG Contemporary, 505 West 28th Street, (212) 564-7662 (through April 26). Torr,who was married to Arthur Dove, was a fine painter in her own right. The influence of Dove, Hartley, Burchfield and other American Modernists are evident in her work, but she had her own lively and intimate personality. It is stunning to learn that she never sold a painting in her lifetime, having subordinated her own career to her husband's. This engaging small show of drawings anticipates a retrospective of paintings scheduled for next month a JG Contemporary's uptown gallery (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

"EXTRA," Swiss Institute, 495 Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 925-2035 (through May 10). The curator Marc-Olivier Wahler asks, "How many extra layers can we graft onto reality before it collapses?" The 11 works here do little to answer the question, but they make an entertaining show. They include Bruno Peinado's giant brown Michelin man with an Afro; Wim Delvoye's tattooed pig; Peter Fischli and David Weiss's trompe-l'oeil studio props; Olivier Blanckart's Village People made of paper and tape; and adorable little robotic dogs programmed to fight by Stephane Sautour (Johnson).

HEIDE FASNACHT, Kent, 67 Prince Street, (212) 966-4500 (through May 3). A sculptor known for her interest in explosions offers a bursting Champagne bottle and splashy puddles, both in cast blue resin, and a sneeze represented by perforations in paper. A big colored pencil drawing of a window glass washed by rain, made with crisp gray and blue hatchmarks, reveals on close inspection an absorbing, crystalline topography; from a distance it resolves into a magically luminous illusion of watery translucency (Johnson).

GEORGE McNEIL, "FE = Form/Energy," Luise Ross, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161 (through May 3). McNeil, who died in 1995 an underrecognized member of the Abstract Expressionist generation, merged painterly abstraction and primitivistic symbolism with sensuous buoyancy. This small selection of works from four decades includes colorful, transcendentally exuberant landscapes and pictures of scary masklike faces embedded in luxuriantly scabrous surfaces (Johnson).

* "THE STAGE OF DRAWING: GESTURE AND ACT," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through May 31). It's not easy to assemble a truly engaging show from a vast collection of drawings like that owned by England's Tate. But this one really works. It views drawing as "an open-ended and exploratory activity," with exhibits ranging from a 295-foot line on a roll of wrapped paper to precise renderings of 19th-century hairdos. The mix of artists runs from J. M. W. Turner to Andy Warhol; the juxtapositions reveal affinities across centuries and cultures (Glueck).

Other Galleries

* TARA DONOVAN, Ace Gallery, 276 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 255-5599 (through May 15). Installation art proved long ago that lots of space combined with lots and lots of one material, arranged by stupefyingly simple labor-intensive methods, can work wonders. This solo debut provides supporting evidence that, if not too original, is amazingly succinct. The materials include transparent tape, Elmer's glue and pencils; the high point is something that looks, from afar, like a fairly large cloud or snow bank, but is not (Smith).

* "PEACE AND LINE," Ethan Cohen, 37 Walker Street, TriBeCa, (212) 625-1250, (through April 26). This is among the few New York dealers to consistently and persuasively present new art from China, often in group shows like this one, which includes calligraphy by the venerable painter C. C. Wang, now 97, done on pages of New York City telephone books; calligraphic paintings from 1986 by Wenda Gu; and experimental work by three young Chinese-based artists Pan Xinglei, Xing Fei and Zhou Hongxiang (Cotter).

ANN SPERRY, "30 Pieces/30 Years," Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion Museum, 1 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 824-2205 (through June 26); "My Piano," Kraushaar, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 307-5730 (through April 12). Since the early 1970's, Ms. Sperry has been bending, shaping and welding metal into metaphorically suggestive abstractions. The best works in her Hebrew Union retrospective have an industrial surrealism similar to, though not as surprising as, that of Donald Lipski. Her new assemblages at Kraushaar include cutup parts of her old piano, a beloved but defunct family heirloom (Johnson).

Last Chance

TONY BERLANT, "What You See Is Who You Are," Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 941-0012 (through tomorrow). A spectacular 60-foot mural representing the four seasons is the main attraction here. This visually ravishing, bucolic landscape was made by Mr. Berlant's signature technique: with zillions of finishing nails that remain visible on the surface, he attaches countless cutup pieces of preprinted and painted tin to wood panels, puzzling together a giant, vividly colorful picture that is as absorbing to study up close as from a distance. It would look great in a New York subway station (Johnson).

ROSS BLECKNER, Lehmann Maupin, 540 West 26th Street, (212) 255-2923 (through tomorrow). Seven works gives an abridged account Mr. Bleckner's exploration of optical and spiritual modes of perception over the last 16 years. In paintings from 1987 fields of blurry stripes punctuated by songbirds or nipples of bright yellow paint create a visually shimmering mysticism tempered by irony. A recent, unabashedly romantic painting contains a flock of smeary white birds fluttering in deep blue space like spirits of the lately departed (Johnson)

* JAMES ESBER, P.P.O.W., 555 West 25th Street, (212) 647-1044 (through tomorrow). Mr. Esber's cartoonish, bizarrely morphed and fragmented paintings made, apparently, by applying Play-Doh directly to the gallery wall (actually he makes them in the studio) are viscerally sensuous, vividly optical and delightfully creepy. Surprising pencil portraits of Abraham Lincoln, rendered as if by a mad engraver, are just as interesting. (Johnson)

"FLESH TONES: 100 YEARS OF THE NUDE," Robert Mann, 210 11th Avenue, at 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-7600 (through tomorrow). From Edward Steichen's blurry Pictorialism to Nan Goldin's diaristic intimism, this selection of photographs of people without clothes is wonderfully diverse. The Village Voice photography critic Vince Aletti selected the 79 images, and there may not be a bad one in the bunch. Neither is there anything so transgressive that parents need beware. Still, the nonchronological, salon-style installation cries out to be more illuminatingly sorted (Johnson).

EUNICE GOLDEN, Mitchell Algus, 511 West 25th Street, (212) 242-6242 (through tomorrow). Ms. Golden was among the early feminist artists of the 1960's and 1970's, and this small survey conveys, along with the flavor of a distinctive artistic personality, a sense of the political anger, antic humor, and conceptual experimentation that characterized the tangy first wave of the women's movement. The work includes photographs of performance pieces and body art, and half-abstract paintings that demonstrate how delicate, quiet and beautiful political art can be (Cotter).

* JOSIAH McELHENY, "Theories About Reflection," Brent Sikkema, 530A West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-2262 (through tomorrow). In this brainy, visually astounding show, objects and vessels of mirrored glass masterfully handblown by the artist are exhibited in mirrored cases; optical and historical illusions abound and the mind struggles to sort it all out. A result is a seamless fusion of Minimalist Puritanism with Neo-Geo's commentary on desire, display and commodification, which may be the best of both worlds (Smith).

ALEXIS ROCKMAN, Gorney Bravin and Lee, 534 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-8372 (through tomorrow). With the meticulous care of a popular science illustrator, Mr. Rockman continues to paint nature under stress. Each glossy, medium-size picture focuses on a particular ecosystem, with in most cases some kind of volcanic activity in the background. Deep sea creatures hover around glowing hyperthermal vents; insects flee a smoke-belching mountain; prairie animals seek subterranean shelter before a river of incandescent lava (Johnson).

GARY SCHNEIDER, Julie Saul, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 627-2410 (through tomorrow). Mr. Schneider's latest parsing of the photographic process involves extended exposures, people who lie down rather than sit for their portraits, an overhead camera and light from a single pinpoint source. Illuminated in a process that resembles drawing, or a gentle touching, the faces glimmer almost lividly beneath dustings of shadows. They could be coal miners getting off work or lost souls brought back from the dead and freshly made up (Smith).

BEVERLY SEMMES, "In the O," Leslie Tonkonow, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-8540 (through tomorrow). What can one say in the face of this largess, which has charged undertones of feminist meaning as well as overtones of female underwear? The entire gallery is clad in hundreds of yards of tangerine-colored chiffon that Niagaras from ceiling to floor to form pools of delicate ruffles. Quirky red pottery vessels handmade by Ms. Semmes, stand around like exclamation points. A huge ovoid bathmat is put together entirely of Band-Aids. Ms. Semmes proves herself once again to be an engaging fantasist as well as a clever manipulator of architectural space (Glueck).

EDWARD WESTON AND MARGRETHE MATHER, "A Passionate Collaboration," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-2456 (through tomorrow). Although Mather (1886-1952), a photographer of considerable accomplishment, was important to the early life and career of Weston (1886-1958), she vanished into obscurity as his reputation advanced. This show calls attention to her achievements alongside Weston's during their 12-year relationship, which ended in 1925. This well-chosen show does make a case for her influence on Weston (and vice versa), and she deserves recognition. Her career, however, was not sustained enough to be compared with his; her impact on one of the 20th century's most influential photographers seems today a relatively small one (Glueck).
