HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
A Mighty Global Power and Its Heir Apparent

BYLINE:  By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:
EMPIRE
The Rise and Demise of the British World Order and the Lessons for Global Power
By Niall Ferguson
392 pages. Illustrated. Basic Books. $35.
 In August 2001, a month before the terrorist attacks of 9/11, a study conducted for Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's office was issued on "Strategies for Maintaining U.S. Predominance." In a section titled "Lessons of History," which used the British, Roman, Chinese and Ottoman Empires as case studies, the report asked, "What does history suggest about the maintenance or failure of powers to hold similar positions of dominance?" 
 Curiously enough, the study's participants did not include the British historian Niall Ferguson, the author of "Empire: The Rise and Demise of the British World Order and the Lessons for Global Power," a new book (first published in England, as a companion volume to a television series) that lays out a history of the British empire's rise and fall, draws analogies between the British Empire and America's current role in the world, and often echoes the Bush administration's most hawkish pronouncements about the need to promote democracy abroad.
The obvious lesson the United States can draw from the British Empire, Mr. Ferguson writes, is "that the most successful economy in the world -- as Britain was for most of the 18th and 19th centuries -- can do a very great deal to impose its preferred values on less technologically advanced societies." He adds that no one should pretend that "at least in fiscal terms, the cost of expanding the American Empire, even if it were to mean a great many small wars like the one in Afghanistan, would be prohibitive." 
"Empire," it quickly becomes clear, is history with an agenda and a point of view -- a book that, in its gung-ho defense of empire, is as devoid of measured objectivity as many recent, politically correct histories have been on the other side of the political spectrum. Mr. Ferguson -- a professor of financial history at New York University, a senior research fellow at Jesus College, Oxford, and the author of earlier books including "The Pity of War" and "Paper and Iron" -- is a wonderfully fluent writer, weaving telling details and vivid anecdotes seamlessly into his narrative. And yet he puts all this fine writing at the service of a decidedly dogmatic thesis, consistently trying to rationalize the injustices committed in the building of Britain's empire while accentuating what he sees as its positive contributions.
Mr. Ferguson contends that the British Empire "pioneered free trade, free capital movements and, with the abolition of slavery, free labor." He hails its investment of "immense sums in developing a global network of modern communications," its maintenance of "a global peace unmatched before or since," and its imposition of "Western norms of law, order and governance around the world." To dismiss all this as "gentlemanly capitalism," he goes on, "risks underselling the scale -- and modernity -- of the achievement in the sphere of economics; just as criticism of the 'ornamental' (meaning hierarchical) character of British rule overseas tends to overlook the signal virtues of what were remarkably nonvenal administrations."
In these pages Mr. Ferguson does acknowledge some of the terrible things that were committed in the course of Britain's empire-building: the acquisition and exploitation of slaves in the 18th century; the massacre of Aborigines in Australia; the grabbing of land in Africa at gun point; brutal put-downs of challenges to imperial authority in places like India, Jamaica and South Africa; and negligent responses to famines in India and Ireland. But again and again he tries to whitewash the dark side of empire. After citing some of the horrors committed against the Aborigines in Australia, he adds that "concern in Parliament about mistreatment of indigenous peoples led to the appointment of Aboriginal Protectors in New South Wales and Western Australia in 1838-39." Never mind that such efforts did not prevent further massacres from occurring: Mr. Ferguson insists that "the presence of a restraining authority, no matter how distant, was something that distinguished British colonies from independent settler republics."
One of Mr. Ferguson's favorite tactics is to compare British imperial behavior favorably to that of other empires; crimes against humanity, he implies, are all relative. He argues that Belgian rule in the Congo was harsher than British rule in other parts of Africa, and he argues that the difference between British and Japanese imperialism was the difference between "an empire that had some conception of human rights and one that regarded alien races as no better than swine."
For that matter, he regards the end of World War II as a vindication of the British Empire's existence: "In the end," he writes, "the British sacrificed her empire to stop the Germans, Japanese and Italians from keeping theirs. Did not that sacrifice alone expunge all the empire's other sins?" As he sees it, the collapse of the British Empire -- which took three centuries to build and just three decades to dismantle -- was not a consequence of national independence movements and dissatisfaction with colonialism, but the result of "the staggering cost of fighting" other, truly evil empires.
Some of the positive achievements Mr. Ferguson cites as a legacy of the British Empire -- including the exportation of liberal capitalism and parliamentary democracy -- uncannily echo aims articulated by proponents of the current war in Iraq and those eager to reconfigure contemporary politics in the Middle East. In fact, Mr. Ferguson draws a direct parallel between Prime Minister Tony Blair's talk about the need to "re-order this world around us" and the "Victorians' project to export their own 'civilization' to the world," pointing out that "the Victorians regarded overthrowing rogue regimes from Oudh to Abyssinia as an entirely legitimate part of the civilizing process."
Mr. Ferguson pointedly adds, however, that it is the United States, not Britain, that is "capable of playing an imperial role" in the world today. He notes that America's own history -- freeing itself from the British Empire -- has made it wary of "formal rule over subject peoples" but exhorts it to face up to its imperial duties; he calls the United States "an empire in denial," an empire "that dare not speak its name."
Having traced in this volume how Britain gradually evolved from an informal to a formal empire (as trade and business propositions gave way to governance, as coastal bases and spheres of influence gave way to more codified rule, in the face of "real and perceived threats" to British commercial interests), Mr. Ferguson concludes this volume with the suggestion that a new era of globalization is occurring, with Americans having "taken our old role without yet facing the fact that an empire comes with it."
"The technology of overseas rule may have changed -- the Dreadnoughts may have given way to F-15's," he writes. "But like it or not, and deny it who will, empire is as much a reality today as it was throughout the 300 years when Britain ruled, and made, the modern world." It's sure to be a chilling assertion to both those in Washington eager to deny imperial ambitions and those in the Arab world suspicious of America's motives.

HEADLINE: Russia Approves Private Pipe To Carry Oil Bound for U.S. 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 17 

 BODY:
Dropping its previous opposition, the Russian government gave a green light today to plans for a privately owned oil pipeline to Murmansk that would carry oil bound for the United States. 
 Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov told his government to begin preparing a feasibility study for the $4.5 billion project, which also involves building a new loading terminal at Murmansk, a port on the Barents Sea formerly reserved largely for military use. The energy minister, Igor Yusufov, said flatly that the government would not oppose full private ownership of the pipeline, an aspect that officials had balked at just a few months ago. 
 "We simply showed that our growth estimates for the oil industry are well founded," said Leonid Fedun, vice president of Lukoil, one of the companies backing the project. "In 2007, the pipeline will be built, and Russia will play a geopolitical role in the oil market just like Saudi Arabia." 
Russia is already the world's second-largest oil exporter, after Saudi Arabia, and its output has grown steadily in recent years. But it has hit a ceiling in its capacity to export its oil. According to Mr. Fedun, 29 million barrels of oil have accumulated in storage around Russia since the beginning of 2003 because of bottlenecks in the existing system. 
With crude output expected to grow another 40 percent or more by 2012, Russia's oil companies say that new export routes are urgently needed. Five of the largest companies -- Lukoil, Yukos, Tyumen Oil, Surgut and Sibneft -- formed a consortium to build the Murmansk project. 
Oil companies here are also pushing another pipeline project, one that would stretch from Angarsk in Siberia to the Chinese city of Daqing. 
The government has said several times that it did not want to cede control of the pipeline network, and by extension the nation's export policy and its energy security, to the private sector. But at today's cabinet meeting, that position appeared to soften considerably. "The state does not intend to fully own all pipelines," Mr. Yusufov said at the meeting, according to Bloomberg News. Still, Mr. Yusufov is quoted as saying, the state "reserves the right to have a say in infrastructure." 
The planned Murmansk pipeline would carry 2.4 million barrels of oil a day. The new terminal would be the only one in Russia that could accommodate the giant oil tankers needed to make trans-Atlantic oil shipments economically feasible. 
The subject of Russia's oil interests in Iraq was also discussed at the cabinet meeting. According to Interfax, the Russian news agency, Mr. Yusufov said that Russian companies should be allowed to own the rights to Iraqi oil fields that they were promised before the war.
Mr. Fedun of Lukoil reiterated today that his company intended to sue any rival company that tried to lay claim to West Qurna-2, a huge Iraqi field that Lukoil signed a contract in 1997 to operate. 
"In the opinion of our American lawyers, our legal position is immaculate," he told reporters at his office in central Moscow.

HEADLINE: Jobless Figure Is Approaching High for Year 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17 

 BODY:
The number of workers filing claims for unemployment benefits increased last week to the second-highest level of the year as struggling companies handed out more pink slips.
 The Labor Department reported today that new applications for jobless benefits rose by a seasonally adjusted 30,000, to 442,000, for the workweek ended April 12. 
 That increase pushed claims to their highest point since March 29, when claims hit 443,000, the highest level of the year. 
For nine consecutive weeks, claims have been above 400,000, a level associated with a stagnant job market. Today's figures were weaker than economists expected.
"It's depressing," said Bill Cheney, chief economist at John Hancock Financial Services. "The economy is in a precarious state right now."
Businesses coping with lackluster profits and uneven demand from customers have been trying to hold down costs. Against that backdrop, companies have been reluctant to increase capital spending or hire more people, major forces restraining the economy's recovery.
Some of the increase in claims last week was attributed to layoffs in the automobile industry, a Labor Department analyst said.
Paul Taylor, chief economist at the National Automobile Dealers Association, said that some automakers were curbing production to work off inventories of unsold vehicles, which began to increase as demand slowed.
The more stable, four-week moving average of initial jobless claims also rose last week, by 3,500, to 424,750, the highest level in nearly a year.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, and his colleagues hope the economy will return to good health once the war in Iraq is over.
The Federal Reserve decided in March to hold the federal funds rate at 1.25 percent, a 41-year low, with the hope that it would spur more spending and investment and help the economy. The funds rate is the Fed's main lever for influencing economic activity.

HEADLINE: A Reticent China Undercuts Its Milder New Image 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, April 17 

 BODY:
China's restrictions on information about a highly infectious respiratory illness has undermined five years of diplomacy intended to alter its image as a prickly regional power and to improve relations with neighboring countries, Asian politicians and analysts say.
 Beijing's secretiveness for much of the last several weeks about severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, contrasts sharply with the openness of its neighbors, even one-party states like Singapore. It also reflects the emphasis China puts on overall social stability above individuals' well-being, many argue. 
 The reaction to China's handling of SARS has been pronounced in Thailand, Malaysia, Taiwan and Hong Kong as well as in Singapore. Politicians, editorial writers and health experts have criticized the Chinese suppression of bad news, and apparent dissembling about SARS-related statistics, as a big step backward that undercuts its influence. 
"China's political structure has not kept pace with its rapid emergence on the world's stage," said Kobsak Chutikul, a former Thai foreign ministry official who now serves on the foreign affairs committee in Parliament. "It did not matter so much when China was still isolated. But its policies have a far-reaching impact today."
China, of course, has been regarded with suspicion by those in Asia and the West who view the Communist leadership as hostile to democratic values.
Yet the broader trend had been toward improved relations with Asian neighbors and the United States. China offered robust support to the Bush administration after the September 2001 terrorist attacks, administration officials note. And while the authorities in Beijing opposed the war in Iraq, they did so with far less vigor than France, Germany or Russia. Just this week, Beijing offered a compromise to break a months-long standoff between the United States and North Korea over the North's nuclear weapons program, allowing negotiations to proceed.
On the sensitive matter of Taiwan, which China regards as part of its sovereign territory, it has abandoned a campaign of military intimidation that it pursued in the mid-1990's. Instead, it has promoted faster economic integration between Taiwan and the mainland.
Regionally, China's stature had been rising in a kind of tandem with Japan's increasing economic troubles. After many Asian nations were forced to devalue their currencies and renegotiate bank loans during the Asian financial crisis of 1997-98, China limited the damage by holding the line on its own currency.
This year, China pushed a broad regional trade initiative and offered concessions that would help poorer countries sell it agricultural goods. It also agreed to discuss its sweeping sovereignty claims over islands in the South China Sea in international forums, dropping demands for one-on-one talks with other claimants.
All that was part of an image makeover intended to cast China as a sophisticated, responsible big power ahead of the Olympics in 2008 and the World Expo in 2010, where it is the host country. By many accounts, this process was working -- until the handling of the SARS epidemic persuaded some people that China's cosmetic changes did nothing to address deeper flaws in its political system. "There were so many gestures and positive moves that relations became really cozy," said Lai Hongyi, a research fellow in East Asian Studies at the National University of Singapore. "But when it came to SARS, people could see that the Chinese system had not really changed."
Tensions between China and its smaller neighbors have been growing since February, when SARS spread from Guangdong Province in the south to nearby Hong Kong and much of Asia. China remained silent from the time of the first reported outbreaks in mid-November until late March, when it began revealing epidemiological records under World Health Organization pressure.
This week, President Hu Jintao and Prime Minister Wen Jiabao pledged to tackle the disease, which they now term "grave." But China has continued to insist that the country is safe and that it should not be treated as the source of SARS.
To retaliate against restrictions on mainland travelers, Beijing ordered travel agents to stop arranging group tours to Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand until they ceased their special scrutiny of Chinese visitors. That has worsened a sharp drop in tourism.
Wariness of China has grown even more pronounced in Hong Kong, which has been under Chinese administration since the end of British rule in 1997. 
SARS caught Hong Kong unaware in February, even though the disease had already infected hundreds in Guangdong. While Hong Kong's chief executive serves at the pleasure of Beijing, the territory apparently received no special access to China's medical records. As a result, Hong Kong media coverage of China has become pointed and popular outrage is growing, some analysts say.
"The politically correct thing the past few years has been to go soft on China," said Wu Guoguang, a former top-level government official in Beijing and now a professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong. "But everyone now sees clearly that China will not think twice about Hong Kong when political stability is at stake."
The epidemic also seems likely to strain China's relations with Taiwan. Just this week, Chen Shui-bian, Taiwan's president, used the sort of language that often provokes Beijing's wrath when he told a visiting Japanese official that Taiwan is "an independent sovereign state" that is "not subordinate to the P.R.C."
Taiwan officials have used SARS as an opportunity to push for observer status at the World Health Organization, which they see as a wedge toward winning greater diplomatic recognition of de facto independent status. China has long used its influence to exclude Taiwan from the W.H.O., a United Nations specialized agency, insisting that it will forward relevant information to Taiwan. But Taiwan officials now say that they cannot depend on Beijing's help in such crises and must have the same timely medical data that member nations receive.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Job-Search Web Site To Seek New Agency

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
Monster, the job-search Web site operated by TMP Worldwide, said unexpectedly yesterday that it had parted ways with Arnold Worldwide in Boston, which had handled its United States account since September 2000.
 Although billings were not disclosed, spending on the account has declined since the dot-com heyday as Monster, formerly Monster.com, spent $29.5 million to advertise last year in major media, according to the CMR division of Taylor Nelson Sofres, down 49.8 percent from $58.8 million in 2000. 
 Jeff Taylor, the chairman at Monster, in Maynard, Mass., said the company would probably conduct a search in the summer for an agency to succeed Arnold. 
Arnold described the decision as a mutual parting related to "changes in the marketplace," an allusion to the reduced spending by Monster. Arnold is part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Rise Despite Lackluster Economic Reports

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wall Street pushed higher yesterday as investors hoped the economy would improve despite a murky corporate outlook and a disappointing jobs report.
 The trading day was shortened ahead of Good Friday, when the market will be closed. 
 Volume yesterday was moderate and somewhat choppy, but a regional manufacturing report helped give shares a lift. 
"The bulls in particular are looking for concrete signs of improvement in earnings, but we're seeing an aimless drift along the bottom," said Keith Keenan, vice president for institutional trading at Wall Street Access, a New York-based firm.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 80.04 points, or about 1 percent, at 8,337.65, after having declined nearly 145 points on Wednesday. Earlier in the day, blue-chip stocks were down as much as 22 points.
The broader market also advanced. The Nasdaq composite index rose 30.78 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,425.50. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 13.67 points, or about 1.6 percent, to 893.58.
For the week, the three main gauges finished higher, with the Dow gaining 1.6 percent, the Nasdaq rising 4.9 percent and the S. & P. 500 advancing 2.9 percent.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that new applications for unemployment benefits rose last week by a seasonally adjusted 30,000, to 442,000. It was the second-highest level of this year and the latest indicator of the difficulties workers face in the sluggish economy.
But the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's April survey of business conditions came in at minus 8.8, compared with a minus 8.0 for March. The better-than-expected reading for April apparently offered investors some hope that the outlook might improve.
Trading has been uneven in recent days as investors look past the war in Iraq to corporate profits and the economy. Analysts say investors have been generally satisfied with first-quarter earnings, although the outlook for the rest of the year remains uncertain.
Nokia, the Finnish cellphone maker, rose $1, or 6.6 percent, to $16.18 after it reported first-quarter profits that beat Wall Street's estimates.
Broadcom, the chip maker, surged $2.55, or 18 percent, to $16.60 on the Nasdaq after it posted strong quarterly earnings and forecast double-digit sales growth in the second quarter.
And AMR rose 77 cents, or 18 percent, to $5 on investor relief after flight attendants at its American Airlines unit accepted $340 million in labor concessions, which may help the company avoid bankruptcy-court protection.
But AMR shares fell 18 cents, to $4.82, in after-hours trading on news that the union representing American Airlines' mechanics and ground workers said it might not sign off on a concession vote, even if that would mean bankruptcy for the airline, the world's largest.
Decliners included Sun Microsystems, the chip maker, which fell 8 cents, to $3.24, on Nasdaq, after it reported fiscal third-quarter revenue that fell below analysts' estimates.
United Technologies, which makes jet engines, dropped $2.27, to $60, after the company reported higher profits, but issued a warning on its second-quarter results.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

Treasury Prices Mixed
(By The Associated Press)
Some bond prices fell yesterday after a report suggested that the economy might be doing better than some investors expected.
The benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell 5/32, to a price of 99 10/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 3.96 percent from 3.94 percent on Wednesday. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 10/32, to 107 11/32. Its yield dipped to 4.89 percent from 4.91 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Flow of Money to Stock Funds Is Most in aYear 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
With war winding down, investors have poured more money into stock mutual funds than they have in a year, according to the latest weekly data.
 Stock mutual funds had a net inflow of $5.7 billion, with much of it devoted to the riskiest investments, in the week ended Wednesday. According to AMGData Services, $1 billion went into aggressive growth funds and $472 million into technology funds. The technology inflow caught a wave of good performance. The Nasdaq composite index, which is loaded with technology stocks, has risen 4.9 percent since Friday. 
 In all, domestic equity funds attracted $4 billion, with $1.1 billion of net inflows into large-company growth funds.
Individual investors also put $1.7 billion into foreign stocks. So far this year, $3.1 billion has flowed into international stock funds.
Part of the attraction of foreign stocks has been an expectation that the dollar will weaken against foreign currencies and improve Americans' returns abroad. Though the dollar has weakened, major foreign stock markets are lagging behind the United States in dollar terms. According to Morgan Stanley Capital International's broad stock indexes, world stock markets outside the United States are down 2.1 percent this year, while the American market is up 1.8 percent.
This underperformance may now be showing up in investors' preferences, as domestic stock funds attract more inflows.
The net inflow into stock funds of all types was the biggest since $7.9 billion in the week ended April 17, 2002. Still, there has been a net outflow for the year, of $49 million.
William E. Rhodes, chief investment strategist at Rhodes Analytics in Boston, was not surprised by the inflow into stock mutual funds, but he is worried that the market faces another downdraft in the near term.
Investors, he said, may be putting money back into stocks because they believe that "the war is over and everything is hunky-dory like it was in 1991." But, he said, the market, economic and geopolitical environments are different, making a stock rally like that in 1991 less likely.
As investors favored stock funds, the weekly flow of new cash into bond funds dropped to $856 million in the latest period, from an average of $2.6 billion weekly for the last four weeks. Even there, investors were willing to take on risk, as $555 million of the week's total went into funds that invest in high-yield, or junk, bonds.
High-yield bonds have done well this year. The total return of a broad index of high-yield bonds is 10.3 percent for the year through yesterday, compared with 2.9 percent for investment-grade corporate bonds and 0.6 percent for Treasury securities, according to Merrill Lynch.

PERSON: J. Paul Getty Jr. 

HEADLINE: J. Paul Getty Jr., Philanthropist, Dies at 70 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
J. Paul Getty Jr., the remote American-born heir to an oil fortune who made Britain his home and beneficiary, died yesterday in London. He was 70.
 Mr. Getty was admitted to the private London Clinic on Monday and was being treated for a recurrent chest infection, the Associated Press reported. 
 Often in the public eye as a hedonistic young man, then long out of view as an older and retiring benefactor, Mr. Getty inherited the riches that flowed from his father's oil business. He came to be highly regarded in his adopted country later in life -- he was knighted as Sir Paul -- after a raucous period of drug use that became grist for gossip columns. 
Since establishing a home in Britain 25 years ago, his often quiet philanthropy eventually eclipsed his notoriety. He donated more than $200 million to numerous causes, charities and institutions, including the National Gallery in London.
His donations could be small and anonymous or large enough to surprise the art world. He could spend huge amounts to keep gems of Britain's patrimony from foreign buyers, or make thoughtful, modest donations that provided a concert artist with a grand piano or saved a seal family marooned in a storm.
His philanthropy could be quirky, too, and aimed at contentious causes. When a bitterly fought miners' strike battered the British economy in the mid-1980, he subsidized dissident miners who refused to join the strike.
He seldom spoke in public, but pronounced himself "privileged to be the heir to huge wealth." He said he regarded himself "as custodian of that money for the benefit of people who need it more than I do."
His adoptive country rewarded his charity with an honorary knighthood in 1986. But because he was not a British subject, people mindful of such subtleties could not call him Sir Paul. He rectified that situation in 1998 by changing his nationality.
John Paul Getty Jr. was born on Sept. 7, 1932, the third of five sons of J. Paul Getty. His father, Jean Paul, known as Oklahoma Crude, made a fortune in the oil fields, building on the business his father started.
J. Paul Getty Jr. spent time at the University of San Francisco and in the United States Army before being posted to Rome as manager of Getty Oil Italia in 1959. Although he worked there until 1970, he did not take it seriously, telling his father that he had little regard for the business.
In Rome he fell into a life of drugs and partying. In 1966 he was divorced from his first wife, Gail Harris, whom he had married in 1956. They had two daughters and two sons. (She later sued him, charging that he failed to pay into the trust fund for their children.)
The year of his divorce he married his second wife (and mother of his third son), Talitha Pol, a Dutch-born model and film actress. Living estranged from him, she died accidentally of a heroin overdose in Rome in 1971.
Her death signaled a new kind of life for Mr. Getty. He moved to London in 1972 and honed an interest in art and philanthropy, living reclusively for years in a well-guarded mansion along the Thames. He was married a third time, in 1994, to Victoria Holdsworth, the daughter of a Royal Army commander. Mr. Getty credited her with being a steadying influence.
Much of his wealth derived from a family trust created with the sale of Getty Oil to Texaco in 1984 -- most of it beyond his control, but estimated to be worth as much as $2 billion. Having fallen out with his father, he inherited little directly from the paternal fortune.
When he died in Britain in 1976, the elder J. Paul Getty was considered the world's richest man, with stakes in as many as 200 companies and as much as $4 billion to his name. He, too, had spent his last 25 years as an expatriate in Britain, shuttered in a 16th-century mansion.
Mr. Getty Sr. endowed the J. Paul Getty Museum, a Roman-style villa built on a hill in Malibu, in Southern California. One of the world's richest museums, it houses art treasures from throughout the world.
The younger Mr. Getty donated well over $50 million to the National Gallery in 1985. It was that museum's largest such bequest since its founding in 1824. He also gave millions to the British Film Institute.
His family and its wealth were in the news for months in 1973 with the abduction of his son J. Paul 3rd, a 17-year-old called the golden hippie by the Roman scandal press because of his reddish-blond hair. The kidnapers demanded $3.4 million.
Speculation abounded; the grandfather refused to pay, fearing that his other 18 grandchildren might become targets; and various sums were mentioned and haggled over until the Calabrian kidnapers mailed an ear severed from the boy. (Years after his release, in 1981, the son suffered a stroke from an overdose that left him severely impaired.)
Mr. Getty is survived by his wife and his children: John Paul 3rd, Mark, Ariadne, Aileen and Tara.
Regally invested with a knighthood at Buckingham Palace in 1998, he received full honors. "When I heard the national anthem played, I felt very proud to be British -- it's my national anthem now," he said after that.

HEADLINE: The Renaissance of White Plains; 
A Wallflower of a City Becomes the Belle of the Ball

BYLINE:  By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, April 17 

 BODY:
During the 1990's, as cities everywhere seemed to prosper and expand, this unassuming city became the wallflower of Westchester. The office vacancy rate ballooned to 31 percent. The downtown turned ghostly at night. And not a single movie screen flickered across its nine square miles.
 But now, as the rest of the region worries through the current recession, White Plains is the belle of the ball and, appropriately, raising a toast to itself. Overnight and against the odds, it has become a boomtown. 
 A billion dollars' worth of construction is under way, including more than 1,600 rental apartments in and around the central business district. Fifteen movie screens, new restaurants and major retailers from Target to Fortunoff are in the works. And developers keep proposing more: a hotel, condominiums, even office space (now that the vacancy rate has dropped to a respectable 15 percent). 
How did White Plains, the archetypal "edge city" of the New York suburbs, suddenly become everybody's sweetheart? To many minds, the answer is Mayor Joseph Delfino. After taking office five years ago, he made it his mission to bring residential development to downtown, following the lead of Stamford, Conn.
He streamlined the notoriously complex, drawn-out process by which developers sought approval, and he broke the city's immutable 230-foot building-height barrier by allowing 350-foot high-rises downtown. He also courted builders and retailers with gusto, personally showing Louis Fortunoff a site recently vacated by Saks Fifth Avenue.
"Developers didn't feel comfortable and didn't feel welcomed," said Mr. Delfino, a native of White Plains, a Republican and a former county legislator. "Now the attitude is: Go to White Plains. They'll make things happen for you."
As one strolls through downtown, where cement mixers whirl and stacks of lumber are moved through the air, there is a sense that White Plains is undergoing a personality change. Many are eager for the downtown to hum with new life, but others look at the future high-rises and shudder.
"I feel overwhelmed by that height," said Louise Foley, a retired analyst for I.B.M. and a longtime resident, gazing up at the new building. "White Plains is no longer going to be a small town."
City officials insist that if developers had not been allowed to build higher, they would have taken their blueprints elsewhere. "The bottom line is, some people want this to be Mayberry, but you know, Andy Griffith died many years ago -- at least the character died," said George Gretsas, the city's executive officer.
Like many cities that dot the suburbs, White Plains has remained a vibrant place to live for its 53,000 residents, despite its bedraggled downtown. There are snug neighborhoods with well-kept houses, and quiet avenues with imposing residences.
Residents appreciate the relatively low taxes, a benefit of the many companies based here. Indeed, White Plains drew the first major corporate relocation from New York City, when General Foods moved its headquarters to Westchester Avenue in 1954.
Certainly, the city in the 1990's was not devoid of development. The Westchester mall opened in 1995, bringing a million square feet of retail space and upscale stores like Tiffany and Williams-Sonoma.
The same year that the mall opened, however, the heart of downtown stumbled when Macy's left the intersection of Main Street and Mamaroneck Avenue. The department store resurfaced a few blocks away, but the sprawling limestone structure that it had occupied sat empty for years, sapping energy from the retail corridor.
Vacancies spread, punctuated by $1 stores, and the site attracted more pigeon droppings than redevelopment plans. City officials were crestfallen when Tishman-Speyer abandoned its plan for a retail center and 21-screen Loews movie theater.
But two years ago, a developer with a long track record, Louis R. Cappelli, strode into town. He had just completed New Roc City in New Rochelle, a $190 million sports, entertainment, retail and hotel complex that helped turn around the downtown area with a huge dose of razzmatazz.
For White Plains, he was proposing a $320 million project, called City Center, on a seven-acre parcel that included the old Macy's site. On it he would erect twin 35-story towers with 300 rentals each; a half-million square feet of retail space; a 15-screen movie theater, and parking for 2,340 cars.
Mayor Delfino was ecstatic. But there were months of hand-wringing on the City Council over building heights. Until then the tallest structure in the city was 20 stories. Mr. Cappelli prevailed, and the project is scheduled to open in the fall. The city persuaded him to include a 450-seat community theater amid his retail lineup of Target, Circuit City, Barnes & Noble, Legal Sea Foods and others.
Mr. Cappelli credits the mayor with opening the doors to development. "Mayor Delfino and his staff listened to what it takes to make a development successful," Mr. Cappelli said. "You get an honest opinion out of them about where you stand right away."
The City Council is now considering the next phase of Mr. Cappelli's minicity -- a hotel-condominium tower at 221 Main Street, across from his City Center, and an adjacent office tower. Both would be 350 feet high. Mr. Cappelli says he prefers to build in a weak economy when financing is cheaper.
"My buildings are timed to come on line over the course of the next year when the war could be over and the stock market could go through the roof," he said. "We've already been in a low point for a while, and I'm making a bet that we're going to go up."
While it is clearly the most ambitious project, Mr. Cappelli's is not the only one in town.
Near the train station, workers are finishing two 21-story apartment buildings, called Bank Street Commons, with a total of 500 rental apartments. On the other side of town is Clayton Park, a 260-unit complex on Canfield Avenue that is nearly complete. At the south end of Mamaroneck Avenue, demolition has started for the Jefferson, a 285-unit apartment building.
Things are bubbling on the retail front, too. Fortunoff is moving into Westchester with a project that will include a 190,000-square-foot store and 72,000 square feet of retail space for lease on Bloomingdale Road. And residents now have a Stop & Shop superstore, which opened on Westchester Avenue in December.
"It's probably the most exciting time of all for White Plains, when you consider all that is going on simultaneously," said Frank Tomasulo, a senior vice president of CB Richard Ellis, a leading commercial real estate firm.
White Plains, he said, was wise to copy Stamford's strategy of putting apartments downtown. "The influx of housing created a real buzz that makes that a 24-hour city," Mr. Tomasulo said.
Diane Cisterna, a White Plains resident for 50 years and co-owner of Creation Plus, a hair salon in the shadow of the City Center project, describes White Plains after hours as a "ghost town." City Center, she feels, "is the best thing that could have happened."
But her employee, Vicky Driggs, a hair stylist who has lived here for 30 years, isn't so sure. "I don't like such big, big buildings," she said. "If they build more, it's going to look like New York City."
Such misgivings are a concern for the mayor's office. Already, the City Council seems to be taking a tougher approach to Mr. Cappelli's hotel and office proposals.
"The wind is finally at our backs and there's a handful of people who say, 'Oh no, now's the time to stop; bring everything to a halt and let's see where we are,' " Mr. Gretsas, the mayor's deputy, said. "The momentum has brought us to the point where we may be good, but you take that momentum to get to the finish line, which is greatness."

HEADLINE: When Freedom Leads to Anarchy 

BYLINE:  By David K. Shipler; David K. Shipler, a former New York Times reporter, won the Pulitzer Prize for "Arab and Jew: Wounded Spirits in a Promised Land."

DATELINE: CHEVY CHASE, Md. 

 BODY:
The Bush administration, ill prepared to curb the lawlessness that has swept Iraq, is reinforcing one of the world's most powerful antidemocratic forces: the fear of chaos. Even as looting subsides, vigilantism flourishes. Revenge killings are reported to have begun in Kirkuk, and Kurdish militiamen are said to be ousting Arabs from villages around the city.
 Unless the United States moves quickly to counter its mistakes, Iraqis are unlikely to trust their security to an open, pluralistic form of government. Public anxiety about disorder has been used to rationalize practically every police state, from left to right, from Moscow to Buenos Aires. Now, in part because of negligent planning in Washington, the notion is taking root in Baghdad that freedom means anarchy. 
 American ground commanders who said the war plan provided too few troops were right for the wrong reasons. There were enough soldiers during battle -- but not enough afterward. There was plenty of fire power from air and armor but not enough visible power in the streets to create an impression of American control. If trained military police units had been deployed, they and large numbers of regular soldiers could have been stationed strategically and obviously as a symbol of order until Iraqi police forces were reconstituted in sufficient numbers.
An image of American control may have been a mirage in the first days, but it would probably have deterred most of the looting. In the throes of an authoritarian system's collapse, citizens are governed by symbolism and illusion, hating their fallen oppressors yet abhorring the vacuum. That contradiction is an echo of the twin fears often experienced under dictatorship: the fear of the strong hand at the top and the fear of losing the stability that the leader provides.
In the Soviet era, ordinary Russians often spoke of anarchy lurking close to the surface. "Besporyadok," meaning "disorder," was the ubiquitous indictment used against nonconformist behavior and political irreverence. The yearning for order, which predated Communism and survived its demise, keeps alive nostalgic memories of Stalin and supports a system in Russia that is only semidemocratic, one in which immense power is still vested in the executive branch.
Russians did not have an easy transition from authoritarianism. The looting after the collapse of the Soviet Union was less frenzied than in Iraq, but it damaged civil society nonetheless. Soviet officials effectively stole factories and other "means of production," and the emerging "mafia" included former agents of the K.G.B. This has left the impression that democracy and free enterprise naturally lead to political chaos and economic exploitation -- precisely the theory espoused in Soviet textbooks.
Whether an upheaval is provoked externally (as in Iraq), internally (as in the Soviet Union) or by a combination (as in Eastern Europe), the immediate aftermath is a delicate and critical moment. Deeply ingrained images and apprehensions, reinforced though years of propaganda, surge to the surface, along with hatreds long suppressed by the police apparatus. It takes enormous effort to overcome these prejudices without simply replacing one authoritarian regime with another.
In the case of Yugoslavia, Tito sealed the fissures of a multiethnic and multireligious society under a Communist veneer. When that was stripped away, out came a scourge of "ethnic cleansing" of Bosnian and Kosovar Muslims by Orthodox Serbs. In Czechoslovakia, even the gentle Velvet Revolution opened space for the expression of stereotyping and animosity between Czechs and Slovaks, which finally split the country in two. Hungary experienced anti-Semitism, and Bulgaria indulged in hostility toward its Turkish residents. Now Iraq becomes a strong candidate for severe sectarian strife among Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds.
Washington should therefore take the current disorder more seriously than Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld has thus far. It is too late to erase the recent blunders -- but not too late to avoid committing more. Joint patrols by American troops and local police should be converted from ad hoc arrangements in Baghdad to a formal program throughout the country. Civilian police forces from abroad, including other Arab countries, could be invited to send help.
Ultimately, it matters less what Iraqis think of Americans than what Iraqis think of themselves -- and of their own ability to govern. When mobs loot not only government offices but also hospitals, museums and libraries, when they steal not just artifacts of state abuse but also artifacts from their ancient past, they steal from themselves the power of healing and their connection with history.
That sets them dangerously adrift in a region where the temptations of autocracy and fundamentalism may be irresistible. It is too late to save the National Museum of Iraq. Yet it is in the vital American interest that marines guard not only the defense and petroleum ministries but also the institutions that will nourish Iraq's civil society.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE TV WATCH; 
In Hoopla Over a P.O.W., A Mirror of U.S. Society

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
There have been many television magazine shows devoted to Pfc. Jessica Lynch, and several movie treatments are in the works, including an unauthorized NBC made-for-television movie.
 But what is striking about tonight's special presentation on A&E, "Saving Jessica Lynch," is how little it has to say about Jessica Lynch. Two weeks after her rescue, there are still few details about her capture or her treatment in captivity. Tonight's documentary reveals far more about American culture than it does about the celebrity under its lens. 
 The attack of Iraq lasted three weeks. Yet the constant, instant, live coverage of every aspect of combat, from mess halls in Kuwait to desert firefights, telescoped the experience into a time-release portrait of war. 
And nothing moves faster than television's power to create instant legends. At a discouraging moment two weeks into the campaign, Private Lynch provided the nation with a made-for-television catharsis, much the way the reappearance of the kidnapping victim Elizabeth Smart did last month.
Since the fighting largely ended, Ali, the little Iraqi boy who lost his parents and both arms to American bombs, has became a symbol of what Jon Lee Anderson, The New Yorker's correspondent in Baghdad, described yesterday on WNYC radio as "wounded Iraqi nationhood." On American television, where coverage focused on Ali's medical treatment and offers of financial assistance and adoption, the child also became a symbol of American generosity.
Private Lynch's as-yet-untold story instantly hardened into a Hollywood-style fable of heroism. But her youth, delicate good looks and blond hair also evoked older, more disturbing myths. In the hands of Saddam Hussein's troops, this fragile 19-year-old supply clerk who joined the military to get an education turned instantly into a Fay Wray struggling in the paws of King Kong.
Perhaps because of that subliminal imagery, the news media quickly seized an unconfirmed report by an anonymous source in an article in The Washington Post that portrayed Private Lynch, wounded but unbowed, fiercely firing her rifle at the Iraqi enemy. Tabloids and television quickly recast her as a teenage Rambo. But that more dashing scenario was not confirmed, and reporters and Pentagon officials quietly let it drop, switching their focus to the heroics of Mohammad, the Iraqi lawyer who led United States troops to her hospital bed.
Her rescue was daring and highly unusual: more typically, P.O.W.'s escape or are exchanged or are returned after a war is over. But it was Private Lynch's femininity that seemed to move even former P.O.W.'s to see her nine days in captivity as worse than their own ordeals. 
"I have to take my hat off to that young Jessica Lynch because she went through hell," a World War II veteran, John Cook, told an A&E interviewer. "A lot more hell than I did in my 34 months." 
Mr. Cook, captured at Bataan, was among 513 P.O.W.'s rescued from a Japanese prison camp in the Philippines by American Rangers in 1945. 
Even Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who spent five and a half years as a P.O.W. in Vietnam -- three of them in solitary confinement -- was undone by Private Lynch's suffering. "Her story is the story of the bravest Americans," Senator McCain told A&E.
Overreaction is an understandable response to the still-shocking sight of women being killed or captured in combat. It could also be a symptom of pain inflation, a wartime version of grade inflation in a culture that views its own suffering as commensurate with that of previous generations.
On television, the toppling of the Hussein statue in Baghdad is compared to the fall of the Berlin Wall. In poignant satellite interviews between soldiers and their families at home, two-month separations turn each relative waiting at Camp LeJeune, N.C., into Mrs. Miniver. Mr. Hussein is as evil as Hitler and Stalin (though his stature as a totalitarian monster dipped to second-rate bully when marines discovered palaces tattily decorated with cheesy pink synthetic sheets and vinyl floors instead of silk and marble.)
Not surprisingly, perhaps, Jessica Lynch became Audie Murphy. Yesterday, an Internet search of the Dow Jones online publications library turned up 3,888 mentions of her since her rescue on April 1. Gen. Tommy Franks received 2,729.
Yet some of the most affecting material in "Saving Private Lynch" is not about the would-be kindergarten teacher from Palestine, W.Va., but the two other women in her unit who were also captured.
Both Pfc. Lori Piestewa, an American Indian who was killed either during or after her capture, and the unit's cook, Shoshona Johnson, an African-American who was found with six other P.O.W.'s last Sunday, had left small children behind. The biographical material, as well as the testimony of their families and friends, proved richer than the scant details about Private Lynch.
"The documentary started out being just about her," Pete Simmons, a senior producer at ABC News Productions, which makes documentaries for cable networks, including A&E, said. "But the other two women were so compelling the show developed a life of its own."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Unions at American Airlines Raise Outcry Over Pensions
Union leaders at American Airlines denounced the company's disclosure on Tuesday that it had set up a trust fund to protect executives' pensions if the company went into bankruptcy court and that it planned to pay generous bonuses to several executives for remaining with the company until 2005.
 Union officials said they might not agree to the concessions their members had voted to give management, even if that meant pushing the airline to file for bankruptcy. Page C2. 

Delta Air Lines said that its first-quarter loss widened to $466 million as the war in Iraq reduced international travel. C2.

Oversight Board Picks Chief Auditor
The new board to oversee the accounting industry announced that Douglas R. Carmichael, an accounting professor at Baruch College in New York, would serve as its first chief auditor. Mr. Carmichael will be the principal adviser to the board on technical accounting issues, including auditing standards. C4.

Bechtel Gets Major Contract in Iraq
The Bush administration awarded the Bechtel Group the major contract to rebuild Iraq giving it a toehold in one of the most lucrative building programs in decades. A1.

Number of Jobless Claims Rises
The number of workers filing claims for unemployment benefits climbed to the second-highest level of the year. The Labor Department reported that new applications for jobless benefits rose by a seasonally adjusted 30,000, to 442,000, for the week ended April 12. C2.

Sears Profit Is Up, but Sales Dip
Sears, Roebuck improved its first-quarter profit by 75 percent over an off quarter a year ago, but it said weak sales are hampering its near-term outlook. C5.

Markets Higher Ahead of Holiday
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 80.04 points, or 1 percent, at 8,337.65. The Nasdaq composite index rose 30.78 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,425.50. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 13.67 points, or 1.6 percent, to 893.58. The financial markets will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. C5.

Despite the lackluster performance of the stock market over the last month, investors poured $5.7 billion into stock mutual funds in the last week, the largest weekly inflow in a year. C5.

Earnings Increase 13% at PepsiCo
PepsiCo reported a 13 percent increase in its first-quarter earnings and attributed the growth to strong sales at its Frito-Lay North America unit, cost savings from its merger with Quaker Oats and the sale of a pasta business. PepsiCo booked incremental growth in each of its major business areas. Overall worldwide sales of the company's products increased 3 percent. C2.

A Brazilian Airline Loses Its Chief
The management of Varig, Brazil's flagship airline, has been thrown into turmoil by the departure of its third chief executive in less than a year, endangering the government's efforts to spare the struggling airline from bankruptcy through a merger with its rival, TAM Linhas Aereas. World Business, Section W.

Russia Approves Oil Pipeline
Dropping its opposition, Russia approved plans for a privately owned oil pipeline to Murmansk that would carry oil bound for the United States. World Business, Section W.

Campaign for Diet Coke Reappears
Two decades ago, Pepsi-Cola peddled Diet Pepsi with a campaign that carried the theme "Now you see it, now you don't." These days, those words could be used to describe the status of advertising for a competitive brand, Diet Coke, which has appeared, disappeared and reappeared with bewildering irregularity as the account changed agencies three times in five years. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C3.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: DIPLOMACY; 
U.N. and European Union Consider the Future of Iraq

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER with FRANK BRUNI

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 17 

 BODY:
As the new debate began here today over how to lift sanctions against Iraq, the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, was in Greece, imploring European Union leaders to forge a shared position on the terms and timing of Iraq's political and economic reconstruction.
 The coming debates on lifting sanctions will be the most fraught since this winter's bitter dispute over the question of military action in Iraq. The talks are clearly seen by both Mr. Annan and leading Security Council members as a crucial opportunity to revive trust in the world body's ability to help maintain international peace and security. 
 Intertwined in the debate will be the larger question of the role the United Nations will play as the government of Iraq is reconstituted. European Union leaders released a statement today calling for a "central role" for the United Nations in Iraq's future, a position that could put them at odds with the United States. 
On Wednesday, President Bush called on the United Nations to lift the sanctions that were first imposed on Iraq in 1990 and that have been the basis of virtually all United Nations programs involving Iraq.
With sanctions gone, the United Nations' authority to oversee the sale of Iraqi oil, to buy and distribute food, to inspect for weapons of mass destruction and to safeguard the border with Kuwait would evaporate.
As one diplomatic observer at the United Nations sees it, the new round of resolutions on Iraq will involve a clear political calculus for Council members. The way countries position themselves, this person said, will depend on "whether they feel they are scoring political brownie points with the U.S. that can be used on other issues or losing the last leverage they've got on Iraq."
Beyond that loomed the larger issue of the relevance of the United Nations, its cohesion and its yet-to-be-determined role in the emergence of a new Iraqi government. Speaking of the Iraq war and its prelude, Mr. Annan said today: "No issue has so divided the world since the end of the Cold War. It is vital that we heal that division now. The world cannot afford a long period of recrimination."
Mr. Annan, who has been urged by some Council members to help bridge the divides on the Council, today suggested a set of four principles as the basis of future Council actions. Among them he listed "the right of the Iraqi people to freely determine their own system of government and political leadership, as well as to control their own natural resources." Any United Nationsrole in Iraq, "beyond the purely humanitarian," was a question for the Security Council, he said. 
Except for the Greek hosts, Mr. Annan was one of the most visible officials at the meetings, arriving on Tuesday before many heads of state, appearing frequently before television cameras and keeping up a grueling schedule of meetings.
At the United Nations today, the Mexican ambassador, Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, whose country is the Council president for the month, said that envoys here were in "intense dialogue" on the future of the oil-for-food program, the weapons inspections and the sanctions. All were striving for consensus, he said.
In Athens, the European leaders failed to fully endorse President Bush's call for the United Nations to lift economic sanctions against Iraq.
Getting Council agreement on broadly accepted principles is seen by some Council diplomats as a prerequisite for future negotiations on the knot of Iraq-related issues. 
There are complex practicalities involved. Unraveling the sanctions, United Nations diplomats suggest, will involve the kind of legal complexities that go with the court-supervised reorganization of a troubled corporation. Decisions must be made on how assets can be used or sold, which contracts will be honored, which creditors will be paid, and under what authority and structure the company will be reconstituted.
Most of the current Iraqi economy operates under United Nations supervision, through the oil-for-food program, which was created in 1995.
Another persistent question is whether Council diplomats will insist that United Nations weapons inspectors declare Iraq free of weapons of mass destruction before sanctions can be lifted.
Hans Blix, a chief weapons inspector, told reporters he could have an inspections team in Iraq within two weeks.
Russia and the United States have different stands on inspections. 
In Moscow today, the foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, said that while sanctions should be lifted, "for the Security Council to take this decision, we need to be certain whether Iraq has weapons of mass destruction or not." 
Speaking to reporters at the president's ranch in Crawford, Tex., Claire Buchan, a White House spokeswoman, suggested today that there would be no support for sending Dr. Blix's inspectors back to Iraq any time soon. 
Mr. Annan's remarks in Athens came at the end of two days of meetings by European heads of state, their largest gathering since the war began. It yielded both scenes of amity and hints of lingering discord.
On the one hand, there were remarks by both the German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, and the French president, Jacques Chirac, both ardent opponents of the war, that indicated a desire for international healing. 
But the British prime minister, Tony Blair, at odds with his French and German counterparts over the war in Iraq, kept a noticeably low profile during his time in Athens. He canceled a scheduled news conference on Wednesday evening and was not present for a so-called "family photo" of European leaders today.
The European Union statement on Iraq today made clear that before the union and the United Nations could help with reconstruction, the coalition forces that waged war there bore "the responsibility to ensure a secure environment."
Representatives from the 25 countries in the expanding union and from other European countries issued a declaration, separate from the statement about Iraq, that reaffirmed Europeans' "determination not to tolerate any new dividing lines."

HEADLINE: Once Just Threats, Cutbacks Sink In Among New Yorkers 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
For many New Yorkers, the budget blues have come on slowly, like a bad, unkickable cold that finally becomes a miserable sinus infection. A street on Staten Island looks a bit dirtier; an Upper West Side subway station seems to have a few more homeless people. 
 It is as if people are already starting to see their city crumble ever so slightly -- even when statistics defy their perceptions -- because they finally believe government when it says that it is out of money. The mayor's budget, which he released on Tuesday, portrays a city where firehouses would close, where teachers would lose their classroom assistants and where there would be far fewer places to take children come next summer. 
 Hearing about the privation on the horizon, many people seem to think it has already arrived, and they are starting to debate in earnest how the city's fiscal problem should be solved. 
"There were predictions of these things a year ago," said Lee Goldman, 75, who lives in Brooklyn Heights. "But it seems to have become stronger. I have a sense that there has been a decline in services, especially in safety. From what I hear, the public schools are terrible. I guess I need to listen more."
Wade Golden, who worked as a florist in the World Trade Center and has been unemployed since Sept. 11, may have an exaggerated view of the facts, but a not untypical sense of doom. "You're playing with people's lives right now," Mr. Golden said of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's latest budget plans. "By closing down the Fire Department, people are being affected," he said at the Fulton Mall in Brooklyn. "This is their lives."
News of the city's dire fiscal problems has not been secret. Since the day he took office, Mr. Bloomberg has warned about massive budget gaps, impending cuts, shared sacrifices. 
But back then, there was a governor running for re-election who skirted the budget story. Then there were whispers on Wall Street and in Washington that a recovery might be just around the corner. And the budget process was always confusing: onerous cuts would be proposed by the mayor, rejected by the City Council and sometimes patched up with "electricity savings" and other mysterious pots of money.
"They have been through this so many times," said Ted Kanabis, who had stopped in for lunch yesterday at the Stein Senior Center on East 24th Street, where he is a client and a part-time worker. "There was talk about cutting the senior centers from five days to four, and that was back in January that there was talk of that and people got upset." 
Now, however, there is an amplified debate between Albany and City Hall over how to get the city out of its financial distress. Falling tax revenue means that service cuts are a given. Pink slips have already gone out to scores of city workers, and no one talks anymore about an imminent economic recovery.
The news is no longer about what will be saved, but rather how deep the cuts will be. "This is the first time I can remember in a long time it's been so bad," said Brenda Hill, an outreach worker for a private nonprofit group. "This is scary. So many people are losing their jobs."
Simply put, the debate between Mayor Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki over a proposed $1.4 billion tax on commuters pits a mayor who wants to spare New York City residents some of the cost of city services against a governor who simply abhors taxes. 
But the disagreement is much broader. Mr. Bloomberg, a newly minted Republican and former businessman, believes that businesses and people leave a city when its services fall into disrepair, as they did in the 1970's. Mr. Pataki embraces the notion that taxes are what drive companies and residents away.
Dee Das, 19, a salesman at Go Jays, a kiosk that sells cellphones in the Staten Island Mall, sided with Mr. Bloomberg yesterday, though a bit reluctantly.
"This is the slowest month ever," he said. "People are scared of losing their jobs. No one feels secure. Cutting back on police and fire isn't good. People won't feel safe anymore. It's better to raise taxes. Not very high -- maybe by 2 percent."
John O'Mahoney, 59, a retired police officer, had a slightly different view. "I think Bloomberg is going about this the wrong way," he said as he waited for his grandchildren to finish riding the Easter train at the mall. "He should tax businesses, not the communities. Let them pay their fair share. We just got a big property tax increase. Why should the middle class always pay the brunt of the tax burden in New York City?" 
Either way, it is clear that people are starting to believe that oppressive service cuts are on the way. 
Carmine Gallo, 51, a special education teacher who lives on Staten Island, said the cuts to city agencies he had heard about in the past were things he could live with. Now, he is not so sure. "We're talking, when you have to go throw your garbage out, or when you want a cop and he doesn't get there for 20 minutes," said Mr. Gallo. "We want our firefighters. We need these policemen on the streets."
Proposed cuts to education -- which is slated for a 2 percent reduction in the 2004 fiscal year budget -- seemed to upset many New Yorkers. And many of them seemed to believe the message that is subtly coming out of City Hall, that part of New York City's burden could be eased by the governor. 
"I blame Bloomberg up to a point," said Mary Ann Carola, 56, who works at Public School 56 on Staten Island. "But he has to balance the budget. I blame Pataki more. There was federal funding given to the Board of Ed. Why don't they take that money and save jobs and do better for the children?"
Mrs. Goldman, the Brooklynite, said she was just starting to piece together what is happening from bits and pieces on television and the radio. "I think the governor should be interested in New York City, but from what I hear on television, he seems not to be," she said. 
But if people had much to say about how they might suffer as a result of the cuts, they had few ideas on how to patch the holes in the budget. 
"I know that we will give up on garbage; that has been given up before," said Beth Linskey, who splits her time between the Upper West Side and Columbia County, N.Y., where she produces jams for sale. 
What should go? She could not say. "We certainly have had less park maintenance before, and we survived," she said. "And it's wonderful that we've had such gorgeous parks. And maybe we shouldn't really give up the swimming pools that are open all the time, because that keeps crime down during the summer by giving kids a lot to do, so those are areas that you shouldn't cut right away.
"I mean, that's a tough one."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
HIBERNIA, LOUISIANA BANK, PLANS TO ELIMINATE 290 JOBS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

 BODY:
 Hibernia, Louisiana's biggest bank, plans to eliminate 5 percent of its work force to cut costs after first-quarter earnings fell 5.1 percent and lending money became less profitable. About half of the 290 jobs that will be cut are vacant, Hibernia said. 
Expenses related to eliminating the jobs will reduce earnings in the second quarter by $3.9 million, or 3 cents a share. Net income in the first quarter fell to $56.2 million, or 36 cents a share, from $59.2 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier, as homeowners paid down more of their mortgages, the company said. Revenue fell 3.9 percent, to $246 million from $256.1 million. The bank has $17.7 billion in assets and about 260 branches.

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Hardware: Electroglas To Cut 25% Of Work Force 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

 BODY:
 Electroglas Inc., a maker of semiconductor equipment, said yesterday that it would cut 25 percent of its work force in the next two quarters. The company also said delays in customer bookings and shipments led to a loss in its first quarter. 
The net loss widened to $23.3 million, or $1.09 a share, from $14.8 million, or 71 cents, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter ended March 31 fell 19 percent, to $9.47 million from $11.7 million. Electroglas employed 469 workers as of December 2002, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Its loss widened because of $8.5 million in expenses for writing down the value of its San Jose, Calif., campus, the company said. Shares fell 21 cents, or 13 percent, to $1.36.

HEADLINE: PepsiCo Reports 13% Rise In First-Quarter Earnings 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY

 BODY:
PepsiCo reported a 13 percent increase in its first-quarter earnings yesterday and attributed the growth to strong sales at its Frito-Lay North America unit, cost savings from its merger with Quaker Oats and the sale of a pasta business.
 PepsiCo showed growth in all of its major business areas. Overall worldwide sales increased 3 percent while global sales of snacks and beverages each increased 3 percent. But the continued growth at Frito-Lay North America was the brightest spot in the report. 
 For nearly a year, PepsiCo has been trying to revive business at Frito-Lay, its snack division. Heavy spending on trade promotions last summer failed to generate a significant increase in sales for the second quarter of 2002. In the months that followed, executives at PepsiCo pledged to lift sales at Frito-Lay, which generates two-thirds of PepsiCo's profits.
The latest quarter provided evidence that the company was moving closer to its goals, analysts said. Revenue at Frito-Lay North America rose 5 percent, to $2 billion, and operating profit was up 6 percent, to $506 million. Volume increased 4 percent.
"It's certainly improving," said Bryan Spillane, a beverage analyst at Banc of America Securities. "You can visibly see a recovery. The next phase is now that you're seeing the top line increase, you should start to see a better spread on profitability."
PepsiCo's earnings topped Wall Street's expectations, which had been fairly conservative because the weak economic environment negatively affected food and beverages companies throughout the quarter, analysts said.
In the first quarter, net income rose to $777 million, or 45 cents a share, from $689 million, or 38 cents a share a year earlier. The per share results included a penny gain from the $16 million sale of Quaker's Mission pasta business. Analysts had forecast earnings per share of 42 cents, according to Thomson First Call. 
Total revenue rose 4.1 percent, to $5.5 billion.
In the North American beverage business, revenue rose 4 percent, to $1.5 billion, and operating profit increased 5 percent, to $343 million. Total volume at the unit inched forward by half a percent, the company said, led primarily by sales of noncarbonated beverages. The carbonated soft drink business proved disappointing. Volume declined 2 percent during the quarter because of slow sales of Pepsi and Mountain Dew, two flagship brands.
"Although we're not satisfied with our volume growth, it is worth noting that it was all generated without acquisition," Steven S. Reinemund, PepsiCo's chairman and chief executive, said, alluding to the Coca-Cola Company, which reported Wednesday that much of its volume increases in the first quarter had come from acquisitions. "We do have some real bright spots in our portfolio, but we also have some challenges, and we will address those challenges." 
Mr. Reinemund said the forthcoming introductions of Mountain Dew LiveWire and Pepsi Vanilla would enhance the product line, which includes Gatorade, Aquafina bottled water and Tropicana juices.
Analysts described Pepsi's earnings as solid and said the challenges were easily surmountable. 
"The comparisons in both the Frito-Lay business and the soft drink business get easier as we go forward," said Carlos Laboy, a beverage analyst at Bear, Stearns. "We've got a pretty bright macro outlook for the second half of the year. Some key areas of the company that were question marks have been addressed, with the exception of North American soft drinks which we knew were going to be weak."
PepsiCo also said it would continue to do business with Fleming, the grocery wholesaler that filed for bankruptcy earlier this month, and with U.S. Foodservice, the American unit of Royal Ahold, which is being investigated for accounting irregularities. The troubles at those businesses are not expected to have a material effect on PepsiCo's business, company officials said. 
Shares of PepsiCo rose $2.64, or 6.6 percent, to $42.54.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: MONEY; 
Iraq to Run On Dollars Till It Gets New Currency

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17 

 BODY:
As the focus in Iraq shifts from waging war to paying wages, the Bush administration plans to run Iraq on dollars until it fosters a replacement for today's nearly worthless "Saddam dinars."
 American military officials are already paying Iraqi civil servants in dollars, and they expect to continue doing so for at least the next several months. But a team of experts from the Treasury Department is already commuting to Baghdad from Kuwait City, trying to determine the fastest and smoothest way for Iraqis to have a new currency and a central bank to control it. 
 Today, a senior administration official said it was in discussions with Peter McPherson, who was a deputy Treasury secretary under President Ronald Reagan, to serve in Iraq as a coordinator on financial issues during reconstruction. A Treasury Department spokesman declined to comment. 
The model is Afghanistan, which had several competing currencies and a financial system in shambles. Working with Afghan leaders, Treasury officials laid the groundwork for a unified Afghan currency and contracted with printers in Germany and Sweden to produce the actual bills.
"We will pay in dollars initially," John B. Taylor, assistant secretary of the Treasury in charge of international affairs, said in an interview today. "It's an interim measure, and we're not going to do it any longer than we have to. But the dollar has value and it's a stable currency."
The most likely strategy, Mr. Taylor said, will be to expand the use of old Iraqi dinars that were used before the first Persian Gulf war decimated Iraq's economy.
Iraq replaced the old "Swiss dinars," as they are known, with Saddam dinars, and then printed ever-larger quantities to make up for the government's chronic budget shortfalls. Though the government maintained the official exchange rate of Saddam dinars at 0.3 to the dollar, the black market exchange rate reached 2,000 to the dollar by the time American forces attacked Iraq last month. Today it is 3,000 to the dollar.
The older dinars continue to circulate in the autonomous Kurdish regions of northern Iraq, and they have kept most of their value because nobody has printed new bills since about 1990. The old dinars are now ragged, sometimes held together with tape, and there is no central bank that controls their supply. They simply recirculate in the regions.
Treasury officials are in the process of assessing the possibilities for printing new batches of the old dinars either in Iraq or abroad. Though Iraq did have printing and engraving plants, officials say they do not yet know how many of them are still functional or whether they can produce bills with modern anticounterfeiting features like holograms.
Many countries have created new currencies in the aftermath of war and upheaval over the last decade. Republics that broke free of the former Soviet Union have mostly adopted new currencies, as did countries like Bosnia that broke free from Yugoslavia. Kosovo, now an autonomous region of Serbia, has essentially adopted the euro.
Establishing a new currency is only a step in rebuilding Iraq's financial system. Iraqi prices have become almost entirely divorced from normal market forces. Inflation roared along at 60 percent a year, and perhaps much more, but the government also kept prices for many staples and for electricity and water far below their actual cost.
Until a new system is established, Iraq will be doing business in dollars, which have circulated widely in Iraq for years. By some estimates, Treasury officials say, as much as $500 million in American currency may be in Iraq.
Administration officials say the choice of a new currency ought to be made by Iraqis, and they insist that the administration is neutral on many basic issues of monetary policy. For example, Iraq could adopt a system of flexible exchange rates, which move in response to market forces. Or it could adopt a fixed exchange rate, which would require the central bank to intervene with its own reserves to keep the exchange rate at a constant level.
"This is something the Iraqis will have to decide and have a lot of ownership on," Mr. Taylor said.
