HEADLINE: Barn Praising 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
HALLOCK TUTHILL, a retired farmer in Cutchogue, talks about his barn as though it were a living, breathing thing.
 Gazing up at the neatly spaced rafters, he runs his hands gently over the uneven surfaces of the hand-hewn support beams and says, "She's a beauty, isn't she?" 
 The barn dates to the early 1700's, and as Mr. Tuthill walks through and describes the different sections of the barn, the history of the huge structure and the land it sits on comes to life.
Here, in the three bays of the original barn, Mr. Tuthill imagines an 18th-century farmer with maybe one cow and one horse, someone who was living off the land. Then big changes came in the early 1900's, when a wing was added and the barn more than doubled in size to accommodate what had become a thriving potato farm that produced food for tables throughout Long Island and New York City. 
By the time Mr. Tuthill bought the farm in 1941, modern equipment made the barn's grain room and horse stalls obsolete, so he used the barn instead as a chicken coop. Mr. Tuthill, 86, grew potatoes and raised chickens here until the late 1960's, when he sold most of the farmland.
But he kept the barn.
He uses it mostly for storage now, gardening equipment and an enormous pile of items collected for his church's spring yard sale. He still marvels at the soaring open framework, the carved wooden pegs and the precise mortise-and-tenon joinery that holds it all together. "Everything's just as tight as they could possibly fit," he said. "It's great carpenter work."
Mary Ann Spencer, a historic preservationist from East Setauket, came upon Mr. Tuthill and his barn last year as she conducted the first comprehensive inventory of barns on Long Island's North Fork. She sees the barn as "a quintessential Long Island barn because of its evolution through agricultural uses, its many additions and modifications."
Ms. Spencer said she decided to count and photograph every barn on the North Fork, because of the barn's place in Long Island's cultural history. Suffolk County's efforts to preserve farmland have focused attention on the diminishing rural lifestyle that once dominated the island. The barn, Ms. Spencer figured, is an often ignored icon in the rural landscape that deserved some attention. 
"Suffolk County will become Nassau County unless farmland preservation is successful, and barns are what identify farmland for us," she said. "Plus, I just think barns are intrinsically interesting because of their simplicity, their scale, the connection between form and function."
Ms. Spencer started her survey about a year and a half ago, using a grant she received through the Old House Society in Cutchogue, a local preservation group. She has yet to finish her final report, but her preliminary figures show 652 barns and 69 carriage houses. She estimates that about 40 percent of those buildings were built before 1950. She also found that 280 of the barns, or 43 percent, are still in agricultural use.
"I didn't anticipate the number would be that high," she said. "It tells you that agriculture on the North Fork is alive and well, and it's just wonderful to see how many of these buildings have been stabilized and maintained, how they've been loved."
Robert B. McKay, director of the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities, said Ms. Spencer's work is both timely and interesting. "Barns remain very much part of the story out there on the East End," he said. "Yet they are the most ephemeral of buildings, because once there's no pressing use for them, they disappear from the landscape."
Farming in Suffolk County has changed significantly in the last 50 years. The number of acres being farmed has dropped from 123,000 in 1950 to only about 31,000. But even though Suffolk County's farm acreage ranks among the lowest in New York State, it ranks first in market value, selling more than $168 million a year in agricultural products.
"It's a small portion of Suffolk County's total economy," said Pearl Kamer, the chief economist of the Long Island Association, the area's largest business group. "But it's a major share of New York's agricultural economy as a whole. And Suffolk County is obviously one of the most significant agricultural counties in the state."
Joseph Gergela, executive director of the Long Island Farm Bureau, said that to survive, "our guys have gone towards higher value agriculture to get a better return per acre." Only about half the farm acreage in Suffolk County is still in traditional vegetable and potato farming, he said, with the rest in vineyards and horticultural products like sod and ornamental flowers. "People like to say it's still rural out there, but it's really farming in and for suburbia," he said.
Despite these major shifts in the industry, there is still a need for barns, he said, noting that greenhouse farmers use barns for storing bulbs and equipment and vineyard owners will use them for winemaking and wine tasting.
At the Castello di Borghese Vineyard in Cutchogue, which is formerly the Hargrave vineyard, a converted 1949 potato barn is used as an art gallery and tasting room, where operas and receptions are held. Like many of the potato barns of that era, the lower walls are made of cinderblocks with stuccoed buttresses in the ground. The walls were so heavily reinforced because conventional barn walls would collapse from the weight of potatoes stacked inside and pushing out.
Ann Marie Borghese, who owns the vineyard with her husband, Marco, said she loved the sense of history at the vineyard, which celebrates its 30th anniversary this year and is widely recognized as Long Island's first.
On the back of the property sit several farm buildings, including a chicken coop, a stable and a barn that dates to 1850. That barn is now used for winemaking, bottling and labeling. In a nice coincidence, the barn also has an underground Prohibition room that was concealed beneath a tiny trap door. The room has a number of arched caves set into the walls that Ms. Borghese believes must have been used to hide liquor during the Prohibition. "It was uncovered during an earlier renovation," she said. "But the entry is so tiny, they must have had to send a child down to get anything out of there."
Finds like the Prohibition room help illustrate the versatility of barns, Ms. Spencer said. The room could have been part of a traditional root cellar that was hidden away when circumstances made it more useful as a secret room. Ms. Spencer said she found many barns that had been adapted for changing times on the North Fork.
The Conway farm in Southold, for example, has a small 19th-century barn that was originally used to board horses, but was modified when tractors replaced real horsepower. The barn was raised from its brick foundation, cinderblocks were laid on top of the bricks to add height and the wall planks had new planks attached at the bottom to double the barn's height. "That's why you see that line running across the middle of the barn," said Joe Conway, 64, a retired Southold police officer whose family rents its land to local farmers. "They raised it so machines could fit in there, but it all predates me."
Michael A. Tomlan, a founder of the New York State Barn Coalition, a preservation group, said barns like the Conway barn are proof that "the first places where the industrial revolution was made manifest was on the farm, not in the factory." Mr. Tomlan is also director of the graduate program in historic preservation at Cornell University; he helped start the coalition eight years ago to study and help preserve barns across the state. The group also helps publicize a 1996 law that gives tax credits to farmers and other business owners who rehabilitate historic barns.
Mr. Tomlan said people have a hard time understanding the importance of barns and agrarian life today because only 1.5 percent of the nation is involved directly in agriculture. "Barns are really rather sophisticated vehicles," he said. "They're not simply boxes that have been discarded on the landscape."
The coalition holds a conference each year, and this fall will come out to tour the North Fork. Coalition members are familiar with rural landscapes throughout the state, but the North Fork will provide one that is unique in many ways, particularly since it goes back to the 1700's, Mr. Tomlan said. "There are very few places in the state that have that continuous history of agricultural use," he said. 
Like many rural areas in the northeast, the traditional barn out here is the three-bay, English-style hay barn, a structure with vertical wood planks on the exterior, and with doors in the center of both broad walls so wagons could pull in, unload their loads and then drive straight out again. In a local adaptation, many of the barns are built into a hillside to give the structures a lower level with a side entrance, in addition to the ground level and hayloft.
Unlike other rural areas, the North Fork has virtually no silos because there were few dairy farms and, thus, no need to store large quantities of grain to feed cattle. But there are plenty of potato barns. In addition to potato barns with buttressed walls like the one at the Borghese vineyard, there are many barns set into the ground, with just the pitched roof and ventilation stacks visible above ground. Burying the walls below grade allows the surrounding dirt to act as a natural buttress for the walls.
The Wickham family farm in Cutchogue, which has been owned by Wickhams since the early 1700's and is now rented out as the David Steele Farm, has a little bit of all these things. The oldest barn there was built in the 1700's and some of the hand-hewn beams were so roughly finished that they still look like tree trunks. It's mostly used for storage now, including an old family buckboard and yokes for oxen. Nearby there is a 19th-century barn with a root cellar built into the ground that now holds farm equipment and a 20th-century potato barn that is still in use.
Virtually all the work buildings on the Wickham farm have always been painted -- what else -- bright barn red. "I guess that's just the way we've always thought it should be," said Gail Wickham, whose grandfather was the last Wickham to actively farm the land. Her father managed the property until he died last year. "My father was extremely proud of his farm and he took good care of all the buildings," she said.
Ms. Spencer said a farmer's pride in his work buildings was obvious everywhere she went. She said that after word got out about her inventory, several farmers who were out when she counted their barns would call her up and say, "Come on by again, I want to show you my barn."
Daniel Latham is the fourth generation in his family to work the Latham Farm out on Orient Point, and he gets sentimental about the main barn, which was built in 1840. The barn is 50 feet wide and about 120 feet deep. "It was a pretty large barn for that time," Mr. Latham said, adding that his great-grandfather had three pairs of horses, allowing him to rest a pair at all times.
"The new barns, you get more square footage and they're functional," he said, pointing dismissively to one of his modern metal barns. "But I like the old barns. This was put together with pegs, and it was built to last."
Mr. Gergela, from the Long Island Farm Bureau, said farmers spend a good deal of time in their barns, especially in the winter months, to work on equipment and prepare for the next season. "People have real offices now," he said. "But the barn's where you really operate your business out of; it's the informal office, the shop for doing things."
Mr. Gergela grew up on a potato farm in Jamesport, and he remembers the main barn being the center of his universe. "I can't really describe it," he said. "But there's a connection between farmers and their buildings. It's just the way it is."

HEADLINE: OPINION; 
When Imagination Took Flight

BYLINE:  By ED SMITS; Ed Smiths is chief executive officer of the Cradle of Aviation museum.

 BODY:
THE paradox is stunning.
 Against a backdrop of high-tech 21st-century aircraft overwhelming Iraqi air defenses, leaving Baghdad open to ground assault, the supersonic, Mach 2-plus Concorde is being retired. To add to the irony, the decision to ground this pioneering passenger plane comes during the centennial of aviation when we are pausing to look back at just how far we have come in 100 years and where we should be going. 
 Long Island has been connected to the Concorde since its first flight to the New World in November of 1977. With Kennedy International Airport its destination, the aircraft continues to slow traffic every time its dramatic delta wing and drooped nose swoops over the Island on its way to landing. Its initial arrival, however, sparked a typical Long Island response to virtually anything new -- not in my back yard. . Or more accurately, "not at my airport." At the time, a handful of Nassau County politicians sought to galvanize opposition to the Concorde on environmental grounds. It came to naught and the Concorde was Long Island bound. 
What is ultimately grounding our supersonic trans-Atlantic visitor is economics. Built far too small for genuine cost effective service, it was reserved for the wealthy or those on generous expense accounts. Throughout the plane's operational life, the cost of a ticket never dropped below $9,000. A far larger and much more economical version built by Boeing never got beyond a wooden mockup. Congress wasn't prepared to pay the price for development at a time when the Vietnam War was consuming our society. So the Concorde became the solo state-of-the-art example of commercial passenger flight at its zenith, arriving on Long Island with all the majesty of an ocean liner during the Golden Era of steamships.
In the beginning, no one thought Concorde would be the end of the line of supersonic transportation. Planners thought nearby Kennedy would be a host to a family of SST's by the 21st century, putting travelers scant hours from anywhere on the globe. But as the Columbia shuttle tragedy proved, and the fuel tank fire that claimed an earlier Concorde, technology ages out with dangerous results. Bits of rudder continue to shed from Concordes on a regular basis, and upgrades were putting the SST operators deeper in debt at a time when airline revenue is declining. 
The retirement of the Concorde and the Columbia catastrophe remain in stark technological contrast to the prowess of American military technology exhibited in Iraq. We have used our extraordinary skill in technology development to reinvent warfare. Never before in the history of mankind has such care been exercised to avoid the deaths of noncombatants through the use of precise munitions. Stealth aircraft, remote-controlled aircraft and a squadron of other aviation advances will punctuate the history of this conflict and set new future standards. 
As we observe the centennial milestone of the Wrights' first flight, is this the sole direction of our advances in aviation? Do we as a nation no longer have any interest in creating advances in commercial aviation, pioneering space flight and lunar exploration? Do the Concorde and the shuttle reflect the high-water mark of aviation's peaceful application? Are these amazing vehicles to be left to museums as symbols not of what we can achieve but of where humanity decided to stop? 
The Cradle of Aviation has in its collection a half-scale model of the Concorde. It was taken down from its perch as an advertisement at Times Square and donated to the institution by British Airways. Our intent is to erect it as an icon inspiring a new generation of Long Island aviation pioneers to move beyond the limits of Concorde. Long Island manufacturers and others throughout the country have made possible the X-43, NASA's experimental hypersonic scramjet that will reach any place on earth in two hours. For the sake of our society's future we must use our skills, intellect, energy and treasure to continue aerospace discovery and produce an aircraft that will not only break the sound barrier but make the world a true global village. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: AIRPORTS (90%); AIRLINES (89%); AIR FORCES (89%); MILITARY AIRCRAFT (78%); AVIATION SECTOR PERFORMANCE (76%); UNMANNED AIRCRAFT (73%); VIETNAM WAR (64%) AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; CONCORDE AIRPLANE

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
StressIs Up. So Why Are Mental Health Benefits Down?

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
FEELING anxious or depressed? The continuing uncertainties of war, terrorism and the weak economy have left many people longing for stability and looking for ways to cope. But just when some people could arguably gain the most by spending a little time on a therapist's couch, their mental health benefits are at risk.
 In a survey this month by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press in Washington, about a third of the people questioned said they felt depressed by the war with Iraq. Russ Newman, executive director for professional practice at the American Psychological Association, said the war was affecting the vast majority of the group's patients, based on a survey conducted last month, but that it was "just the latest stressor." 
 "Over the years, the stress people feel just continues to increase," he said.
The share of employers offering mental health benefits, however, dropped to 76 percent last year from 84 percent in 1998, according to the 2002 benefits survey of the Society for Human Resource Management. Because health care costs are estimated to rise 15 percent this year, "employers are looking for areas where they can cut costs," said Jennifer Schramm, manager of workplace trends and forecasting for the human resources group, "and mental health is one of the areas that's easier to cut."
"People are less likely to protest because of the stigma around it," she added.
Even if they don't cut benefits outright, some employers are increasing co-payments and deductibles, said Patrick Leary, a group health care consultant at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a human resources consulting firm based in Washington. Others are reducing out-of-network coverage, he said. That is significant because many psychologists and specialists do not participate in large health care networks.
By reducing mental health coverage, employers may be hurting themselves. In a study released in February by Mercer Human Resource Consulting and Marsh Inc., an insurance broker, 70 percent of 723 employers reported that stress or depression had increased in cost or frequency as a disability condition during 2001. That was a higher figure than for any other health problem, including cancer, lower-back pain or repetitive trauma like carpal tunnel syndrome. "Many industries have been cutting back on staff because of the economy, but the work still has to be done," said George Faulkner, a principal at Mercer. "That exacerbates the stress."
In 1996, Congress took the first step toward elevating mental health coverage to a par with medical and surgical care. It passed legislation that prevented private plans from setting lower annual or lifetime caps for mental health care than for other types of coverage. But that law allowed companies to require much higher deductibles and co-payments for mental health treatment than for other kinds of care.
A bill introduced this past winter in the House and the Senate would close those loopholes. But it's no panacea; like the original bill, it would apply only to employers who already offer mental health coverage, and then only to those with 50 or more employees. There has also been talk of restricting the disorders covered by the bill -- excluding, for example, post-traumatic stress syndrome, anorexia and autism. 
OF course, the bill could backfire, even with the restrictions. "I've certainly heard of employers who've said they'd drop their mental health coverage if the legislation goes through," said Ruth Donahue, a health care consultant in the Chicago office of the Segal Company, a benefits consulting firm based in New York.
Noting that employers found ways to circumvent the original 1996 legislation by requiring higher co-payments and deductibles, Ms. Donahue said, "if they put real teeth into this new parity legislation, it will be interesting to see what kind of creative ways employers find to get around it again."
And for an already anxious public, that may be just one more thing to worry about.

HEADLINE: For Charities, the Taxman Cometh 

BYLINE:  By GARY SANTANIELLO 

 BODY:
AS the state cuts back on the amount of money it passes to cities and towns and their budgets get tighter, several municipalities are going where few tax collectors have gone before. They are sending property tax bills to nonprofit organizations.
 Encouraged by a State Supreme Court ruling in December that allowed Bridgeport to tax a homeless shelter, some communities have already begun rejecting the tax-exempt status of similar groups and others are looking into doing the same thing. 
 New Haven is taxing an organization that provides emergency and transitional shelter for women and children, Hartford is taxing an organization that runs a halfway house, a substance abuse rehabilitation center is being taxed in Windham and Bridgeport has sent tax bills to several nonprofits. Stamford is asking organizations such as the YMCA, Jewish Community Center, the Italian Center, Saint Luke's Community Services and Stamford Hospital to justify their current exempt status. 
"It's a sign of how desperate cities are for tax money, especially in light of the cutbacks in state aid to cities and towns," said Kevin Maloney, spokesman for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, an association of cities and towns.
The groups, shocked by the new strategy, said the taxes will not only cut into the services they offer, but also possibly force them to close altogether. That, the groups said, would put the burden of providing services back onto communities that don't have the money.
"How pathetic this makes us look to the rest of the country," said State Senator Bill Finch, a Democrat whose district includes Bridgeport and Trumbull. "The most affluent state in the country, and we're forcing municipalities to tax homeless people."
Verenda Smith, a government affairs associate at the Federation of Tax Administrators in Washington, said the economic climate was forcing municipalities to find new revenue.
"Such activities are unique to each state and locality, and how laws are interpreted also is going to be unique," she said. "Where you might see a trend emerging is in administrators combing through statutes and as diligently as they humanly can making sure that every tax that ought to be collected, is collected.
"What this issue boils down to is what legislators and governments think public policy ought to be in this area, whether the public benefit these nonprofits provide outweighs the costs to the public."
The Bridgeport Rescue Mission, the subject of the Supreme Court ruling, is facing a $300,000 tax bill. The mission, founded in 1993, is a nonprofit organization that provides shelter for the homeless, operates a substance abuse recovery program and serves roughly 110,000 meals a year. In 1996 the mission took over the Fanny Crosby Memorial Home in Bridgeport, which provided housing for the elderly.
The Fanny Crosby property was treated as tax-exempt by Bridgeport from 1927 until 1996, when a new tax assessor, Pam Davis, began looking more closely at the tax-exempt status of nonprofits that provided housing. "She was very aggressive in her approach," said John Fabrizi, the mayor of Bridgeport.
In 1996, the city put the property on its grand list, citing the state statute that disallows tax-exempt status for properties used for housing. Bridgeport Superior Court upheld the city's position that the low-and moderate-income housing provided by the mission was not a "charitable purpose" because the group received rent from some of the tenants.
The mission appealed to the State Supreme Court, where it was represented pro bono by David Lehn of Kleban & Samor of Southport. The court unanimously upheld the trial court's decision on Dec. 31, basing its ruling on a strict interpretation of General Statute 12-81(7), which defines tax-exempt properties, and a 2001 case that found an organization must be "exclusively charitable" to be tax-exempt.
By this time, the mission's tax liability had grown to $300,000, nearly half its annual operating budget.
"We don't have any resources," said the Rev. Terry Wilcox, its executive director. "We have no endowment or reserve fund. We're thrilled when we finish a fiscal year in the black. Last year was an especially good year -- we finished with $8,000 in our checking account."
Mr. Wilcox said a settlement in the $30,000 range had been discussed with city officials, "but then we'd have to go out and raise $30,000, and it's not easy to raise money to pay your taxes. Hopefully, we can find some way to keep operating."
Although the Bridgeport mission's tax bill has received the most headlines, "it's not just a Bridgeport issue anymore," said Dr. Rudy Feudo, executive director of the Greater Bridgeport Adolescent Pregnancy Program, a maternity home for pregnant and parenting teens that pays $8,000 in taxes to the city. "It's a statewide issue."
Encouraged by Bridgeport's success levying taxes against the mission and similar nonprofits, Connecticut municipalities are applying 12-81(7) more aggressively. Windham, for example, is taxing Perception Programs, a counseling center for substance abusers. The group is appealing its $35,000 tax bill.
"We're like those cities, but on a much smaller scale," said Mike Paulhus, first selectman of Windham, home to a number of nonprofit agencies serving northeastern Connecticut. "We're in the same boat, looking for the same money."
Maurice Segall, deputy director of the Pro Bono Partnership, a tax-exempt legal resource center for nonprofit organizations and lawyers, said the interpretation of the state statute on nonprofits shouldn't come from the towns.
"The bottom line is that application shouldn't be contingent upon a person in a government agency's reading of the statute," he said. 
Mr. Segall said the scope of the statute was limited.
"It was meant to stop for-profit developers of affordable housing from being tax-exempt," he said. "It didn't have as broad a reach as it's being given now."
Whatever the intent, the reach is extending. In New Haven, a half-dozen nonprofit agencies are challenging these tax-collection efforts. One of them, ALSO-Cornerstone, which provides prevention, treatment, recovery and supportive housing services for people with mental illness and substance abuse problems, successfully fought a tax bill three years ago, and now is trying to reach accommodation with the city on a $25,000 tax bill.
"We're taking people who literally are homeless off the Green and providing them housing, and now the city wants to tax our housing," said Jerry Ross, the executive director.
Mr. Ross said he was working with other nonprofits to preserve their tax-exempt status and change the legislation. Similar efforts are under way in Bridgeport, although some nonprofits have made accommodations with the city.
Bethel Recovery Center, a shelter in Bridgeport for abused women and children who are homeless, initially tried to fight a $25,000 tax bill, then reluctantly agreed to pay the city $7,000 a year in taxes.
"It's settled, so at least we can breathe and know they can't take this place away," said Janice Kelly, the executive director. "I was losing all of my funding. I was writing for grants all the time, but with these funders, their bylaws state that if a nonprofit has any kind of legal problem with a municipality, they can't give them money. I said to myself, 'I've got to get rid of this problem."'
Another nonprofit group, Isaiah 61:1 of Bridgeport, decided to fight its tax bill and won.
"If we weren't blessed with an attorney that went to bat for us, we would've done the same thing as Bethel Recovery Center," said Ed Davies, executive director of Isaiah 61:1, a halfway house for people completing prison sentences. "We would've paid more in legal fees than in tax bills."
Represented by Mr. Segall, the group won its case in Superior Court, before the same judge who ruled against the Bridgeport mission. Bridgeport has appealed the decision to the Supreme Court. "If the city wins, we're looking at $12,000 to $15,00 a year that's not in our budget right now," Mr. Davies said.
To clarify this issue, State Senator John McKinney, a Democrat from Fairfield, reintroduced a bill in January through the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee to amend 12-81(7) so that transitional housing facilities such as homeless shelters and substance-abuse centers are exempt from local property taxes.
Passage of such a bill would help organizations, but it would deprive municipalities of tax revenue at a time of decreasing state aid. The consequences in Bridgeport, said Ted Gwartney , the tax assessor, would be that "many new properties would qualify for tax exemption -- a substantial number."
That would further constrain tax-burdened cities like Bridgeport and New Haven, which claim they already are shouldering a disproportionate load by being a haven for nonprofits that are zoned out of surrounding communities.
"Senator McKinney's heart is in the right place," said State Representative James Holloway, a Democrat from Bridgeport, "but there's no transitional housing in Fairfield or Darien. Bridgeport is fighting this thing by itself. We're a magnet for every social service that's out there."
"The current tax system is unfair, but on my best day I couldn't vote for that bill," said Senator Finch, a former Bridgeport city councilor. "There's a feeling within certain cities in Connecticut that they do more than their fair share for social services, and they're the ones least able to afford it."
"Socially, we need these nonprofit organizations, no question about it," said Russell Liskov, the associate city attorney of Bridgeport. "But don't shove everyone into one narrow area and say 'sink or swim' and you, the poor, have to foot the bill. The burden has to be spread among communities. If it falls on one city, that city needs to get money to pay for it." 
The most likely source of that money would be from the state, but considering its monumental budget problems, that's unlikely. "In this economic climate, I don't know how that bill could pass," Mr. Segall said.
That leaves nonprofits fearful of new tax liabilities.
"Unfortunately, towns and municipalities are starting to look at nonprofits as their private piggy bank," Ron Cretaro, executive director of the Connecticut Association of Nonprofits, which represents more than 500 charitable organizations. "We've seen this issue pop up a lot, though it's not yet as prevalent as it could be."
One unanswered question raises is whether municipalities will end up spending more in services provided than they are gaining in taxes. "If these nonprofits aren't able to function, ultimately it will cost cities and towns more money," said Mr. Cretaro.
Mr. Wilcox of the Bridgeport Rescue Mission agreed: "Any money the city takes for taxes is money that won't go to feed and clothe and house poor, hungry people, and meet basic human needs. I empathize with the city's plight. I'm a homeowner in Bridgeport. But we're not costing the city money; we're saving the city money."
Further, the nonprofits argue, the tax money going to city can't possibly be spent as efficiently as they can spend it.
"Nonprofits don't have that bureaucracy, and their administrative costs are very low," Dr. Feudo said. "Plus, they can act immediately to try to resolve some of these issues."
Some municipalities, though, see the issue in terms of fairness.
"I view it strictly as a matter of equity and responsibility," said Bill O'Brien, the tax assessor of New Haven. "It's not fair to have the rest of the residents carry the burden of exempt properties that are not eligible to be exempt."
Jorge Perez, a New Haven city councilor, said the two sides were just going to have to come to an agreement on the issue.
"Government officials have to use their common sense dealing with these organizations when they're not trying to defraud and cheat," he said. "You have to make accommodations. The public good is not served by putting these organizations out of business."

HEADLINE: Office Data: Many Players, Fuzzy Numbers 

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
LIKE so many other significant developments in the New York real estate business, this one was triggered by a proposed rent increase. 
 During the inflationary years of the 1970's landlords were trying to pass on rising costs to tenants, each in proportion to the amount of space they occupied, recalled Robert F. R. Ballard, an executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company. 
 The problem was that few agreed on what percentage of the total rent increase should be assigned to each tenant, because there was no accepted compilation of building sizes and layouts.
So Mr. Ballard and some assistants set about collecting information on every major building in Manhattan that was not completely owner occupied, and they published the Directory of Manhattan Office Buildings in 1978. The book, which was priced at a whopping $79.50, contained pictures, layout plans and floor sizes for each of the 500 buildings listed, along with their ages and heights and the names of the owner, architect and principal tenants. 
The book was the predecessor of the computerized databases that now provide up-to-date information for landlords, tenants, brokers and investors. Several ambitious efforts in the field did not survive the implosion of the dot-com companies, but others have become well established.
The larger national players, as well as some specialized companies that focus on investors, are increasingly adding analytic capabilities to their services, so users can probe the databases in search of economic opportunity. The addition of analytical tools is a conscious emulation of what the Bloomberg terminals did in disseminating financial information for the markets for bonds and other debt securities. Other smaller players have sought out niche markets, such as supplying listings for economic development agencies or for print publications' Web sites that carry the brand of the host organization. 
"A lot has happened over the last two years," said Andrew C. Florance, president of CoStar Group, one of the most prominent of the real estate information services. "Our long-term goal was not to be a listings service, but to try to quantify what is happening in commercial real estate markets." Traditionally, he said, real estate has been a localized business with information on market conditions and transactions often hard to find.
Based in suburban Washington, CoStar says it is attempting to supply data on more aspects of the real estate market by adding, among other things, information on building sales and prices to data on vacancy rates, direct and sublet spaces and asking rents. The company collects its data at 34 offices in the United States and Britain and has about 875 employees.
Mr. Florance said CoStar, which has acquired 14 data reporting companies over the last few years, is attempting to impose order on the chaotic industry by setting standards for how information is collected and reported. This is a new development for an industry where each brokerage company has had its own standards for what types of buildings to monitor and how to present data.
In New York, where the number of buildings changes only slowly over time, each of the large brokerage firms reports different figures for vacancy rates and average asking rentals. For example, the current office vacancy rate in Manhattan varies from 10.39 percent to 14.6 percent, according to various reports, while the average asking rent has been reported at anywhere from $32.37 a square foot annually to $43.39 a square foot. The disparities can be caused by things as simple as the failure of building managers to return telephone calls from researchers seeking information on leasing, industry executives say, or disagreements as to what buildings are grouped in Class A, Class B and Class C.
Other differences are caused by varying definitions. Some firms will track only buildings over a certain size; others include smaller properties. Submarket definitions vary as well. "Midtown South" is in the eye of the beholder, and brokerage companies tend to hold on to old definitions to keep their statistics comparable over time.
Having accurate information about the state of the market is important for those making investment decisions, particularly about starting new construction, Mr. Florance said. He said it is generally agreed that when the vacancy rate in an office market reaches 15 percent, starting new buildings is unwise.
The vacancy rate hit that level in 1990 in the Washington area, he said, but no one could be sure at the time "because the reported vacancy rate was 8 to 23 percent." The result, he added, "was massive overbuilding." 
He said that because many large brokerage companies use CoStar data to establish base lines, while doing specialized research on their own, the variations among reports is less than in the past. "They are within a few points of each other these days," he said. 
But some research executives say that it takes too long for CoStar to collect and publish data for the information to be completely useful to brokers trying to make deals and that the company's data does not go into enough detail. Other researchers say the economic interests of companies that market services to landlords and tenants alike tend to use data collection methods that have an influence on the final results.
No company can buy all the information it needs about real estate on open markets, said Maria Sicola, the senior managing director for research for Cushman & Wakefield, which downsized its research department in 2000 during the dot-com boom.
"We were swept up in the e-commerce notion that information was going to become a commodity available to anybody," she said. "In about two months we realized that was not going to be the case." 
By then, however, the company had laid off about 30 of the approximately 100 people on its research staff and sold its current database at the time to RELocate, a successful leasing research company that focused on the New York market.
The database was used to create RealtyIQ.com, which tried to compete with CoStar, but collapsed when revenues did not come close to meeting the debt incurred in setting up a national system. It was one of several ambitious reporting projects that failed or never got started after investors soured on the profit potential of Web-based services.
Bruce Z. Weissberg, who ran RELocate for about 10 years before selling to the investors backing the RealtyIQ venture, said a service like CoStar's has become essential, particularly for smaller brokerage companies that cannot afford research staffs. But he said it is hard for users to know how accurate and timely the information is. "CoStar said it calls properties on a monthly basis, which is actually hard to do," he said. "In any case, the information is 30 days old. When we had a different database, brokers bought both."
Mr. Weissberg said he is currently associated with D. G. Hart, a Manhattan brokerage, and is managing a redevelopment project in Chicago.
Ms. Sicola said Cushman & Wakefield had retained its historical database after the sale and a research staff of about 70 people, and rebuilt its research capability based on information not available from public sources. "We have 800 brokers and 100 appraisers, and they are constantly meeting with owners, building agents and tenants," she said.
"They add information to the database about who has space that may not be on the market yet and tenants who may need space," she said. "For example, we know there is as much as 8 million square feet of shadow space out there -- that is, space that is not on the market but could be. We know where that space is, but it is not reported by any service."
ACCOUNTING rules and practices have recently been changed with the intent of limiting the reporting of losses that cannot be accurately measured, but these changes are not likely to force this shadow space into the open, according to Gregory A. Tosko, an executive managing director in Insignia/ESG's consulting operation.
Existing rules force publicly owned companies to take losses against current earnings when they sign subleases at rents less than they are paying the landlord. But companies are not allowed to take charges for unused shadow space as a means of improving future earnings reports, Mr. Tosko said.
Still, investors would be wise to keep an eye on companies that keep piling sublet space on the market, Mr. Florance observed. "Often," he said, "a big sublet is a flag signaling that a company is in big trouble." 
Joseph R. Harbert, the chief operating officer of Insignia/ESG's metropolitan New York region, said he buys basic information from CoStar, but also relies on his company's brokers to get closer to the current market. "We think of brokers as the best single source of information, so we do broker-centric information gathering," he said. While listing services can provide asking rents for properties, brokers who are shaping the deals are in the best position to know what the actual taking rent was that resulted from negotiations.
Mr. Harbert said that while CoStar's reporting system, which includes 550 researchers making telephone calls backed up by a people in a fleet of vehicles making on-site inquiries, has improved over the years, information from brokers doing deals will almost always be closer to the market. "We think we have an edge of two to four weeks in time, and greater accuracy," he said.
Building managers have a greater incentive to give full information to a broker than to a researcher, because the broker may bring a tenant to the property, Mr. Harbert said. Nevertheless, he noted that his company had a 15-member research staff to fill in information gaps left by the brokers. 
Brokers active in a market are more sensitive to changes in building classifications, said Matthew Barlow, an executive managing director of Julien J. Studley, a brokerage that has traditionally represented tenants. Buildings in New York are generally grouped in three grades: Class A, for the newest and best equipped; Class B, for older properties in less choice locations; and Class C, for the least desirable space.
"Of 1,100 buildings listed by a third-party data service, we had different classifications on 300, which can significantly alter the statistics," he said, adding that Studley brokers had a meeting last month during which the classification of 35 buildings was changed. The criterion? "If 55 out of 60 brokers say a building is Class B, then it is a B building," he said.
Brokerage companies that represent landlords and property managers have an incentive to describe the market as more robust than it may actually be, said M. Myers Mermel, the chief executive of TenantWise.com, a Web-based service that combines listings with brokerage activities.
"They have a conflict because they represent landlords as well as tenants," he said, an argument echoed by other tenant brokers and firmly rejected by their competitors who represent interests on both sides of the space leasing process. 
Mr. Ballard, who prepared the book that was the precursor of the databases now available for New York, said his original objective was to settle disputes over rent escalations. "The landlords wanted escalations and the tenants were supposed to pay their proportionate share of the increase," he said. "The landlords' accountants sent out bills with the increases each year, but the bigger tenants didn't buy that. At the time, in many cases neither the landlord or the agent knew how many total square feet were in a building, so it was hard to peg the correct percentage for each tenant."
With the blessings of his superiors at Cushman & Wakefield, Mr. Ballard approached the publisher McGraw-Hill with his proposal. It was accepted, and the publisher assigned an editor and an assistant to help gather data.
The project entailed long hours at the city's Department of Buildings, going over floor plans and recording when buildings opened and who designed them. The legwork also included visiting buildings, dealing with often-uncooperative landlords and literally measuring the floors.
This was still the age of paper, so each building had its own folder containing plans, photographs and clippings from industry publications. Some notable properties, like the Chrysler Building, required more than one folder, Mr. Ballard said.
In all, it took about 3,000 hours of work over two years to complete the project. Cushman & Wakefield's research department was a result of the book, he said. "It happened slowly, starting with one person," he said. "But the company wanted to be known as a real estate services company that really knew the market, so it grew over a 20-year period to what it is today."
Mr. Ballard recalled that he had had no interest in updating the book as information changed and new buildings were added. "I was worn out," he said.
One company that did was Yale Robbins Inc., whose magazine-style Office Buildings publications largely followed Mr. Ballard's format. "Bob Ballard did the first book, and he did a great job as a one-man show," said Henry Robbins, executive vice president of the company. "We wanted to do a joint venture with Bob, but I guess Cushman & Wakefield did not want him to do it."
THE Robbins company has since added Web-based information to its printed publications, with a listing service called MrOfficeSpace.com. Unlike most data services, which charge users for information, MrOfficeSpace.com offers its information free, while charging listers for displaying enhancements beyond basic data.
Robbins has also developed a business of hosting the office space listings for publications like Crain's New York Business and business groups like the Alliance for Downtown New York. Another smaller player, Cityfeet.com, has developed a niche hosting space listings for the Web sites of newspapers, including nytimes.com.
Two years after the dot-com related shakeout, the real estate information services appear to be financially stable, if not hugely profitable. CoStar, which is publicly traded, has reported that it is profitable as measured by earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, an accounting standard preferred by real estate companies. It has not yet reported a profit according to the more demanding standards used by most major corporations.
Others report they are cash flow positive, meaning they have more money coming in than going out, although not profitable in a fully accounted sense. Many other listings services exist, including the San Francisco-based LoopNet.com, which claims to have the largest number of listings and users.
The Ballard and Robbins publications and their electronic descendants have largely been marketed to brokers and renters and users of office and retail space.
Meanwhile, other electronic information services have been developed that are aimed primarily at real estate investors. Once again, the model is the Bloomberg service, which combined data on securities trading with automated analytic capability so that prospective investments could be quickly ranked against one another.
One of the leading players in this sector is Reis Inc., a New York based company that sells Web-based reports on the financial condition of various markets around the country and of individual properties and the terms of sales transactions.
Lloyd Lynford, the president of Reis, said he started publishing paper reports on real estate markets in 1980 but has migrated to a Web-based system as the technology has evolved. "The last year and a half has been a time of evolution," he said. "Despite the crash and burn of the dot-coms, Web-based delivery ofinformation on commercial real estate to lenders and investors has grown in response to evolving markets."
He said real estate investment managers need timely and accurate information because they compete for capital with managers who invest in stocks and bonds, where access to information is almost instantaneous. "We need a Bloomberg for real estate," Mr. Lynford said.
He said the company focuses on 50 major real estate markets in the United States and collects its basic data quarterly, but is emphasizing adding tools so that its 9,000 desktop users can quickly analyze their portfolios or prospective purchases in response to changes in market conditions. "Real estate is valued as an income stream, so you want to be able to figure the impact of a change in interest rates," he said.
The Reis database includes information on some individual properties as well as general market conditions and includes likely financial outlooks for them. For example the database includes estimates that the 2.5-million-square-foot former Port Authority warehouse at 111 Eighth Avenue, between 15th and 16th Streets, which is now mostly an office building, will have a net cash flow of $57.9 million this year. This is expected, the database says, to rise to $58.6 million by the end of next year and $59 million by 2005.
Mr. Lynford admits that the figures, which seem amazingly precise, are based on a standard set of assumptions, which can be changed and the results automatically recalculated. Indeed, a page is attached to the financial display giving a user a long list of variables to be changed if the user thinks his own estimates are closer to reality.
The largest category of customers for Reis services is lending institutions, because most real estate transactions are financed with far more debt than equity, Mr. Lynford said. Using the system, a loan officer can enter the loan terms and derive an estimate of a property's worth and estimate the likelihood of a default by the owner.
These estimates will become increasingly important as lenders have to conform to new international standards for holding financial reserves against potential losses. In general, the higher these reserves, the lower a lender's profitability.
"What is the probability of default? Is it 2 percent or is it 8 percent? Bankers need to know the answer," Mr. Lynford said.
Although automated information systems are improving, Robert M. White, president of Real Capital Analytics, which sells information services to investors, said his group collects its own data on $8 billion of sales in progress. "We maintain a proprietary database because there are no standards out there," Mr. White said. "What is a community shopping center? No one agrees. 
"We do sales comparables, including who the players were in a deal, how much was paid and the other details," he said. "There was no other data available, so we had to create it."

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
A Mixed Message For the Schools

BYLINE:  By DEBRA NUSSBAUM

 BODY:
ALMOST half the state's superintendents and educators are trying to figure where they went wrong. When they finish sorting that out, they will have to resubmit their school budgets to municipal boards and councils and decide where they can cut -- from personnel or programs.
 On Tuesday, voters in 208 of the state's 550 school districts, or 63 percent of them, rejected their budgets, and 342 approved them. In all, the New Jersey School Boards Association said that only 14.7 percent of all registered voters went to the polls last week -- a typically meager turnout. 
 Around the state, results were mixed, with 80 percent of the proposed budgets receiving approval in Essex, Morris, Mercer and Middlesex counties and fewer than 50 percent passing in Hunterdon, Passaic, Camden, Burlington and Salem counties.
"When the economy is sluggish, the success rate tends to go down," said Michael Yaple, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association.
Last year, when the economy was also stalled, voters approved 359, or about 65.4 percent, of the 550 proposed budgets -- a drastic drop from the previous five years, when the stock market was robust. In 2001, 81 percent of the budgets were approved, and 88 percent were accepted in 2000. 
In 2002, districts faced financial difficulties caused by a freeze in state aid along with increases in costs ranging from transportation to insurance to special education, Mr. Yaple said. 
This year, costs continued to escalate, he said, and although state will rise by $200 million for the 2003-2004 school year, half of that will go toward construction projects.
"There's not a lot of wiggle room in these school budgets," Mr. Yaple said. "There's contractual obligations and state and federal regulations. Some districts are getting increases, but they are puny. So many of these districts have enrollments that are constantly growing. A lot of districts are just trying to hold on to what they have."
According to state law, budgets that are rejected by voters must be submitted to borough or town government boards, which can approve them as is or make changes and vote again.
Of course, the districts took different tacks to get budgets approved. In Cherry Hill, where voters rejected the $134 million budget by a vote of 3,078 to 3,407, Superintendent Morton Sherman said his district would look at cutting positions and scaling back on transportation. 
But to Mr. Sherman, the larger question was why more parents had not come out in a district of 11,600 students.
"I'm not sure I can figure it out," he said. "I'm just frustrated. There's a lot of complacency I don't understand among the parents."
In the end, he attributed the rejection to frustration with the state government. "Trenton is not doing its job," Mr. Sherman insisted.
Edwina Lee, executive director of the New Jersey School Boards Association, agreed that the brunt of voter dissatisfaction over taxes was taken out on schools.
"This is the only budget people can vote on," Ms. Lee said. 
She said some districts now faced "painful cuts" that would result in larger classes and delays in maintenance and other projects. 
"What are the choices?" she asked.
In the case of Cherry Hill, which was seeking an increase of about $9 million, a spokeswoman, Susan Bastnagel, said that parents and administrators had worked to get the word out that the budget would allow existing programs to continue, keep class size the same and not add new programs.
Increases in health benefits, special education costs and busing all added to the growing budget, Ms. Bastnagel said.
She said that district officials had wanted to shrink class sizes in the high school, increase the number of world language programs in the elementary schools and institute full-day kindergarten classes, but that they did not even try putting those items in the budget because they would have been prohibitively expensive.
"There are things we would like to have, but this isn't the time," she said.
As in many districts throughout the state, parents and administrators in Cherry Hill held coffees and informational sessions about the budget. In addition, material was mailed to all residents, and messages were broadcast on the local cable channel.
"We tried to reach out to all different constituencies," Ms. Bastnagel said.
Nor was Cherry Hill the only district that faced defeat after putting in some hard work. In Washington Township, Gloucester County, a school district with 10,000 students, Superintendent Thomas Flemming and his staff worked with no fewer than 11 budget committees made up of local residents. Yet the $114 million budget --a $7 million increase over the current year --was voted down 3,024 to 2,300.
The way he viewed the situation, it was not a rebuff of his stewardship but rather "a reaction to taxes in New Jersey."
Still, not all the news was bad. In such districts as Bloomfield, in Essex County, with 6,000 students, programs and staff positions would have been cut had the $62 million budget -- an increase of $4 million over last year --not been approved by a vote of 1,427 to 1,107.
Starting in February, Superintendent Thomas Dowd explained, the administration put on evening presentations, mailed fliers and used the local-access cable channel to get word to voters that the district was suffering from cuts in state financing at the same time costs were rising.
"The key was letting people know that until the state funding is appropriately addressed, we have to find ways to fund these programs," Mr. Dowd said.
In the Ocean Gate School District in Ocean County -- made up of one elementary school with 198 students -- voters approved two budget questions that will add $125,000 to the $2.2 million budget.
"I couldn't have been more surprised that we passed both," said Frances O'Loughlin, the district's business administrator, who attributed the passage to a "push from the PTA" to get parents to the polls.
At this time of year, educators in the 550 districts that seek voter approval may well envy their colleagues in the districts that rely on a board of estimate to determine the tax rate and approve the budget. About 50 districts around the state -- like Montclair -- bring their budgets to a board, usually composed of town council members and some school board members. 
This year, Montclair received approval for its $80 million budget, a $4 million increase over last year, on April 1.
Not having to take the budget to the voters can work both ways.
"Sometimes it may be more difficult," said Dana Sullivan, the district's business administrator. "It depends. It's a yearly thing. At this point, it's a relief."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 27, 2003

HEADLINE: War And Politesse 

BYLINE:  By JEREMY PEARCE

DATELINE: ROXBURY 

 BODY:
FROM pancake socials to Elks Club dinners, Representative Rodney P. Frelinghuysen cuts a mellow, unfailingly polite figure among his constituents in northern New Jersey. The son of a former member of Congress and the scion of a Republican political dynasty of sorts, he jovially fields questions and, in his office, answers each and every letter.
 As for legislative duties, he has long preferred to tinker with tax reforms and such local issues as the location of train lines. But in recent weeks, the war on Iraq has overshadowed Mr. Frelinghuysen's status as a social moderate and fledged him into a hawk, one whose voice in Congress carries more than symbolic resonance. He happens to be New Jersey's senior member of the powerful House Appropriations Committee and sits on its defense appropriations subcommittee, the body that earlier this month approved a $75 billion advance for the Bush administration to finance the war. Last week that amount grew to $80 billion in a Senate vote. 
 In the transformation, Mr. Frelinghuysen (FREE-ling-high-sen), 56, has not lost the gloss of his amiable manner, but his language, sometimes salted with mild oaths of the prep school variety, is more aggressive now, even as he takes pains to stress the propriety and grounds for the military invasion. 
"I think there is enough evidence that even if there are not factories, the Iraqis have caches of different chemical and biological agents, and there's some real potential for reaching terrorists, given the history of this regime," he said in an interview after a town meeting here. "And yes, I think this has been a training ground for terrorists."
He paused, then issued this warning to any Iraqis who might use unconventional weapons against United States troops: "For those who would perpetrate and press the chemical button -- they ought to pay with their lives. We will find out before our dying day who was responsible. You do something like that, and you can count on paying a huge penalty."
Indeed, Mr. Frelinghuysen plays politics from the balls of his feet. He is a trim, erect and nimble man, a runner and tennis player whose energy overflows into daily contacts with a constituency of 650,000 in the 11th Congressional District, which spans all of Morris County and parts of Essex, Somerset, Passaic and Sussex counties. It is safe to say that he practically owns his seat, having recorded clear-cut victories in the last three elections and winning 73 percent of the vote last year. 
He is also an Army veteran, who served a tour in Vietnam that he said colors his view of the war in Iraq. After graduating from Hobart College, where he studied American history, he was drafted and became a clerk in a construction battalion, spending a year overseas building roads and seeing flashes of combat. 
"We were mortared, we took fire and it's a frightening and horrendous experience," he said recently, with an occasional stutter that belies the image of a controlled, pedigreed lawmaker.
"So I have a deep respect for these young people that are out there in a huge land area. We don't need demonstrations supporting the Iraqi regime or Columbia professors suggesting that America deserves to suffer 100 Mogadishus. I don't regard that as a hawkish view on my part."

The Costs of Victory
When it comes to the monetary costs of the war, he is less sure-footed. A fiscal conservative, he continues to support the idea of federal tax cuts, while both the House and Senate try to reconcile proposals that would result in tax reductions on the order of $350 billion to $750 billion. He says such cuts would in fact be essential for the domestic economy's recovery in the aftermath, once the fighting ends and the reconstruction of Iraq begins.
"I don't know anyone who can pinpoint what the overall cost of this war is going to be," he said. "This $74.5 billion may well be a substantial down payment, but we think there would probably be similar supplementals in the future. There are no limits. Most people would agree that we need to spend what we need to be victorious."
About the tax cuts, he said: "The real question is about who is going to get back most of the money into their pockets. Some of us on the majority side say that those of us who pay the most taxes ought to be getting most of the tax relief."
He then added: "I do think tax cuts are a pretty good way of giving people more confidence."
The congressman also supported the Homeland Security Act but shared others' concerns about possible civil liberties encroachments in anti-terrorism measures that were advanced by Attorney General John Ashcroft. Mr. Frelinghuysen's aides said he had "felt reluctance" about the so-called Ashcroft amendments but decided that "the greater good in the bill won out."
Mr. Frelinghuysen's political rise has been marked by steady steps and patient application. After Vietnam and a year in graduate school, he returned home to Morris County to work as a grants coordinator for the County Board of Chosen Freeholders. His first political race -- for a freeholder's seat -- was helped along by name recognition, and it came just as his father, Peter H.B. Frelinghuysen, was retiring from a 22-year career representing New Jersey in Congress. Because boundary lines have been redrawn over the decades, the younger Frelinghuysen's district covers part of his father's old constituency, including Morris County, but does not reflect it exactly.
"That was 1974, which of course was the Watergate year, and a hell of a time to run," he recalled. "Nixon had done a pretty good job of disgracing himself and making it difficult for any Republican aspirant -- even one with a name like Frelinghuysen -- to run for public office."
Yet Mr. Frelinghuysen won that race and spent nine years as a county official before moving to the state Assembly, where he served for 11 years. From his start in state office, he found a place on the Legislature's Appropriations Committee and gained an education that he said had prepared him when he entered Congress in 1995.
His father provided other tuition. The elder Frelinghuysen often took his son along to social events, introducing him to the flesh-pressing and casework that the younger energetically calls the "hallmark of my administration."
When in New Jersey, Rodney Procter Frelinghuysen lives in Harding Township with his wife, Virginia, and their two children. His father, now 87, lives in the same town.
Sumner Putnam, a friend, said that he had witnessed the seeds of youthful ambition when the two attended St. Mark's, an Episcopal boarding school in Southborough, Mass. Mr. Putnam, who lives in Bedminster, said Mr. Freylinghuysen's subscriptions to a British newspaper, The Manchester Guardian, and The Christian Science Monitor, immediately set him apart.
"Rodney had an innate curiosity and was already reading widely," he remembered. "He worked at it. And that's the fun thing about his career -- he certainly worked his way from the bottom up."
Even so, Mr. Frelinghuysen had family models and precedents. Four others bearing his surname served as United States senators, and one of them ascended to Secretary of State under President Chester A. Arthur. Others were Revolutionary officers and ministers, the offspring of Dutch settlers who first moved to Somerset County in the 1720's. Another ancestor, Theodore Frelinghuysen, ran unsuccessfully for the White House with Henry Clay. 
"Frelinghuysen was everything that Clay wasn't -- a president of the American Bible Society and a very righteous and proper New Jerseyan," he said. "Clay was an incredible orator and gambler, womanizer and drinker. It was a good team, I guess."
A history buff, Mr. Frelinghuysen is somewhat wide-eyed about his own lineage.
"Subconsciously, I suppose it does influence me," he said with a smile. For one thing, he added, his family has witnessed many decades of great change across New Jersey -- "the disappearance of farmland, the end of the big estates, everything that has been snapped and gobbled up."
Mr. Frelinghuysen said that he considered the key to his popularity to be both hard labor and a mostly moderate platform. Following many Democrats, he has opposed drilling for oil in the Alaskan National Wildlife Refuge, pushed for purchases of open space around the state and championed projects that promote mass transit and environmental cleanups. Further pushing the ideological envelope, he has supported financing for youth services and believes in women's legal right to abortion.
Thomas A. Zelante, chairman of the Morris County Democratic Committee, said, "People view him as being decent and honorable and as holding viewpoints similar to Democratic viewpoints."

'He Has Walked in Our Shoes'
Another Morris County official, John J. Murphy, director of the county's Board of Freeholders, said that Mr. Frelinghuysen's thrift had also struck a chord.
"He has walked in our shoes and understands what kinds of projects we need funding for," Mr. Murphy said. "But he's also very practical about his politics and watches every penny as it's spent."
For all of the political snuggling, Mr. Frelinghuysen has made clear some sharp differences with the administration of Governor McGreevey.
He wonders how much the rights of property owners are at risk, for example, in the planning map devised by the state Department of Environmental Protection to add new land-use restrictions for developers.
"The horses are already out of the barn, with the completion of all the Interstate highways that cross New Jersey, from east to west and north to south," he said. "Let the developers achieve their monetary objectives, but legally prevail upon them to do things to minimize the burdens on local infrastructure." 
And he is skeptical about Mr. McGreevey's handling of the state's projected $5 billion budget deficit. "I have no suggestions for the governor," he said. "I guess he's doing what he has to do. But I'm not sure he has done enough to solicit from the various constituencies from which he has cut -- what literally the day-to-day impact is going to be."
Recently, speaking at the town meeting that he had scheduled in Roxbury, the congressman took questions about the Iraq war, nursing homes, veterans' funds, loopholes for obtaining immigrant visas and the marriage penalty tax. The queries ranged from the mundane to the cranky, and Mr. Frelinghuysen fielded them with equal attention. But when a constituent asked about an element of the war on terrorism that would allow the Central Intelligence Agency to listen in on overseas cellphone calls, he came to life.
"You're damned right we should be eavesdropping on every damned cellphone out there," he said, snapping his fingers. "We need to act like that." 
Yet as confident as he may be on the home front, Mr. Frelinghuysen acknowledges that drafting large packages of legislation has never been a strong point. Even with his illustrious ancestors, there is still no Frelinghuysen Act on the national law books, although the family name is attached to a Warren County township, an arboretum in Morristown and a thoroughfare in Newark. 
A survey of bills that Mr. Frelinghuysen has recently sponsored shows initiatives to prohibit telemarketers from interfering with telephone caller identification services; to establish a program to test veterans for hepatitis C; and to name New Jersey an American Revolution National Heritage Area.
And then there is the bill that deals with "the liquidation or reliquidation of certain entries of pasta."
Its purpose?
"I should be able to do justice for the record on what that is," Mr. Frelinghuysen said, flagging for a moment. "Somebody is getting the short end of the stick around here, in terms of importation of pasta, although I'm not exactly sure what that is."

Teacher, Broker Anything
But he brightened again when asked about his ambitions for the future. A run for the Senate against the state's two seated Democrats would be tempting, he said, but seeking the chairmanship of the House Appropriations Committee would be more likely. According to his own historical research, a New Jerseyan has not held that title since the committee was founded in 1865.
And after Congress? 
With characteristic energy, he said: "I could easily see myself being a teacher or doing something at a college. And I always thought it would be fun to be a stockbroker."
In a final burst, he added: "Hell, I'm ready for anything. Retired public servants are an asset that ought to be pumped and utilized."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
The Pinelands Plan

BYLINE:  By JAMES J. FLORIO; James J. Florio was governor of New Jersey from 1990 to 1994.

 BODY:
GOVERNOR McGREEVEY has made combating unrestrained and uncontrolled growth a priority of his administration, and we can expect changes from the State House aimed at facilitating balanced economic growth while protecting New Jersey's environment and our overall quality of life. The Pinelands Commission, of which I am the chairman, has had this goal for 20 years. In fact, in its pursuit of sustainable growth, New Jersey is fortunate to have in the Pinelands model what is likely one of the greatest regional planning success stories. It offers a conceptual model for consideration by the rest of New Jersey.
 Authorized by federal legislation I introduced as a member of Congress and by state legislation signed by Gov. Brendan T. Byrne in the late 1970's, the Pinelands Comprehensive Management Plan is the regulatory code that guides land use, development and preservation of the million-acre Pinelands, covering all or parts of 53 municipalities in seven counties. In addition to designating nine land-use management areas, similar to municipal development zones, the plan sets forth a variety of resource protection and management programs covering issues like water quality, threatened and endangered species, forestry, historic and cultural resources, wildfire management and open space acquisition. 
 While there are many state and regional land-use plans around the nation, the Pinelands plan is unusual in that it has the regulatory teeth to facilitate smart growth. The basic framework requires municipal land use and zoning ordinances to comply with the plan's goals and principles to protect natural resources and guide growth. This provides a key mechanism for implementing and enforcing the standards of the plan. 
Many strategies touted today as weapons for the war on sprawl have already been successfully applied in the Pinelands. Through its land use management areas, the Pinelands plan designates what intensities and types of growth are suitable for a given area. This has virtually halted suburban sprawl in much of the Pinelands and has supported appropriate development in areas deemed suitable based on criteria like the presence of infrastructure, prevailing development patterns and environmental conditions. The plan's rules prevent the construction of certain growth-generating infrastructure in conservation areas, while the Pinelands Infrastructure Trust Fund provided $30 million to support infrastructure investments in the designated growth areas. 
An important component of the plan is a transfer-of-development-rights program, which helps to redirect growth from the preservation and agricultural districts, where development is largely restricted, to growth areas supported by infrastructure. Landowners in conservation areas may deed-restrict their property in exchange for Pinelands Development Credits. In turn, developers buy credits to increase development opportunities, in the regional growth areas, within prescribed densities. To date, this program has permanently protected nearly 37,000 acres in the heart of the Pinelands. 
The Pinelands plan encourages redevelopment of older industrial towns such as Egg Harbor City, Hammonton, Woodbine and Buena Borough through the Pinelands Town designation. This designation has facilitated the development of state-of-the-art sewerage treatment plants as well as a special project to streamline the approval process for industrial parks. An economic development program has helped seven rural Pinelands communities identify economic opportunities compatible with their needs and community character. The commission's long-term monitoring continually takes the temperature of the Pinelands economy by gauging an array of indicators from property values to employment to cranberry prices. 
The plan also offers a phased-growth program that allows towns to stage development over both time and geographic areas to facilitate growth in an orderly fashion. Hamilton Township in Atlantic County has adopted this program, reserving 2,000 acres for future development. The program is similar to the timed-growth concept proposed through legislation in Trenton. It represents the common-sense observation that growth should be coordinated with the availability of the infrastructure necessary to sustain it.
Today, the concept of smart growth is directly linked to protecting the quality and adequate supply of water resources. Watershed planning has been fully integrated into the Pinelands plan since its inception in 1980. The state and federal Pinelands acts both recognized the importance of protecting the 17-trillion gallon Kirkwood-Cohansey aquifer and the regions vast network of rivers, streams and wetlands. 
The commission is addressing some of the challenges faced by communities in the Pinelands area in planning for and absorbing growth. The commission has received a grant from the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation for creation of the Pinelands Excellence Program. With a focus on zoning, infrastructure and open space, the program is working with two municipalities -- Winslow and Hamilton Townships -- to develop prototypical approaches to smart growth planning and creating sustainable communities
The Pinelands plan is a truly smart growth plan, but there is always room for improvement.
The commission is committed to addressing the remaining challenges while recognizing that smart growth by its nature requires a cooperative approach among a multitude of agencies at every level of government, as well as a significant private investment. As chairman, I am dedicated to building bridges to all our partners toward this end. 
I often think of the Pinelands experience as a sort of laboratory experiment in regional planning, growth management and natural resource protection. In view of the sprawl that has besieged much of New Jersey and the nation, there is little doubt that the Pinelands region would look much different today had it not been for the achievements of this plan. The commission is committed to continuing the course set nearly a quarter century ago, while at the same time addressing remaining and emerging challenges.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Tom Bloom)
