HEADLINE: Art World Asks, Who Is Next? 

BYLINE:  By MARIA NEWMAN

DATELINE: Englewood 

 BODY:
WHEN the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood shut its doors on Monday because of financial problems, it sent a "there but for the grace of God" shudder through the arts world in New Jersey as arts groups face zero financing from the state under a budget proposed by Gov. James E. McGreevey.
 "It's very sad news," said Jeffrey Woodward, managing director of the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, and chairman of Art Pride New Jersey, an advocacy group. "It shows how fragile arts institutions are. If you lose a source of your funding, things go south very quickly. Unfortunately, unless you see a restoration of the state funding cuts, you're going to be seeing a lot more of this." 
 Arts advocates also said the closing would be felt far and wide.
"It will create a void, in the City of Englewood, in Bergen County, in the educational system," said Sharon Harrington, chairwoman of the state Council on the Arts and the state Historical Commission, which hands out millions in grants each year. "They were a very important part of the community, of the economy of the community and of the cultural life of the region."
Jeffrey Norman, vice president of public affairs for the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newarkalso also called the news "so very sad." He said he had tickets to hear Ira Glass, who is featured on National Public Radio's "This American Life," at the Harms next week. "I bought the tickets six months ago."
Directors of the Harmscenter, when announcing the closing at a news conference on Monday, said their financial problems were not related to the financing they would lose from the state next year, if the Governor's budget is adopted. They attributed their problems primarily to their inability to pay off a $2.3 million debt accumulated during a $6.6 million renovation in the 1990's that turned the 1926 Victorian-style theater into a state-of-the-art performance hall.
But even so, many arts advocates saw a connection between the bleak prospects for state arts financing and the closure, which also was a reminder of what a tightly woven chain of money arts institutions depend on. If one link breaks, it loosens the entire chain.
"The crushing burden of the debt makes fundraising virtually impossible," said Robert Stern, president and chairman of the Harms Center's board, explaining why it had not found someone to rescue the institution. "Individuals and foundations are paralyzed, reluctant to commit scarce and precious resources to an organization that faces an enormous and overwhelming debt."
People active in the arts world said they were surprised by the closing. Ms. Harrington of the arts councils said the Harms leadership was not to blame.
"They have a good, committed board," she said. "I'm confident they did everything they could to fend this off. It's very disappointing."
The Harms was what is considered a "presenting," rather than a "producing" organization. Like the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, the State Theater in New Brunswick and the South Jersey Performing Arts Center in Camden, the Harms brought in a variety of acts or companies to put on performances. While these venues vary in size, they all rent their spaces to outside producers and agencies for performances, often one-night stands, for concerts, comedy acts and dance companies.
Others, like the McCarter Theater in Princeton and the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, are producing organizations whose main mission is the production of dramatic theater although the McCarter presents outside acts as well.
The Harms brought to Englewood, and the entire northern New Jersey region, a range of performers, from the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, to the Moscow Circus. Recent acts included Dr. John, a New Orleans bayou-funk piano player and singer, and the actress and comedienne Janeane Garofalo. The Harms also runs a well-attended performing arts school for children and stages special shows for families.
The Harms was built in 1926 as the Englewood Plaza, a showcase for vaudeville. As the times changed, it showed silent movies, and then talking pictures. In the 1970's, it fell into disrepair, and was threatened with demolition.
In 1976, John Harms, a local concert impresario, led a drive to save the theater. Mr. Harms, who was an organist, was a director of the John Harms Chorus, and in the 1940's, had started engaging well-known concert artists to appear in Bergen County with that group. He helped find private and public money to renovate the theater; after he died in 1981, the theater was renamed for him.
Located on North Van Brunt Street, off the city's main thoroughfare, Palisade Avenue, the Harms is credited by many locals with bringing new life to downtown in the form of restaurants and other businesses.
The renovation program that the directors said was the root of the current problems began in 1996. The center got a new roof, air conditioning, sound system, marquee, and additional seating that brought capacity to 1,400. Two years ago, a new fiber-optic cable linked the theater to the nearby Bennett Recording Studios for live music recordings and broadcasts.
The debt was one burden. Also the center's revenues have suffered in the last two years. Like many other live theaters, the Harms center had to cope with declines in consumer spending and in philanthropy after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. In summer 2002, ticket sales were down $100,000 compared with the previous year, and corporate donations were down $150,000.
"Maybe the renovation was overly ambitious," said Frank Huttle, a new board member. "But we do have a world-class theater."
The directors would not say this week if they are going to declare bankruptcy, and still appeared to hold out hope that someone could come to the rescue.
Mr. Norman of NJPAC said the news had further galvanized art advocates to fight the proposed arts cuts. A rally to support arts financing is planned for May 14 in Trenton. At performances throughout the state, directors and others are making appeals to the public. On the Web site of almost every state arts organization, there is a message about the issue, and a link that people can use to contact their legislators. 
The governor has pledged to restore half the arts budget, but the decision is now in the hands of the legislature.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The closing of the John Harms center "will create a void," said Sharon Harrington of the state Council on the Arts. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)
